Without the waxing and waning of yin and yang, the One likewise cannot be seen. For yang does not stand alone—it necessarily attains its establishment through yin. Thus, yang takes yin as its foundation, while yin cannot manifest itself except by awaiting yang. Therefore, yin takes yang as its counterpart. Every movement and stillness, every advance and retreat, every cold and heat—all are the workings of yin and yang. Yet there is no agent acting upon them, nor is there a principle of two standing independently. Either yin prevails over yang, or yang prevails over yin. There is nothing that is not so, no time that is not so. Yin and yang are but a single ebb and flow: when advancing, it is called yang; when retreating, it is called yin. Yang’s retreat is yin’s arising—not that yang retreats and then some other yin arises. Viewing yin and yang as one is permissible, as is viewing them as two. In general, generation is always the work of a single yang. As yang grows by one part, yin arises by one part beneath it—not that when yang wanes, one seeks out yin to replace it. Thus, yang’s return is *fu* (復), the original state of things, while yin’s arising is *gou* (垢), a chance encounter. Yin and yang are the yin and yang within yang. When speaking of qi, yin and yang are primary; when speaking of hardness and softness, they are the yin and yang within form. Here, a thing is discernible as either hard or soft.

Master Cheng said: "At the juncture of yin and yang’s waxing and waning, there is no abrupt division, yet the principle of separation remains. Their ascending and descending, their life and death—these great distinctions cannot be absent." He also said: "The movement of yin and yang—its rising and falling, its fullness and contraction—never ceases for even a moment. Yang is ever full, yin ever deficient. The slightest imbalance gives rise to ten thousand changes. It is like a turning millstone: though its teeth are uneven, once set in motion, endless variations emerge."

Master Zhu said: "Yin and yang are the root of creation and cannot be without each other. Their waxing and waning follow a constant pattern, beyond human alteration. Yet yang governs life, yin governs death, and thus their categories admit distinctions of good and ill. In the *Yi*, the Sage, addressing their inseparability, clarifies them through attributes like strength and compliance, benevolence and righteousness, without partiality. But at the juncture of their waxing and waning, where good and ill diverge, he never fails to express his intent to uphold yang and suppress yin. Speaking of the natural qi of Heaven and Earth, they cannot be without each other. But speaking of the symbols of the noble and the petty, one would wish the world to be entirely noble, without a single petty man. When framed in terms of good and evil, as in *‘Treading on frost, solid ice arrives,’* the arising of a single yin is like the emergence of a thief. Yang is good, yin is evil; the noble and the petty, Heavenly principle and human desire—these contend in victory and defeat."

He also said: "Why compare yin to the petty man? Viewed in isolation, it seems fine. But by category, though its outward form may be flawed, its essence remains sound." Master Yi Chuan said: "The tenth month is called the yang month—one might doubt whether yang is present, yet yin is the same." The Sage did not speak of it thus. Cai Jitong disagreed, saying: "Yin cannot contend with yang, just as Earth cannot match Heaven." Master Zhu remarked that the reason the Sage did not speak of it was that this itself reveals the Way of assisting and completing. For to restrain yin and advance yang, to foster the good and diminish the evil, to employ the noble and dismiss the petty—this is clearly evident. When yang transforms into yin, it is like a gradual shrinking away without a trace, hence it is called *transformation*. When yin transforms into yang, its momentum gradually grows, becoming more distinct, hence it is called *change*. When yin is less than yang, in qi, principle, and number, whether used wholly or partially, the difference lies here.

Master Shao said: "Yang is the function of the Dao; yin is the substance of the Dao. Yang employs yin, yin employs yang. When yang is taken as function, yin is honored; when yin is taken as function, yang is honored." Master Zhang said: "Yang moves, yin is still; yang is noble, yin is base. Yin can never be spoken of on equal terms with yang. Yet when adapting to time and change, yang contains yin, yin contains yang, and they alternate in function. When yang is exhausted and yin is pure, Kun prevails; when yin is exhausted and yang is pure, Qian prevails."

I say: In the *zi* month, the *si* month honors yang; in the *wu* month, the *hai* month honors yin. In terms of division, Qian is noble and Kun is base—they cannot be equated. In terms of the family, though father and mother are both honored, the mother can never be equated with the father, for there is no second supremacy. Master Cai said: "Yang is not complete without yin, yin does not arise without yang, and yin and yang further rely on each other for function. Yet in qi, yang is the function, hence yang moves and yin is still. In form, yin is the function, hence yin is swift and yang is relaxed."

Master Zhu said: "When the Supreme Polarity divides, it is merely two yin and yang, which encompass all things under Heaven. The *Yi* does not depart from yin and yang; its thousand changes and ten thousand transformations are but these two. When yin qi flows, it becomes yang; when yang qi flows, it becomes yin. This single qi, in its waxing and waning, advancing and retreating, produces the boundless affairs of Heaven and Earth from ancient times to the present. Take day and night, cold and heat: one is horizontal, one is vertical. Viewed horizontally, the principle is uniform—left is yang, right is yin; front is yang, back is yin; facing is yang, turning away is yin; advancing is yang, retreating is yin; east and south are yang, west and north are yin; spring and summer are yang, autumn and winter are yin—all follow the same pattern. Viewed vertically, the principle is likewise uniform—above is yang, below is yin; facing upward is yang, covering is yin; ascending is yang, descending is yin; clear is yang, turbid is yin; great yang and small yin, high yang and low yin, beauty is yang, ugliness is yin. Extending this by category, there is nothing that is not so, no time that is not so. The more finely it is analyzed, the more subtle it becomes; the more deeply it is explored, the more boundless it grows."

chunks.original_text: 阴阳之精，互藏其营。 阴阳之气，循环迭至。 阴阳之质，从横曲直，莫或使之，莫或御之。 在天则阴阳成象，在地则刚柔成质，在人则仁义成德，莫匪阴阳也。 邵子日#4：阴以阳为体，阳以阴为体。 阳得阴而凝，虚赖实以立。 阴待阳而发，实从虚而出。 阴至坤而成体，乾之十二阳托焉。 故阳以阴为体。 复自坤出三十一变而央，为春为夏，则阴以阳为用。 阳至乾而成体，坤之十二阴托焉。 故阴以阳为体。 娠自乾出三十一变而剥，为秋为冬，则阳以阴为用。 在天则阳动而消阴，在地则阴动而消阳。 极阴之际，坤余十二阳，其终成乾而得三十六阳．o极阳之际，乾余十二阴，其终成坤而得三十六阴。 以坤之阳而生震坎艮二十阳，以乾之十二阴而生巽离兑二十阴。 散一为三，生之始也。 并为三十二，阴阳各得八位之半。 以巽离兑之二十八阳而生乾之三十六阳，以震坎艮之二十八阴而生坤三十六阴。 会三归一，生之极也。 并而为六十四，阴阳各得八位之全。 所以立春至立秋，阳数并之皆六十四，阴数皆三十二。 立秋至立春，阴数并之皆六十四，阳数皆三十二。 四八三十二者，四卦之全。 八八六十四卦，八卦之全也。 图左三十二阳，右三十二阴，分天地之体，并之皆六十四卦者。 阳极无阴，阴极无阳也。 邵子曰：离束坎西，当阴阳之半，为春秋昼夜之门。 又曰：阳侵阴，阴侵阳，故坎离当半也。 先天六十四卦气，皆中起以八卦配十二辰。 子午卯酉为四中。 乾当午，坤当子，离当卯，坎当酉。 故曰：乾坤定上下之位，坎离列左右之门，得其正矣。 四维之卦，则兑辰巳震，丑寅巽未，申艮戌亥也。 而邵子又曰：坎离阴阳之限。 离当寅，坎当申，数常脸之者，阴阳之溢也。 盖谓用数不过乎中，以寅申巳亥居四孟之首。 乾当巳而生於巳，坤当亥而生於亥，离当寅而限於三阳之半，坎当申而限於三阴之半，中则瑜其限而溢矣。 况气盈朔虚，其余各六。 《易》曰：日中则反，月盈则蚀。 亦邵子怕处其盛之意，而退一位以居之，则卯辰兑也，子丑震也，午未巽也，酉戌艮也。 皆处数之不及，而不瑜乎中也。 是故以坎离之半，而当阴阳之半也。 若以坤为子半，推之则卯酉中矣。 故卯为日门而居左，太阳所生。 酉为月门而居右，太阴所生。 为春秋昼夜之门者，春分阳中，秋分阴中。 故曰：日中宵中，昼夜均也。 非若夏至则昼数多，冬至则夜数多也。 非但日月之出入於此，而万物亦出生入死於其中也。 翁氏曰：天地虽始於寅，而开物至卯，而门弥辟。 虽始於戌，而闭物至酉，而门已闭。 一岁而春夏秋冬，一月而弦望晦朔，一日而旦昼暮夜。 虽皆坎离，日月之功，而莫不由乎门之左右矣。 张氏曰：离当卯而终申，昼之分也。 坎当酉而终寅，夜之分也。 又曰：离当寅未卯而已明，坎当申巳酉而未昏。 天克地以为余分，昼常多夜五刻者，离阳侵坎阴，昼阳侵夜阴也。 愚以大数言之，开物於鸾垫后，闭物於立冬前，阴阳互相侵也。 故乾全用，坤全不用，坎离用半也。 坎离二卦，是乾坤中爻之交。 先天位坎离，以卯酉而为日月。 后天位坎离，以子午而为水火。 只此四#5位极好，阳中有阴，阴中有阳，是皆羲文之微意。
chunks.translated_text:
The essence of yin and yang mutually conceals its nourishment.
The qi of yin and yang circulates in alternating arrival.
The substance of yin and yang—whether vertical or horizontal, curved or straight—is moved by none, restrained by none.
In heaven, yin and yang form images; on earth, hardness and softness form substance; in humans, benevolence and righteousness form virtue—all are none other than yin and yang.

Master Shao says: Yin takes yang as its body, and yang takes yin as its body.
Yang solidifies through yin, and the void relies on the solid to stand.
Yin awaits yang to manifest, and the solid emerges from the void.
When yin reaches *Kun* (☷), it forms a body, and the twelve yang of *Qian* (☰) are entrusted therein—thus yang takes yin as its body.
After thirty-one transformations emerge from *Kun* and culminate, spring and summer arise—then yin takes yang as its function.
When yang reaches *Qian*, it forms a body, and the twelve yin of *Kun* are entrusted therein—thus yin takes yang as its body.
After thirty-one transformations emerge from *Qian* and decline, autumn and winter arise—then yang takes yin as its function.

In heaven, yang moves and diminishes yin; on earth, yin moves and diminishes yang.
At the extreme of yin, the twelve residual yang of *Kun* ultimately complete *Qian*, yielding thirty-six yang.
At the extreme of yang, the twelve residual yin of *Qian* ultimately complete *Kun*, yielding thirty-six yin.
From the yang of *Kun* arise *Zhen* (☳), *Kan* (☵), and *Gen* (☶), totaling twenty yang; from the twelve yin of *Qian* arise *Xun* (☴), *Li* (☲), and *Dui* (☱), totaling twenty yin.
Dispersing one into three marks the beginning of generation.
Combined, they number thirty-two, with yin and yang each occupying half of the eight positions.
From the twenty-eight yang of *Xun*, *Li*, and *Dui* arises the thirty-six yang of *Qian*; from the twenty-eight yin of *Zhen*, *Kan*, and *Gen* arises the thirty-six yin of *Kun*.
Converging three into one marks the culmination of generation.
Combined, they number sixty-four, with yin and yang each occupying the full eight positions.
Thus, from the Beginning of Spring to the Beginning of Autumn, the sum of yang numbers is sixty-four, while yin numbers total thirty-two.
From the Beginning of Autumn to the Beginning of Spring, the sum of yin numbers is sixty-four, while yang numbers total thirty-two.
Four times eight is thirty-two, the completion of the four trigrams.
Eight times eight is sixty-four, the completion of the eight trigrams.
The left diagram shows thirty-two yang, the right thirty-two yin, dividing the bodies of heaven and earth—combined, they form the sixty-four hexagrams.
At the extreme of yang, no yin exists; at the extreme of yin, no yang exists.

Master Shao says: *Li* (☲) in the east and *Kan* (☵) in the west stand at the midpoint of yin and yang, serving as the gates of spring, autumn, day, and night.
He also says: Yang encroaches upon yin, and yin encroaches upon yang—thus *Kan* and *Li* occupy the midpoint.
The qi of the sixty-four precelestial hexagrams all arise from the center, with the eight trigrams corresponding to the twelve earthly branches.
*Zi* (子), *Wu* (午), *Mao* (卯), and *You* (酉) are the four centers.
*Qian* corresponds to *Wu*, *Kun* to *Zi*, *Li* to *Mao*, and *Kan* to *You*.
Thus it is said: *Qian* and *Kun* establish the positions of above and below; *Kan* and *Li* arrange the gates of left and right—this is their proper alignment.
The trigrams of the four corners are: *Dui* (☱) at *Chen* (辰) and *Si* (巳), *Zhen* (☳) at *Chou* (丑) and *Yin* (寅), *Xun* (☴) at *Wei* (未), *Gen* (☶) at *Shen* (申), and *Xu* (戌) and *Hai* (亥).
Master Shao further says: *Kan* and *Li* mark the boundary of yin and yang.
*Li* corresponds to *Yin* (寅), *Kan* to *Shen* (申)—those who examine the numbers often verify this as the overflow of yin and yang.
This means that the application of numbers does not exceed the center, with *Yin*, *Shen*, *Si*, and *Hai* occupying the heads of the four seasons.
*Qian* corresponds to *Si* and is born at *Si*; *Kun* corresponds to *Hai* and is born at *Hai*.
*Li* corresponds to *Yin* and is bounded by the midpoint of the three yang; *Kan* corresponds to *Shen* and is bounded by the midpoint of the three yin—when centered, they exceed their bounds and overflow.
Moreover, as qi waxes and wanes, the remainder is six.
The *Book of Changes* says: "At midday, it turns back; when the moon is full, it wanes."
This also reflects Master Shao’s caution regarding excess, retreating one position to reside in *Mao* (卯), *Chen* (辰), *Dui* (☱); *Zi* (子), *Chou* (丑), *Zhen* (☳); *Wu* (午), *Wei* (未), *Xun* (☴); and *You* (酉), *Xu* (戌), *Gen* (☶)—all positioned where numbers fall short, not exceeding the center.
Thus, the midpoint of *Kan* and *Li* corresponds to the midpoint of yin and yang.
If *Kun* is taken as the midpoint of *Zi*, then *Mao* and *You* are centered.
Therefore, *Mao* is the gate of the sun, residing on the left, where the great yang is born.
*You* is the gate of the moon, residing on the right, where the great yin is born.
As the gates of spring, autumn, day, and night: at the spring equinox, yang is centered; at the autumn equinox, yin is centered.
Thus it is said: "Midday and midnight are equal, as are day and night."
This is unlike the summer solstice, when daylight is longer, or the winter solstice, when night is longer.
Not only do the sun and moon rise and set here, but all things are born into life and enter death within it.

Master Weng says: Though heaven and earth begin at *Yin* (寅), the opening of things reaches *Mao* (卯), where the gate is fully opened.
Though they begin at *Xu* (戌), the closing of things reaches *You* (酉), where the gate is already shut.
In a year, there are spring, summer, autumn, and winter; in a month, there are crescent, full, waning, and new moons; in a day, there are dawn, day, dusk, and night.
Though all depend on the functions of *Kan*, *Li*, the sun, and the moon, none occur without the gates of left and right.

Master Zhang says: *Li* corresponds to *Mao* and ends at *Shen*—this is the division of day.
*Kan* corresponds to *You* and ends at *Yin*—this is the division of night.
He also says: *Li* corresponds to *Yin*, *Wei* (未), and *Mao*, where it is already bright; *Kan* corresponds to *Shen*, *Si* (巳), and *You*, where it is not yet dark.
Heaven overcomes earth to create the surplus, so daylight is always longer than night by five *ke*—*Li* yang encroaches upon *Kan* yin, and daytime yang encroaches upon nighttime yin.
In my humble opinion, speaking of the greater numbers: things open after the Waking of Insects (*Jingzhe*) and close before the Beginning of Winter (*Lidong*)—yin and yang mutually encroach upon one another.
Thus, *Qian* is fully used, *Kun* is fully unused, and *Kan* and *Li* are half-used.
The two hexagrams *Kan* and *Li* are the intermingling of the middle lines of *Qian* and *Kun*.
In the precelestial arrangement, *Kan* and *Li* occupy *Mao* and *You* as the sun and moon.
In the postcelestial arrangement, *Kan* and *Li* occupy *Zi* and *Wu* as water and fire.
Only these four positions are most excellent: within yang there is yin, and within yin there is yang—such are the subtle intentions of Fu Xi and King Wen.

chunks.original_text: 其他卦不偏则杂矣。 朱子曰：五行相为阴阳，又各自为阴阳。 春为少阳，夏为老阳。 秋为少阴，冬为老阴。 此以流行於四时而言也。 自一岁言，六个月阳，六个月阴。 一日亦然，昼阳夜阴，午前阳，午后阴。 一月言，望前阳，望后阴。 六甲言，甲子阳，乙丑阴。 分言之，则甲阳子阴。 从古至今，只怠裒去，屈伸往来，循环不已。 孰使然哉？ 天地是一个大阴阳，一年一月一日一时，皆自其中流出。 又春为阳始，夏为阳极。 秋为阴始，冬为阴极。 阳始则温，阳极则热。 阴始则凉，阴极则寒。 温则生物，热则长物。 凉则收物，寒则杀物。 是一气之变为之也。 阳生自下而上，则进而生物。 阴生自上而下，则退而成物。 阳居束南，主春夏以生。 阴居西北，主秋冬以杀。 此其大略也。 邵子曰：太阳为日，太阴为月。 少阳为星，少阴为辰。 其变则为暑寒昼夜、雨风露雷。 或问：雷霆风雨，雪霜云露。 张子对曰：阴气凝聚，阳在内不得出，则奋击而为雷霆。 阳在外者不得入，则周旋不舍而为风。 其聚有远近虚实，故风雷有大小暴。 缓和而散为雪霜雨露，不和而散为戾气阴霾。 阴常散受交於阳，则风雨调寒暑正。 又曰：阳为阴累，则相持为雨。 而降阴为阳，得则飘扬为云而升。 故云物班布太虚者，阴为风驱敛聚而未散者也。 又有问雨风云雷於邵子者。 答曰：阳得阴为雨，阴得阳为风。 刚得柔为云，柔得刚为雷。 无阴不能为雨，无阳不能为雷。 雨柔属阴，待阳而后兴。 雷刚属阳#6，待阴#7而后发。 张氏释之曰：阳倡阴从流为雨，阴格阳薄散为风。 刚倡柔从蒸成云，柔蓄刚动激成雷。 客主后先，阴阳逆顺，不同也。 风雨自天降，故言阴阳。 云雷自地升，故言柔刚。 天阳无阴，不能为雨。 地阴无阳，不能成雷。 雨阴形柔，本乎天气之阳。 雷阳声刚，出乎地体之阴。 阴阳互相用也。 又有以八卦爻象问於蔡节斋者。 答曰：坎阴为阳所得，则升为云，阳浅则为雾。 坎阳为阴所累，则条为雨，阴浅则为露。 阴在外，阳不得出则为雷。 阴固则为地动，震也。 阴在内，阳不得入则为风。 阴固则为大风，巽也。 阳包阴则离为霰，阳和阴则为雪，离交坎也。 阴包阳则坎为雷，阴入阳则为霜，坎交离也。 阴阳之精，互藏其宅，则离为日，坎为月。 阴阳相戛则为电，阴阳失位则为霓。 又曰：气自子至午为升，自午至子为降。 子至寅地中升于地上，卯至巳地中升于天中。 午至申天中降于地上，酉至亥地上降于地中。 愚按：子午各六，有地以限之。 阳生於子至寅，则十一月至正月，阳气升于地上。 少阳数七，阴中阳也。 卯至巳，二月至四月，地中升于天中。 老阳数九，阳中阳也。 ＇又自一阴生午以至于申，五月至七月，阴气自天中降于地上。 少阴八，阳中阴也。 酉至亥，八月至十月，地上降于地中。 老阴数六，阴中阴也。 一日一月亦然。 大抵寅申巳亥当乾坤泰否之交，三阳三阴，皆为天之用。 震为少，至乾则老。 巽为少，至坤则老。 坎离又以四阴四阳，生物于中。 三阴三阳，泰与否对。 六阴六阳，乾与坤对。 如水数六，雪片也。 六不是人做将出来，物物造化皆是如此。 可以见阴阳之妙处。 又曰：太柔为水，太刚为火。 少柔为土，少刚为石。
chunks.translated_text:
The other hexagrams, if not biased, become mixed. Master Zhu said: The Five Phases mutually serve as yin and yang, and each also has its own yin and yang. Spring is *lesser yang*, summer is *greater yang*. Autumn is *lesser yin*, winter is *greater yin*. This is spoken in terms of their flow through the four seasons. From the perspective of a year, six months are yang and six months are yin. A day is likewise: daytime is yang, night is yin; before noon is yang, after noon is yin. In a month, the period before the full moon is yang, and after the full moon is yin. In the *six jia* cycles, *jiazi* is yang, *yichou* is yin. Speaking in divisions, *jia* is yang and *zi* is yin. From ancient times to the present, there has only been ceaseless gathering and dispersing, bending and extending, cycling without end. What causes this? Heaven and Earth are one great yin and yang, and a year, a month, a day, an hour—all flow forth from within them.

Moreover, spring is the beginning of yang, summer is the extreme of yang. Autumn is the beginning of yin, winter is the extreme of yin. When yang begins, there is warmth; when yang reaches its extreme, there is heat. When yin begins, there is coolness; when yin reaches its extreme, there is cold. Warmth gives rise to things, heat makes things grow. Coolness gathers things, cold destroys things. These are the transformations of the single *qi*.

Yang arises from below and ascends, thus advancing to generate things. Yin arises from above and descends, thus retreating to complete things. Yang resides in the southeast, governing spring and summer to give life. Yin resides in the northwest, governing autumn and winter to destroy. This is the general outline.

Master Shao said: *Greater yang* becomes the sun, *greater yin* becomes the moon. *Lesser yang* becomes the stars, *lesser yin* becomes the celestial bodies. Their transformations give rise to heat and cold, day and night, rain and wind, dew and thunder.

Someone asked about thunder, wind, rain, snow, frost, clouds, and dew. Master Zhang replied: When yin *qi* congeals and yang is trapped within unable to emerge, it struggles and strikes to become thunder. When yang is outside and unable to enter, it revolves ceaselessly to become wind. Their gatherings vary in distance and fullness, thus wind and thunder differ in magnitude and intensity. When dispersed gently and harmoniously, they become snow, frost, rain, and dew; when dispersed disharmoniously, they become perverse *qi* and yin haze. Yin constantly disperses and receives exchange from yang, thus wind and rain are regulated and cold and heat are balanced.

He also said: When yang is burdened by yin, they contend to form rain. When yin descends and yang obtains it, it scatters and rises as clouds. Thus, the patterned distribution of cloud things across the great void is yin driven by wind, gathered but not yet dispersed.

Someone asked Master Shao about rain, wind, clouds, and thunder. He answered: Yang obtaining yin becomes rain; yin obtaining yang becomes wind. Hard obtaining soft becomes clouds; soft obtaining hard becomes thunder. Without yin, there can be no rain; without yang, there can be no thunder. Rain, being soft, belongs to yin and awaits yang before arising. Thunder, being hard, belongs to yang and awaits yin before erupting.

Master Zhang explained: When yang leads and yin follows, flowing together, it becomes rain. When yin obstructs and yang presses, scattering, it becomes wind. When hard leads and soft follows, steaming, it forms clouds. When soft stores and hard moves, striking, it forms thunder. Whether as guest or host, preceding or following, yin and yang act in opposition or accord—these differ.

Wind and rain descend from heaven, thus they are spoken of in terms of yin and yang. Clouds and thunder rise from earth, thus they are spoken of in terms of soft and hard. Heaven’s yang, without yin, cannot form rain. Earth’s yin, without yang, cannot produce thunder. Rain, being yin in form and soft, originates from heaven’s yang *qi*. Thunder, being yang in sound and hard, emerges from earth’s yin body. Yin and yang mutually employ one another.

Someone asked Master Cai Jieqai about the line images of the eight hexagrams. He answered: When *Kan* yin is obtained by yang, it ascends as clouds; if yang is shallow, it becomes mist. When *Kan* yang is burdened by yin, it streams as rain; if yin is shallow, it becomes dew. When yin is outside and yang cannot emerge, it becomes thunder. If yin is solid, it becomes an earthquake—this is *Zhen*. When yin is inside and yang cannot enter, it becomes wind. If yin is solid, it becomes a great wind—this is *Xun*. When yang envelops yin, *Li* becomes sleet; when yang harmonizes with yin, it becomes snow—this is *Li* intersecting *Kan*. When yin envelops yang, *Kan* becomes thunder; when yin enters yang, it becomes frost—this is *Kan* intersecting *Li*. When the essence of yin and yang mutually reside in each other’s abodes, *Li* becomes the sun and *Kan* becomes the moon. When yin and yang clash, it becomes lightning; when yin and yang are out of place, it becomes a rainbow.

He also said: *Qi* ascends from *zi* to *wu* and descends from *wu* to *zi*. From *zi* to *yin*, it rises from within the earth to above the earth; from *mao* to *si*, it rises from within the earth to the midst of heaven. From *wu* to *shen*, it descends from the midst of heaven to above the earth; from *you* to *hai*, it descends from above the earth to within the earth.

In my humble observation: *Zi* and *wu* each have six, bounded by the earth. Yang arises from *zi* to *yin*, thus from the eleventh month to the first month, yang *qi* ascends above the earth. *Lesser yang* is seven, yang within yin. From *mao* to *si*, the second to the fourth month, it rises from within the earth to the midst of heaven. *Greater yang* is nine, yang within yang. Then, from the moment one yin arises at *wu* to *shen*, the fifth to the seventh month, yin *qi* descends from the midst of heaven to above the earth. *Lesser yin* is eight, yin within yang. From *you* to *hai*, the eighth to the tenth month, it descends from above the earth to within the earth. *Greater yin* is six, yin within yin. A day and a month are likewise.

Generally, *yin*, *shen*, *si*, and *hai* correspond to the transitions of *Qian*, *Kun*, *Tai*, and *Pi*. The three yangs and three yins are all employed by heaven. *Zhen* is lesser, reaching *Qian* it becomes greater. *Xun* is lesser, reaching *Kun* it becomes greater. *Kan* and *Li*, with their four yins and four yangs, generate things in their midst. The three yins and three yangs oppose *Tai* and *Pi*. The six yins and six yangs oppose *Qian* and *Kun*. Like the number of water being six, as in snowflakes—six is not fabricated by humans; all things in creation are thus. From this, the marvel of yin and yang can be seen.

He also said: *Greater softness* becomes water, *greater hardness* becomes fire. *Lesser softness* becomes earth, *lesser hardness* becomes stone.

chunks.original_text: 其化则为走飞草木色声气味。 阳生动物，阴生植物。 朱子曰：本是一理，而消息盈虚，便生阴阳。 虽至微至细，草木乌兽皆然。 如鲤鱼上有三十六鳞，阴数。 龙背上有八十一鳞，阳数。 龟背中问五段，五行也。 两边各四段，八卦也。 周围二十四段，二十四气也。 至於草木、雌雄、银杏、桐楮、牝牡、麻竹皆然。 张子曰：糟粕煨烬，无非教也。 愚尝以《皇极经世书》推之，谓有飞飞之物，飞木、飞草、飞走之物，又有走飞、走木、走草、走走之物，又有木飞、木走、木草、木木之物，又以。 草飞、草走、草木、草草之物。 又有阴阳推之，飞阳走阴，动阳植阴，马阳牛阴，角阳尾阴，皆不逃乎阴阳之数。 大抵色声气味，目耳鼻口，物各有之。 但或偏而不全，全而不能，如人之灵耳。 程子曰：近取诸身，百理皆具屈伸之气，只鼻息问见之。 鼻□窍为天门，气由以出入也。 朱子曰：以气言之，呼为阳便是发达底，吸为阴便是收敛底。 如鼻息，无时不吸，无时不嘘。 嘘尽生吸，吸尽生嘘。 胡文定公曰：人一昼一夜，有一万三千五百六十息。 横渠张氏曰：魂交成梦，百感纷纭。 对寤而言，一身之昼夜也。 气按为春，万物错揉。 对秋而言，天地之昼夜也。 朱子谓：太极是性，动静阴阳是心。 金木水火土，是仁义礼智信。 躯体血肉，便是五行。 所以开眼不是阴，便是阳，不是仁便是义。 进便是阳，退便是阴。 处己一爻是阴#9，应事接物是阳。 爻#10又曰：事之未定者属阳，已定者属阴。 邵子曰：天有四时，地有四方，人有四肢#11。 指节可以观天，掌文可以察地，天地之理具于掌矣。 释者曰：手仰本乎天，亲上。 足方俯乎地，亲下。 手可翻覆，足不可者。 阳能兼阴，阴不可兼阳也。 掌后高前下，束南多水，西北多山。 聚为川泽，掌中之文，如川象手。 自掌腕肘至肩足，自趾至经，股胯各三节，应十二次。 四肢应天#12四时，应地四方。 四指各三节，应十二辰。 合之应二十四气。 拇指三节，二为阴阳。 隐者为太极，掌大物也。 合之而三十二，应天卦。 并手足六十四，兼地卦。 地体极于十六一，一手有十六数，而显者十五。 一者太极，隐于大物之问也。 人之四肢各一脉，应四时也。 一脉三部，应一时三月。 一部三候，应一月三旬。 乾策也。 《素问》言十二节气，皆通天气。 十二节气应人之十二经脉，谓手足各三阴三阳三候，谓沈浮中阴阳，有太过不及也。 又曰：天地一气而已。 分阴分阳，便是两物。 故阳为仁，而阴为义。 然阴阳又各分为二。 故阳之初，为木为春为仁。 阳之盛，为火为夏为礼。 阴之初，为金为秋为义。 阴之极，为水为冬为智。 兼三材而两之也。 阴阳作一气看，亦得作二气看，亦得随时分出看，亦得大处有大阖辟大消息，小处有小阖辟小消息。 大而十二万九千六百年，小而一年一月一日一时皆然。 於其中虽有万变不同，而其理则一定不易也。 故曰：一阴一阳之谓道。 继之者善，成之者性也。 学得其究心焉。 天原发微卷之四竟 #1此句原作『其实一物无阴阳者』，据《四库全书》本改。 #2『若』，《四库全书》本作『方』。 #3此句《四库全书》本作『若说流行处，却只是一气』。
chunks.translated_text:
Their transformations manifest as creatures that run and fly, grasses and trees, colors and sounds, *qi* and flavors. The yang gives rise to mobile beings; the yin gives rise to rooted plants.

Master Zhu said: "It is fundamentally one principle, yet through waxing and waning, expansion and contraction, yin and yang arise. Even in the most minute and subtle things—grasses, trees, birds, and beasts—this holds true. For example, the carp bears thirty-six scales, a yin number. The dragon’s back bears eighty-one scales, a yang number. The tortoise’s shell has five segments at its center, corresponding to the Five Phases. On either side are four segments each, corresponding to the Eight Trigrams. Around the perimeter are twenty-four segments, corresponding to the twenty-four solar terms. As for grasses and trees—whether male and female, ginkgo and paulownia, hemp and bamboo—all follow this pattern."

Master Zhang said: "Even dregs and ashes are nothing but teachings." I once applied the principles of the *Huangji Jingshi Shu* to deduce that there are creatures of flight—flying trees, flying grasses, flying creatures that run—and creatures of running—running fliers, running trees, running grasses, running runners. There are also tree-fliers, tree-runners, tree-grasses, tree-trees, as well as grass-fliers, grass-runners, grass-trees, and grass-grasses. Further, when divided by yin and yang, fliers belong to yang and runners to yin; mobile beings to yang and rooted plants to yin; horses to yang and oxen to yin; horns to yang and tails to yin. None escape the reckoning of yin and yang.

Generally, colors, sounds, *qi*, and flavors—each corresponds to the eyes, ears, nose, and mouth, and every thing possesses them. Yet some are partial and incomplete, while others are complete but ineffectual, as in the case of human intelligence.

Master Cheng said: "Look near at the body, and the hundred principles are all present in the *qi* of contraction and extension—this can be seen in the breath between the nostrils. The nostrils are the Gate of Heaven, through which *qi* enters and exits."

Master Zhu said: "In terms of *qi*, exhalation is yang and pertains to expansion, while inhalation is yin and pertains to contraction. As with the breath through the nose, there is no moment without inhalation, no moment without exhalation. When exhalation is exhausted, inhalation arises; when inhalation is exhausted, exhalation arises."

Minister Hu Wending said: "In one day and night, a person takes 13,560 breaths."

Master Zhang of Hengqu said: "The mingling of the *hun* gives rise to dreams, a tumult of a hundred sensations. Relative to waking, this is the day and night of the body. When *qi* presses forth, it is spring, and the myriad things intermingle. Relative to autumn, this is the day and night of heaven and earth."

Master Zhu said: "The Supreme Ultimate is nature; movement and stillness, yin and yang, are the heart-mind. Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth are benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust. The body and its blood and flesh are the Five Phases. Thus, when the eyes open, it is either yin or yang, either benevolence or righteousness. Advancing is yang; retreating is yin. In self-cultivation, one line is yin; in responding to affairs and engaging with things, it is yang. Another line states: that which is not yet settled belongs to yang; that which is settled belongs to yin."

Master Shao said: "Heaven has the four seasons; earth has the four directions; humans have the four limbs. The joints of the fingers can reveal heaven; the lines of the palm can discern earth. The principles of heaven and earth are fully present in the palm."

The exegete said: "The hands face upward, aligned with heaven; the feet are square and face downward, aligned with earth. The hands can turn and flip, but the feet cannot—yang can encompass yin, but yin cannot encompass yang. The back of the palm is high, the front is low; the southeast has much water, the northwest has many mountains. Where they gather are rivers and marshes, and the lines in the palm resemble rivers and the shape of the hand. From the wrist to the elbow to the shoulder, and from the toes to the knee to the thigh and hip, there are three joints each, corresponding to the twelve stations. The four limbs correspond to heaven’s four seasons and earth’s four directions. The four fingers each have three joints, corresponding to the twelve earthly branches. Together, they correspond to the twenty-four solar terms. The thumb has three joints, two of which are yin and yang; the hidden one is the Supreme Ultimate, the great thing. Combined, they number thirty-two, corresponding to the heavenly hexagrams. Together with the hands and feet, they number sixty-four, encompassing the earthly hexagrams. The earth’s body culminates in sixteen; one hand has sixteen numbers, of which fifteen are manifest. The one is the Supreme Ultimate, hidden between the great things.

Each of the four limbs has one vessel, corresponding to the four seasons. Each vessel has three sections, corresponding to the three months of a season. Each section has three periods, corresponding to the three ten-day weeks of a month. This is the *Qian* strategy.

The *Suwen* speaks of the twelve seasonal nodes, all of which communicate with heavenly *qi*. The twelve seasonal nodes correspond to the twelve meridians of the human body—referring to the three yins and three yangs of the hands and feet—and the three periods refer to the deep, floating, and middle yin and yang, which may be excessive or deficient.

It also states: "Heaven and earth are but one *qi*. When divided into yin and yang, they become two things. Thus, yang is benevolence, and yin is righteousness. Yet yin and yang each further divide into two. Thus, the inception of yang is Wood, spring, and benevolence; the fullness of yang is Fire, summer, and propriety. The inception of yin is Metal, autumn, and righteousness; the extreme of yin is Water, winter, and wisdom. This encompasses the Three Powers and doubles them.

When viewed as one *qi*, yin and yang may also be seen as two *qi*. They may be observed as they change with the seasons, or in the great openings and closings, the great waxings and wanings of the cosmos, as well as in the small openings and closings, the small waxings and wanings of the minute. Whether in the vast span of 129,600 years or in a year, a month, a day, or an hour, it is all thus. Though there may be ten thousand changes within, their principle remains constant and unchanging. Thus it is said: 'One yin, one yang—this is the Dao.' That which continues it is goodness; that which completes it is nature."

Having thoroughly studied this, one may fathom its depths.

*Tian Yuan Fa Wei*, Scroll Four, concludes.

chunks.original_text: 衍五 郑氏引《白虎通》云：行者为天行气。 水训准，水在黄泉，养物平均有准。 火，化也。 阳气用事，万物变化。 金，禁也。 秋时万物，阴气禁止。 木，触也。 阳气动跃，触地而出。 土，吐也。 土居中央，总吐万物。 生物者，木火七八之数。 成物者，金水九六之数。 《易》精气为物。 注云七八。 游魂为变。 注云九六。 朱子曰：太极列五者於阴阳之下。 五常是理，阴阳是气。 有理无气，则理无所立，故五行次阴阳。 又曰：义智属阴，仁礼属阳。 阴阳是气，五行是质。 有这质，又有五行之气，所以做得物事出来。 愚曰：五行后天也。 若问先天一事，无一者，太极也。 自一分二，则有阴阳。 阴阳者，五行之气。 五行者，阴阳之体质。 一三五七九，为天之五行。 二四六八十，为地之五行。 二五一十，阴阳合而为一，则能生成万物。 故上．日一，五行而已。 一中有二。 甲阳乙阴为木，丙阳丁阴为火，戊阳己阴为土，庚阳辛阴为金，壬阳癸阴为水，天也。 亥阴子阳，北寅阳卯阴，束巳阳午阴，南申阳酉阴，西辰戌阳丑未阴。 位中央，地也。 木神主仁，金神主义，火神主礼，水神主智，土神主信，人也。 贯三才而一之，气行理亦行。 周子曰：阳变阴合，而生水火木金土。 朱子曰：五行质具於地，而气行於天。 以质而语其生之序，则水火木金土。 而水木阳也，火金阴也。 以气而语其行之序，则木火土金水。 而木火阳也，金水阴也。 盖其变，至於不可穷，无适而非阴阳之道。 又曰：水阴根阳，火阳根阴，错综而生。 到运行处，便水生木，木生火，火生土，土生金，金生水，水生木，循环旺相。 又如甲乙丙丁戊己庚辛壬癸，都是这个物事。 黄勉斋曰：《图说》云：水阴盛，火阳盛，乃行之序，非生之序。 如作建子时看，则水木是阳，火金是阴，此生之序。 又曰：《太极图》有一处可疑。 图以水阴盛居右，火阳盛居左。 金阴秆，故次水。 木阳秆，故次火。 此是说生之序。 下文却说，水木阳也，火金阴也，却以水为阳火为阴。 论来物之初生，自是幼嫩，如阳始生为水尚柔弱，到生木已强盛。 阴始生为火尚微，到生金已成质。 如此则水为阳秆，木为阳盛，火为阴秆，而金为阴盛也。 又曰：五行之生，各一其性。 就气质言之，水性玲，火性热，木性温，金性冻，土性中和。 人之生也，亦各随其气质所禀，有智愚强弱之不同。 然自本求之，则各一其性。 所谓浑然太极之．全，无不各具於一物之中。 此人也，所以独得五行之秀，而其心为最灵。 程子曰：坎，水也。 一始於中，有生之最先者也。 天一生水，故水居五行之先。 物之初生，其形皆水。 水者，万物之一源，皆根於天一之造化也。 如金石之产，其初亦乳。 一阳之气，一日之时，一年十一月，冬至皆肇於子。 子者，水位也。 夫水生於阳，而成於阴。 气始动而阳生，气聚而静则成水观，呵气可见。 盖生水之初属一，故微至。 成水时，则六矣。 或问曰：天一生水，亦有物可证乎？ 曰：人之一身可证矣。 食心动则津生，哀心动则泪生，愧心动则汗生，欲心动则精生，方人心寂然不动之时，则太极也。 此心之动，则太极动而生阳也。 所以心一动而水生，即可以为天一生水之证。
chunks.translated_text:
**Expounding the Five [Phases]**

Master Zheng cites the *Baihutong*: "Movement is the qi of Heaven’s activity." Water serves as the standard, for water lies in the Yellow Springs, nurturing all things with impartial constancy. Fire is transformation. When yang qi prevails, the myriad things undergo change. Metal is restraint. In autumn, the myriad things are constrained by yin qi. Wood is arousal. Yang qi stirs and leaps, bursting forth from the earth. Earth is spouting. Earth, dwelling at the center, universally brings forth the myriad things.

That which engenders things follows the numbers seven and eight of wood and fire. That which completes things follows the numbers nine and six of metal and water. The *Book of Changes* states: "The essence of qi becomes things"—the commentary notes seven and eight. "The wandering soul undergoes change"—the commentary notes nine and six.

Master Zhu [Xi] says: The Supreme Polarity arrays the Five [Phases] beneath yin and yang. The Five Constants are principle, while yin and yang are qi. Without qi, principle would have no place to stand; thus the Five Phases follow yin and yang. He further states: Righteousness and wisdom pertain to yin; benevolence and ritual pertain to yang. Yin and yang are qi, while the Five Phases are substance. With this substance, and with the qi of the Five Phases, things are thus produced.

This fool says: The Five Phases belong to the postnatal. If one inquires into the prenatal, the One is the Supreme Polarity. From the One dividing into two, there arises yin and yang. Yin and yang are the qi of the Five Phases; the Five Phases are the substantial forms of yin and yang. One, three, five, seven, and nine are the Five Phases of Heaven. Two, four, six, eight, and ten are the Five Phases of Earth. Two and five make ten; when yin and yang unite as one, they can engender and complete the myriad things. Thus above, the *Daybook* says: "One is the Five Phases alone." Within the One there are two.

Jia (yang) and Yi (yin) form Wood; Bing (yang) and Ding (yin) form Fire; Wu (yang) and Ji (yin) form Earth; Geng (yang) and Xin (yin) form Metal; Ren (yang) and Gui (yin) form Water—these are of Heaven. Hai (yin) and Zi (yang), the north; Yin (yang) and Mao (yin), the east; Si (yang) and Wu (yin), the south; Shen (yang) and You (yin), the west; Chen (yang) and Xu (yang), Chou (yin) and Wei (yin)—these occupy the center and are of Earth. The spirit of Wood governs benevolence; the spirit of Metal governs righteousness; the spirit of Fire governs ritual; the spirit of Water governs wisdom; the spirit of Earth governs trust—these are of Man. Uniting the Three Powers as one, qi flows and principle likewise flows.

Master Zhou [Dunyi] says: Yang transforms and yin unites, giving rise to Water, Fire, Wood, Metal, and Earth. Master Zhu says: The Five Phases’ substance resides in Earth, while their qi flows in Heaven. Speaking of their generative sequence in terms of substance, it is Water, Fire, Wood, Metal, Earth—here, Water and Wood are yang, while Fire and Metal are yin. Speaking of their operational sequence in terms of qi, it is Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, Water—here, Wood and Fire are yang, while Metal and Water are yin. For their transformations are boundless, and nowhere do they not follow the Dao of yin and yang.

He further states: Water’s yin is rooted in yang; Fire’s yang is rooted in yin. Interwoven, they give rise to life. In their cyclical movement, Water engenders Wood, Wood engenders Fire, Fire engenders Earth, Earth engenders Metal, Metal engenders Water, Water engenders Wood—thus they circulate in mutual flourishing. Again, Jia, Yi, Bing, Ding, Wu, Ji, Geng, Xin, Ren, and Gui are all of this same thing.

Huang Mianzhai says: The *Diagram Explanation* states that Water’s yin is abundant and Fire’s yang is abundant—this is their operational sequence, not their generative sequence. Viewed from the establishment of the *zi* [midnight] hour, Water and Wood are yang, while Fire and Metal are yin—this is their generative sequence. He further says: There is one point of doubt in the *Diagram of the Supreme Polarity*. The diagram places Water, with its abundant yin, on the right, and Fire, with its abundant yang, on the left. Metal, being yin, follows Water; Wood, being yang, follows Fire—this explains their generative sequence. Yet the text below states that Water and Wood are yang, while Fire and Metal are yin, thus making Water yang and Fire yin. In considering the initial arising of things, they are naturally tender and immature. When yang first arises, as Water, it is still soft and weak; by the time Wood is engendered, it has grown strong. When yin first arises, as Fire, it is still faint; by the time Metal is engendered, it has taken form. Thus Water is yang in its inception, Wood is yang in its fullness, Fire is yin in its inception, and Metal is yin in its fullness.

He further states: The generation of the Five Phases, each with its own nature. In terms of qi and substance, Water’s nature is cold, Fire’s is hot, Wood’s is warm, Metal’s is frozen, and Earth’s is harmonious. When humans are born, they likewise differ in intelligence, foolishness, strength, and weakness according to the qi and substance they receive. Yet when each returns to its root, it possesses its own nature. This is what is meant by the Supreme Polarity’s wholeness being fully present within each thing. Thus humans, alone among beings, receive the finest essence of the Five Phases, and their minds are most numinous.

Master Cheng says: Kan is Water. The One begins at the center, being the first of the engendered. Heaven engenders Water with the One, so Water stands first among the Five Phases. When things first arise, their forms are all water. Water is one source of the myriad things, all rooted in the creative transformation of Heaven’s One. Even the production of metal and stone begins as a fluid. The qi of the first yang, the first hour of the day, the eleventh month of the year, and the Winter Solstice all commence at *zi*. *Zi* is the position of Water. Now, Water is engendered by yang yet completed by yin. When qi first stirs, yang arises; when qi gathers and stills, it becomes water—observe the breath, and it is visible. The inception of Water belongs to the One, hence it is subtle. When Water is formed, it becomes six.

Someone asked: Is there evidence for Heaven engendering Water with the One? The answer: The human body provides evidence. When the heart of hunger stirs, saliva is produced; when the heart of sorrow stirs, tears are produced; when the heart of shame stirs, sweat is produced; when the heart of desire stirs, essence is produced. When the human heart is quiescent and unmoving, it is the Supreme Polarity. When this heart stirs, the Supreme Polarity moves and yang arises. Thus when the heart stirs and Water is engendered, this can serve as evidence for Heaven engendering Water with the One.

chunks.original_text: 神为气主，神动则气随。 气为水母，气聚则水生。 朱子曰：五行之序，木为之始，水为之终，而土为之中。 以《图》、《书》之数言之，则水一木三土五，皆阳之生数而不可易。 故得以更迭为主，而为五行之纲。 五行：春始於束方之木，冬终於北方之水，中主於中央之土，是始中终三者，行之序也。 而其生之序，则皆始於天。 水能利泽万物，天一打初便生水。 水有贞静之性，刚而有力，包藏於冬。 木能温燠万物，天三便生木。 木有发生之性，充吧莫御，条达於春。 土能持载万物，至天五生土。 土为包育之母，直方以大居中，而旺四方。 三者既生，生生不已，各居其方，而不可易。 於以见上天好生之心，源头既正，骨子又好，皆是天生。 火之与金，乃是五行中相资以变化，不可一日无者，却是地生。 火生於地二，其性炎上，或自有而无，或自无而有，位可以居南，亦可以居西。 金生於地四，其性从革，或方可为圆，圆可为方，位可以居西，亦可以居南。 故《图》与《书》有更置之说，不似水木土，皆天所生而有定序。 然而，於定＇序之中，五行生生，相为融贯，则序虽定而气未尝不相通也。 故朱子曰：得以更迭为主，．而为五行之纲。 又曰：木之包五行也，以其流通贯彻，而无不在也。 饶双峰曰：气运於天，以生为主。 故朱子以春为四时之首，而贯乎夏秋冬。 其在人，则恻隐为四端之首，而贯乎羞恶辞逊是非。 以春能生万物，而恻隐能兼众善故也。 安氏曰：一在木下为本，是归根复命而合於五也。 一在本上为末，是分枝布叶而散於万也。 以一知万。 天一生水而为木，共此一尔。 又曰：水之包五行也，以其归根反命而藏於此也。 木无水则枯，火无水则燥，金无水则宿。 以水包之，则流通四时，活动万物。 功成则退藏二阴之中，伏於黄泉之底，所以能归根复命於此。 及其出也，则又元而亨，雷域中雨天下也。 其在人，则肾精所藏，百体皆润。 又曰：土则水火之所寄，金木之所资，居中而应四方，一体而载万类也。 双峰饶氏曰：质具於地，以养为主。 故土居五行之中，而统乎水火木金。 其在人，则脾居五脏之中，而统乎心肝肺肾。 以土能养万物，脾能养众形。 夏季未月，土为最王，故能生秋金。 又寄王四季，每季皆十八日，共计七十二日。 其他四行分四时，亦各得七十二日，共成三百六十日。 翁氏谓：五行离土，则不能各成一器。 一得五，便成水。 二得五，便成火。 三得五，便成木。 四得五，便成金。 五得五，便成土。 五者，土居中央。 一二三四五，才得五，便成水火木金土，谓之六七八九十也。 又曰：天地者，阴阳对待之定体。 一二三四五六七八九十者，阴阳流行之次序。 对待非流行，不能变化。 流行非对待，不能自行。 此五行，所以流行於天地中以为用。 变化者，一变六，化而成水。 二变七，化而成火。 三变八，化而成木。 四变九，化而成金。 五变十，化而成．土。 天地其对待之大者。 其次五行，亦各自为对。 是为交易之《易》，火与水对，金与木对。 对待则二，是有定体。 行者，流通，流通则一。 是为变易之《易》也。 五行相生，为水木火土金，金复生水。 对峙者，各半体。
chunks.translated_text:
The spirit governs qi, and when the spirit moves, qi follows. Qi is the mother of Water, and when qi gathers, Water is born.

Master Zhu said: In the sequence of the Five Phases, Wood is the beginning, Water is the end, and Earth is the center. According to the numbers in the *Diagram* and the *Book*, Water is one, Wood is three, and Earth is five—all odd numbers of yang’s generative sequence and unalterable. Thus they take turns as the principal, forming the warp of the Five Phases.

The Five Phases: Spring begins with Wood in the East, Winter ends with Water in the North, and Earth presides in the center—this is the sequence of beginning, middle, and end. Yet the sequence of their generation all begins with Heaven.

Water can moisten and nourish the myriad things; Heaven’s One first engenders Water. Water has the nature of steadfast stillness, firm and potent, concealed in Winter. Wood can warm and nurture the myriad things; Heaven’s Three engenders Wood. Wood has the nature of sprouting forth, inexhaustible and unrestrained, flourishing in Spring. Earth can bear and sustain the myriad things; Heaven’s Five engenders Earth. Earth is the mother of nurturance, upright and vast, dwelling in the center and flourishing in the four directions. Once these three are born, they ceaselessly generate, each occupying its own direction, immutable.

Thus we see Heaven’s heart of loving life: the source is upright, and the offspring are good—all are Heaven-born. Fire and Metal, however, are those within the Five Phases that rely on one another for transformation and cannot be absent for a single day, yet they are Earth-born.

Fire is born from Earth’s Two; its nature is to flame upward, sometimes existing from non-existence, sometimes non-existing from existence. Its position may be in the South or the West. Metal is born from Earth’s Four; its nature is to follow and reform, sometimes square made round, round made square. Its position may be in the West or the South. Thus the *Diagram* and the *Book* speak of rearrangement, unlike Water, Wood, and Earth, which are Heaven-born and have a fixed sequence.

Yet within this fixed sequence, the Five Phases ceaselessly generate, mutually permeating one another. Though the sequence is fixed, their qi is never unconnected. Thus Master Zhu said: They take turns as the principal, forming the warp of the Five Phases. He also said: Wood encompasses the Five Phases, for it flows through and penetrates all without exception.

Rao Shuangfeng said: Qi moves through Heaven with generation as its principal. Thus Master Zhu took Spring as the first of the four seasons, running through Summer, Autumn, and Winter. In humans, compassion is the first of the four beginnings, running through shame, deference, and right and wrong. For Spring can generate the myriad things, and compassion can embrace all virtues.

Master An said: When One is beneath Wood, it is the root—returning to the root and recovering the mandate, uniting with Five. When One is above Wood, it is the branch—sending forth limbs and leaves, scattering into the myriad. From One, know the myriad. Heaven’s One engenders Water and thus Wood—all share this One.

He also said: Water encompasses the Five Phases, for it returns to the root, restores the mandate, and conceals itself therein. Wood without Water withers, Fire without Water dries, Metal without Water stagnates. With Water to encompass them, they flow through the four seasons, animating the myriad things. When its work is done, it retreats and hides within the two yin, lying hidden at the Yellow Springs’ depths—thus it can return to the root and recover the mandate. When it emerges, it is once more primal and penetrating, like thunder shaking the earth and rain soaking the world.

In humans, it is the essence stored in the kidneys, moistening all the body. He also said: Earth is the lodging of Water and Fire, the resource of Metal and Wood, dwelling in the center and responding to the four directions—one body bearing the myriad kinds.

Rao Shuangfeng said: Substance resides in Earth, with nurturance as its principal. Thus Earth dwells at the center of the Five Phases, governing Water, Fire, Wood, and Metal. In humans, the spleen dwells at the center of the five viscera, governing the heart, liver, lungs, and kidneys. For Earth can nurture the myriad things, and the spleen can nurture all forms.

In the last month of Summer, Earth is most flourishing, thus it can engender Autumn’s Metal. It also flourishes in the four seasons, each season for eighteen days, totaling seventy-two days. The other four Phases divide the four seasons, each also receiving seventy-two days, together making three hundred and sixty days.

Master Weng said: The Five Phases, separated from Earth, cannot each become a vessel. One united with Five becomes Water. Two united with Five becomes Fire. Three united with Five becomes Wood. Four united with Five becomes Metal. Five united with Five becomes Earth. Five is Earth, dwelling in the center. One, two, three, four, five—once five is reached, Water, Fire, Wood, Metal, and Earth are formed, called six, seven, eight, nine, and ten.

He also said: Heaven and Earth are the fixed forms of yin and yang’s opposition. One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, and ten are the sequence of yin and yang’s flow. Without opposition, there can be no flow, and no transformation. Without flow, there can be no self-movement. Thus the Five Phases flow through Heaven and Earth to fulfill their function.

In transformation: One transforms into six, becoming Water. Two transforms into seven, becoming Fire. Three transforms into eight, becoming Wood. Four transforms into nine, becoming Metal. Five transforms into ten, becoming Earth.

Heaven and Earth are the greatest of oppositions. Next, the Five Phases each form their own oppositions. This is the *Yi* of exchange: Fire opposes Water, Metal opposes Wood. In opposition, there are two—this is the fixed form. In flow, there is circulation, and in circulation, there is one—this is the *Yi* of change.

The Five Phases generate one another: Water, Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, and Metal again generates Water. In their opposition, each is half a body.

chunks.original_text: 流通者，皆全体。 对待流行，各有次序。 以一气言，则息极而消，消极而息。 以二气言，则阳极生阴，阴极生阳。 以四时言，则所克者为夫妇，所生者为母子。 夫取妻，而夫之血气日以耗，故夏化为秋。 母生子，而子之血气日以充，故冬变为春。 以五行，戊己问乎十干，辰戌丑未问乎十二支，中央间乎四方，坤问乎离兑。 火生土，土生金也。 （程氏） 朱子曰：阳变阴合，初生水火。 水火，气也。 流动闪烁，其体尚虚。 其成形，犹未定。 次生金木，则确然有定形矣。 天地生物，先轻清，以及重浊。 水火二物，在五行最轻清，金木次之，土最重浊。 张子曰：水火，气也。 故炎上润下，与阴阳升降。 土不得而制焉。 木之为物，水清则生火，然而不离也。 朱子曰：《正蒙》只说金与木之体质属土，水与火却不属土。 问火附水而生，莫亦属土否#2？ 曰：火是个虚空中物。 问：只温与热．之气，便是火否？ 曰：然。 如火中虚暗，离中之阴也。 水中虚明，坎中之阳也。 火中有黑，阳中阴水。 外黑内明者，阴中之阳。 故水谓之阳，火谓之阴亦得。 张子又曰：阳陷於阴为水，附於阴为火。 木金者，土之华实也，其性有水火之杂。 故木水渍则生火，然而不离，益得土之浮华於水火之交也。 金得火之精於土之燥，得水之精於水之濡。 故水火相持而不害，烁之反流而不耗，益得土之精实於水火之际也。 勉斋黄氏曰：以人物之初生验之，天一生水，水便有形。 人生精血，奏合成体，亦若造化之有水也。 地二生火，火便有气。 人有此体，便能为声。 声者，气之所为，亦若造化之有火也。 水阴而火阳，貌亦属阴，而言亦属阳也。 水火虽有形质，然乃造化之初。 故水但能润火，但能炎其形质，终是轻清。 至若天三生木，地四生金，则形质已全具矣。 亦如人身耳目既具，则人之形成矣。 木阳金阴，亦犹视阳而听阴也。 造化之初，天一生水，而三生木，地二生火，而四生金。 天得一奇而生水，一之极为三，故三生木。 地得二偶而生火，二之极为四，故四生金。 六之成水犹坎，以一阳居中，天一生水也。 地六包於外，阳少阴多，而水始盛成。 七之成火犹离，以一阴居中，地二生火也。 天七包於外，阴少阳多而火始盛成。 岂曰：一生水而未成水，二生火而未成火，叉待五行俱足，方待六与七而成水火，如此则全不成造化矣。 益水火之气，一湿一燥。 水湿极而生木，火燥极而生金。 人物始生，亦精与气聚而为之耳。 精湿而气燥，精沉而气浮，故精为貌而气为言。 精之盛者，湿之极，故为目、为肝、为视。 气之盛者，燥之极，故为金、为肺、为听。 大抵貌与视属精，故精衰而目暗。 言与听属气，故气塞而耳聋。 此晓然易见也。 医家以耳属肾，以肺属金。 与此比配，各有不同。 云庄刘氏曰：阴阳互为其根。 水居子位，极阴之方，而阳已生於子。 火居午位，极阳之方，而阴已生於午。 若木生於天三专属阳，故其行於春亦属阳。 金生於地四专属阴，故其行於秋亦属阴。 不可以阴阳互言，盖水火未离乎气。 阴阳交合之初，其气自有互根之妙。 木则阳之发达，金则阴之收敛，而有定质矣。 此所以与水火不同也。 朱子曰：《乐》声是土金木水火，《洪范》是水火木金土。
chunks.translated_text:
In circulation, all are complete bodies. In opposition and flow, each has its own sequence.

Speaking of a single *qi*: when exhalation reaches its extreme, it turns to waning; when waning reaches its extreme, it turns to exhalation. Speaking of two *qi*: when yang reaches its extreme, yin arises; when yin reaches its extreme, yang arises.

Speaking of the four seasons: that which is overcome becomes husband and wife; that which is generated becomes mother and child. The husband takes a wife, and the husband’s blood and *qi* daily diminish—thus summer transforms into autumn. The mother bears a child, and the child’s blood and *qi* daily flourish—thus winter changes into spring.

Speaking of the Five Phases: *wu* and *ji* inquire among the ten Celestial Stems; *chen*, *xu*, *chou*, and *wei* inquire among the twelve Earthly Branches. The Center mediates between the four directions; *kun* inquires between *li* and *dui*. Fire generates Earth, and Earth generates Metal.

Master Cheng said: Yang transforms and yin unites, first giving rise to Water and Fire. Water and Fire are *qi*. Flowing and flickering, their forms remain insubstantial, their shapes not yet fixed. Next arise Metal and Wood, which are firmly established in fixed forms.

Heaven and Earth generate beings, first the light and pure, then the heavy and turbid. Among the Five Phases, Water and Fire are the lightest and purest; Metal and Wood follow, while Earth is the heaviest and most turbid.

Master Zhang said: Water and Fire are *qi*. Thus Fire flames upward and Water moistens downward, ascending and descending with yin and yang. Earth cannot restrain them. Wood as a thing: when Water is clear, Fire is born, yet they do not part.

Master Zhu said: *Zheng Meng* states only that the substantial forms of Metal and Wood belong to Earth, while Water and Fire do not belong to Earth. Someone asked: Since Fire arises attached to Water, does it not also belong to Earth? He replied: Fire is a thing of empty space. Asked: Is warmth and heat merely *qi* and thus Fire? He replied: Yes. The darkness within Fire is the yin within *li*. The clarity within Water is the yang within *kan*. Within Fire there is blackness—yin Water within yang. That which is black outside and bright inside is yang within yin. Thus Water may be called yang, and Fire may be called yin.

Master Zhang further said: When yang is submerged in yin, it becomes Water; when it clings to yin, it becomes Fire. Wood and Metal are the blossoms and fruits of Earth, their natures mingled with Water and Fire. Thus when Wood is steeped in Water, Fire is born, yet they do not part—further proof of Earth’s floating blossom at the intersection of Water and Fire. Metal obtains Fire’s essence from Earth’s dryness and Water’s essence from Water’s moisture. Thus Water and Fire sustain each other without harm; when smelted, they flow back without depletion—further proof of Earth’s essential solidity at the juncture of Water and Fire.

Huang of Mianzhai said: Examining the initial generation of humans and things, Heaven’s one generates Water, and Water at once takes form. When humans are born, essence and blood unite to form the body, just as in creation there is Water. Earth’s two generates Fire, and Fire at once has *qi*. When humans have this body, they can produce sound. Sound is the work of *qi*, just as in creation there is Fire. Water is yin and Fire is yang; appearance also belongs to yin, while speech also belongs to yang. Though Water and Fire have form and substance, they arise at creation’s beginning. Thus Water only moistens, and Fire only flames—yet their forms remain light and pure. When Heaven’s three generates Wood and Earth’s four generates Metal, their forms and substances are fully complete, just as when the human body’s ears and eyes are formed, the human shape is complete. Wood is yang and Metal is yin, just as seeing is yang and hearing is yin.

At creation’s beginning, Heaven’s one generates Water, and three generates Wood; Earth’s two generates Fire, and four generates Metal. Heaven obtains one odd number and generates Water; one’s extreme is three, thus three generates Wood. Earth obtains two even numbers and generates Fire; two’s extreme is four, thus four generates Metal. The completion of Water at six resembles *kan*, with one yang residing within—Heaven’s one generates Water. Earth’s six envelops externally, with yang scarce and yin abundant, and Water begins to flourish and form. The completion of Fire at seven resembles *li*, with one yin residing within—Earth’s two generates Fire. Heaven’s seven envelops externally, with yin scarce and yang abundant, and Fire begins to flourish and form.

Someone asked: If one generates Water but Water is not yet complete, and two generates Fire but Fire is not yet complete, must one wait until the Five Phases are all present before six and seven complete Water and Fire? If so, creation would never be whole. Rather, the *qi* of Water and Fire are one moist and one dry. When Water’s moisture reaches its extreme, Wood is born; when Fire’s dryness reaches its extreme, Metal is born. The beginning of humans and things is merely the gathering of essence and *qi*. Essence is moist and *qi* is dry; essence sinks while *qi* rises. Thus essence becomes appearance, and *qi* becomes speech. When essence flourishes, moisture reaches its extreme—thus it becomes the eyes, the liver, and sight. When *qi* flourishes, dryness reaches its extreme—thus it becomes Metal, the lungs, and hearing. Generally, appearance and sight belong to essence, so when essence wanes, the eyes dim. Speech and hearing belong to *qi*, so when *qi* is obstructed, the ears grow deaf. This is clearly evident.

Physicians assign the ears to the kidneys and the lungs to Metal. Compared with this arrangement, there are differences.

Liu of Yunzhuang said: Yin and yang are mutually rooted. Water resides in the *zi* position, the direction of extreme yin, yet yang is already born at *zi*. Fire resides in the *wu* position, the direction of extreme yang, yet yin is already born at *wu*. Wood, born from Heaven’s three, belongs entirely to yang, thus its movement in spring also belongs to yang. Metal, born from Earth’s four, belongs entirely to yin, thus its movement in autumn also belongs to yin. One cannot speak of them in terms of yin-yang mutuality, for Water and Fire have not yet parted from *qi*. At the beginning of yin-yang union, their *qi* naturally possesses the wonder of mutual rooting. Wood is yang’s expansion, and Metal is yin’s contraction—they have fixed substances. This is why they differ from Water and Fire.

Master Zhu said: The *Music* tones are Earth, Metal, Wood, Water, and Fire; the *Hong Fan* sequence is Water, Fire, Wood, Metal, and Earth.

Heaven and Earth are the greatest of oppositions. Next, the Five Phases each form their own oppositions. This is the *Yi* of exchange: Fire opposes Water, Metal opposes Wood. In opposition, there are two—this is the fixed form. In flow, there is circulation, and in circulation, there is one—this is the *Yi* of change.

chunks.original_text: 《乐》辨五声，十九八七六。 《范》分四方，一二三四五。 又曰：《范》言一二三四五，而不及六七八九十。 《月令》言八七五九六，而不及一二三四十。 《太玄》言三八四九二七一六五五，而不言十。 《范》以水火木金土为序，禹以水火金木土为序，刘向、班固以木火土金水为序，范晔以木金火土水为序。 又曰：五行质具於地，而气行於天者也。 蔡九峰曰：在天而流布四时日五行，在地为人所取用日五村。 唐孔氏曰：五行以微着为次。 水最微为兀火渐着为二，木形．实为三，金体固为四，土实大为五。 今以《洪范》推之。 蔡氏曰：润炎曲直，从革以性言，稼穑以德言。 水润而又下，火炎而又上，木曲而又直，金从而又革，土兼四方而具生之德。 故言其所重在稼穑，而民以食为天也。 冯氏曰：种曰稼苗也，获日穑穗也。 蔡传言稼而又穑者，言其生生不已也。 又曰：咸苦酸辛甘者，五行之味也。 五行有声色气味，而独言味者，以其切於民用也。 五味以五谷为主。 以《月令》推之，可见五壳之配五行者，麦为木，黍为火，稷为土麻为金，菽为水。 以五畜言，鹅为木，羊为火，牛为土，犬为金，豕为水。 以五果言，则栗水、李木、杏火、桃金、枣土。 是数者皆质具於地而切於民之生养，不可一日无也。 其运此气而在天则为五行，其凝此质而在地则为五材。 天有日，故地有火。 天有月，故地有水。 天有雨旸寒燠风，故地有水火木金土。 天而地，地而天，充塞宇宙，何莫非五行者。 况人禀五行之秀气以生，孰不资五行以为用。 邵子曰：火生於无，水生於有。 火内暗而外明，故离阳在外。 火之用，用外也。 水外暗而内明，故坎阳在内。 水之用，用内也。 火用外，目象水； 用内，耳象火。 内．为体，外为用。 水外为体，内为用。 阳者，用也。 朱子曰：阴以阳为质，阳以阴为质。 水内明而外暗，火内暗而外明。 阴阳之精，互藏其宅也。 西山真氏曰：日火外景，金水内景，本淮南子。 益清明者，内景金水也。 浊明者，外景日火也。 或曰：日火扬光於外，故日有蚀，火有灭。 金水潜光於内，故无穷。 以此收视反听，潜神不耀。 此理故妙，可以养生。 又於治道不相关，孰若吾儒，当明则为离晋，当晦则为明夷。 又曰：火、日外光，能直而施，所应无穷。 金水内光，能辟而受，随才各得神与形。 天与地之道欤？ 张氏曰：火托木而木生水，神乘气而生精。 先天以神生精，一生二。 后天以精集神，二生一。 愚尝推其说曰：水阴根阳，故为少阳，春至夏而老。 火阳根阴，故为少阴，秋至冬而老。 乾坤具坎离之体，乾以九二交坤成坎。 坎中一阳生子，是为真水，乃阴中之真阳也。 坤以六二交乾成离。 离中一阴生午，是为真火，乃阳中之真阴也。 二多一少，坎一离二。 少者为主，则多者为用。 少为主，故坎为冬。 所生之岁月日辰，自子至巳，六辰皆阳。 多者为用，故离为夏。 所生之岁月日辰，自午至亥，六辰皆阴。 天地之问，无往而非水火之用。 所以乾坤付正性於坎离，坎离为乾坤之用也。 又曰：云有水火土石之异，地类亦然。 张氏曰：水火土石地之体也，几物皆具地之体。 先生曰：水雨霖，火雨露，土雨蒙，石雨雹；

The *Music* distinguishes the five tones as nineteen, eighteen, seventeen, and sixteen. The *Hong Fan* divides the four directions as one, two, three, four, and five.

It is further said: The *Hong Fan* speaks of one, two, three, four, and five, but does not mention six, seven, eight, nine, or ten. The *Monthly Ordinances* speaks of eight, seven, five, nine, and six, but does not mention one, two, three, four, or ten. The *Great Mystery* speaks of three, eight, four, nine, two, seven, one, six, and five, but does not mention ten.

The *Hong Fan* orders them as Water, Fire, Wood, Metal, and Earth; Yu orders them as Water, Fire, Metal, Wood, and Earth; Liu Xiang and Ban Gu order them as Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water; Fan Ye orders them as Wood, Metal, Fire, Earth, and Water.

It is also said: The five phases possess substance in Earth, while their *qi* moves in Heaven. Cai Jiufeng said: Flowing through the four seasons in Heaven, they are called the five phases; on Earth, where humans draw upon them, they are called the five materials. Tang scholar Kong said: The five phases are ordered from the subtle to the manifest. Water is the most subtle, thus ranked one; Fire gradually manifests, thus ranked two; Wood takes form and substance, thus ranked three; Metal is solid and firm, thus ranked four; Earth is vast and substantial, thus ranked five. This is verified by the *Hong Fan*.

Cai said: Moistening, flaming, bending-straightening, transforming, and sowing-reaping—these describe their natures by function and their virtues by capacity. Water moistens and flows downward; Fire flames and rises upward; Wood bends and straightens; Metal obeys and transforms; Earth encompasses the four directions and possesses the virtue of generation. Thus, its emphasis lies in sowing and reaping, for the people regard food as heaven.

Feng said: Sowing is *jia* (planting), and reaping is *se* (harvesting). Cai’s commentary speaks of *jia* and *se* together to express their ceaseless generation.

It is further said: Salty, bitter, sour, pungent, and sweet—these are the flavors of the five phases. The five phases possess sound, color, *qi*, and flavor, but only flavor is mentioned here because it is most essential to human use. The five flavors are based on the five grains. According to the *Monthly Ordinances*, the correspondence of the five grains to the five phases is: wheat to Wood, millet to Fire, broomcorn millet to Earth, hemp to Metal, and beans to Water. In terms of the five livestock: goose to Wood, sheep to Fire, ox to Earth, dog to Metal, and pig to Water. In terms of the five fruits: chestnut to Water, plum to Wood, apricot to Fire, peach to Metal, and jujube to Earth. All these possess substance in Earth and are indispensable to human sustenance, not to be lacking even for a day. When this *qi* circulates in Heaven, it becomes the five phases; when this substance congeals on Earth, it becomes the five materials.

Heaven has the sun, thus Earth has Fire. Heaven has the moon, thus Earth has Water. Heaven has rain, sunshine, cold, warmth, and wind, thus Earth has Water, Fire, Wood, Metal, and Earth. From Heaven to Earth, and from Earth to Heaven, filling the cosmos—what is not of the five phases? Moreover, humans are born with the finest *qi* of the five phases; who does not rely on the five phases for use?

Shaozi said: Fire is born from non-being, Water from being. Fire is dark within and bright without, thus *li* (Fire) has yang on the outside. Fire’s function lies in its exterior. Water is dark without and bright within, thus *kan* (Water) has yang on the inside. Water’s function lies in its interior. Fire functions externally, symbolized by the eye; Water functions internally, symbolized by the ear. The interior is the body, the exterior is function. Water’s exterior is its body, its interior is function. Yang is function.

Master Zhu said: Yin takes yang as its substance, and yang takes yin as its substance. Water is bright within and dark without; Fire is dark within and bright without. The essence of yin and yang mutually abides in their dwellings.

Xishan’s Master Zhen said: The sun and Fire are the outer illumination; Metal and Water are the inner illumination—this originates from the *Huainanzi*. The clear and bright belong to the inner illumination of Metal and Water. The turbid and bright belong to the outer illumination of the sun and Fire. Some say: The sun and Fire radiate light externally, thus the sun may be eclipsed and Fire may be extinguished. Metal and Water conceal their light internally, thus they are inexhaustible. By this, one may withdraw the gaze and reverse the hearing, concealing the spirit without display. This principle is wondrous and may be used for nurturing life. Yet in matters of governance, it is irrelevant. How can it compare to we Confucians, who, when it is time to be bright, act as *li* (Fire), and when it is time to be obscure, act as *mingyi* (Darkening)?

It is further said: Fire and the sun emit light externally, able to extend and bestow without limit. Metal and Water emit light internally, able to receive and adapt, each according to its capacity, to spirit and form. Is this not the Dao of Heaven and Earth?

Master Zhang said: Fire relies on Wood, and Wood generates Water; spirit rides *qi* and generates essence. In the prior Heaven, spirit generates essence—one gives birth to two. In the posterior Heaven, essence gathers spirit—two gives birth to one.

I have pondered this and say: Water, rooted in yang within yin, is thus lesser yang, aging from spring to summer. Fire, rooted in yin within yang, is thus lesser yin, aging from autumn to winter. *Qian* and *Kun* possess the bodies of *kan* and *li*. *Qian*’s nine-two exchanges with *Kun* to form *kan*. Within *kan*, one yang is born at *zi*, becoming true Water—this is the true yang within yin. *Kun*’s six-two exchanges with *Qian* to form *li*. Within *li*, one yin is born at *wu*, becoming true Fire—this is the true yin within yang. Two are many, one is few—*kan* is one, *li* is two. The few govern, thus the many serve. The few govern, thus *kan* belongs to winter. The years, months, days, and hours it generates, from *zi* to *si*, are all yang. The many serve, thus *li* belongs to summer. The years, months, days, and hours it generates, from *wu* to *hai*, are all yin. Between Heaven and Earth, nowhere is not the function of Water and Fire. Thus, *Qian* and *Kun* entrust their true natures to *kan* and *li*, and *kan* and *li* serve *Qian* and *Kun*.

It is further said: Clouds differ as Water, Fire, Earth, and Stone, and the types of Earth are likewise varied.

Master Zhang said: Water, Fire, Earth, and Stone are the bodies of Earth; all things possess Earth’s body.

The Master said: Water rains as drizzle, Fire rains as dew, Earth rains as mist, and Stone rains as hail.

chunks.original_text: 水风凉，火风热，土风和，石风冽； 水云黑，火云赤，土云黄，石云白； 水雷玄，火雷愿，土雷连，石雷霹； 故一物铃通四象。 天有日月星辰，地有水火土石。 首有目耳口鼻，身有骨肉血髓。 髓为火，血为水，肉为土，骨为石，是为动物四象。 液为水，华为火，枝为土，根为石，是为植物四象。 几人之吹喷吁呵呼，应天之风雨云雾雷。 《易》有阳贞阴贞。 朱汉上曰：乾贞於十一月子，左行，阳时六。 阴贞六月未，右行，阴时六。 阳贞取阳卦，乾生三男，震坎艮也。 阴贞取阴卦，坤生三女，巽离兑也。 乾一阳生於子，始於坎，至离而乾终。 坤一阴生於午，阴不敢当午位，故退一辰而贞於未，至坎而坤终。 阳自左行，问时以治六辰。 阴自右行，亦间时以治六辰。 顺成其岁功，阴阳二贞既定，然后可以推四时之节气。 愚考之孔疏，数之所起，起於阴阳。 阴阳往来於日道。 冬至日南极，阳来而阴往。 冬，水位也。 一阳生为水，数一。 故乾贞於十一月，子而左行。 夏至日北极，阴进而阳退。 夏，火位也。 当以一阴为火数，但阴不名奇数，叉以偶。 故六月二阴生为火，数二故坤贞於未而右行。 冬至以及於夏至，当为阳来。 故正月建寅。 三阳生为木，数三。 夏至以及於冬至，当为阴进。 故八月建酉。 四阴生为金，数四。 三月建辰，居四季之首，为土位。 五阳生为土，数五也。 水在北，从盛阴之气，故润下者从阴也。 火在南，从盛阳之气，故炎上者从阳也。 木束金西，阴阳相半，柔可曲直，刚可从革，土含养万物，以为五行之主。 朱子曰：京房因卜筮推出许多道理。 其说谓：大．衍五十，其一不用者，天之生气，将以虚来实，故用四十九焉。 十日十二辰二十八宿，共五十。 其一不用，今只取生气一句为说。 一者为天之生气。 愚曰：天之数不用五，一由五出故。 大衍之数不用一者，一乃天之神也。 一入于北，则变坤成坎而生水，其数一。 一入于南，则变乾为离而生火，其数二。 一入于束，则天始交地而生木成震，其数三。 一入于西，则阴说於阳而生金成兑，其数四。 其终也，一复归藏於五，而为万化本。 存一不用者，是为生气。 太初气之始，是也。 五十五，数存五以为五行之本。 大衍五十，又存一以为太极之本。 太极而五行，以一分五，以五分十。 其四十九者，又五行之细数。 五十者，五其十。 十者，两其五。 两者，一也。 一者，水也。 五行之始，生气之出也。 十者，土也。 五行之终，生气之入也。 是故十日十二辰二十八宿，散在天。 三百六十是为度数，散在地。 万有一千五百二十，是万物之盈数。 其一不用者，退岁於密。 故木旺#3则水退#4火王则木退，土王则火退，金王。 则土退，水王则金退。 此五十五退五不用者，所以去衍之盈数。 五十又退一不用者，所以虚衍之本数。 故曰：抑其盈虚，其一万本於五，五本於一，天地盈虚与时消息。 天以一变四，四有体，一无体也。 此一在人为心，在德为仁，在《易》为乾，在时为春，无往而不为天之生气，岂特四十九着，赖此以为神哉。 天地万物，皆倚此以为立命之地。 故曰：不用之一，群用之所攸宗。 朱子曰：有八卦之金木水火土，有五行之金木水火土。
chunks.translated_text:
Water’s wind is cool, Fire’s wind is hot, Earth’s wind is mild, and Stone’s wind is biting.
Water’s clouds are black, Fire’s clouds are red, Earth’s clouds are yellow, and Stone’s clouds are white.
Water’s thunder is dark, Fire’s thunder is rumbling, Earth’s thunder is rolling, and Stone’s thunder is crashing.
Thus, a single thing necessarily connects to the Four Images.

Heaven has the sun, moon, stars, and constellations; Earth has Water, Fire, Earth, and Stone.
The head has eyes, ears, mouth, and nose; the body has bones, flesh, blood, and marrow.
Marrow is Fire, blood is Water, flesh is Earth, and bones are Stone—these are the Four Images of living beings.
Sap is Water, blossoms are Fire, branches are Earth, and roots are Stone—these are the Four Images of plants.
Every person’s exhalations—blowing, sniffling, sighing, and breathing—respond to Heaven’s winds, rains, clouds, mists, and thunders.

The *Yi* has yang’s steadfastness and yin’s steadfastness.
Zhu Hanshang said: *Qian* is steadfast in the eleventh month, *zi*, and moves left, governing six yang periods.
Yin is steadfast in the sixth month, *wei*, and moves right, governing six yin periods.
Yang’s steadfastness takes the yang hexagrams: *Qian* gives birth to the three sons—*Zhen*, *Kan*, and *Gen*.
Yin’s steadfastness takes the yin hexagrams: *Kun* gives birth to the three daughters—*Xun*, *Li*, and *Dui*.
*Qian*’s first yang arises at *zi*, beginning at *Kan* and ending at *Li* as *Qian* concludes.
*Kun*’s first yin arises at *wu*, but yin does not dare occupy the *wu* position, so it retreats one period to be steadfast at *wei* and ends at *Kan* as *Kun* concludes.
Yang moves left, governing six periods in alternation.
Yin moves right, likewise governing six periods in alternation.
Following the completion of the year’s work, once the two steadfastnesses of yin and yang are established, one may then deduce the solar terms of the four seasons.

In my humble study of Kong’s commentary, numbers originate from yin and yang.
Yin and yang move to and fro along the sun’s path.
At the winter solstice, the sun reaches its southern extreme: yang advances as yin retreats.
Winter is Water’s position. The first yang arises as Water, its number one.
Thus, *Qian* is steadfast in the eleventh month, *zi*, and moves left.
At the summer solstice, the sun reaches its northern extreme: yin advances as yang retreats.
Summer is Fire’s position. It should take one yin as Fire’s number, but yin is not called an odd number, so it is paired.
Thus, in the sixth month, the second yin arises as Fire, its number two, and *Kun* is steadfast at *wei* and moves right.
From the winter solstice to the summer solstice, yang advances.
Thus, the first month is established at *yin*. The third yang arises as Wood, its number three.
From the summer solstice to the winter solstice, yin advances.
Thus, the eighth month is established at *you*. The fourth yin arises as Metal, its number four.
The third month is established at *chen*, occupying the first of the four seasons, as Earth’s position.
The fifth yang arises as Earth, its number five.

Water lies in the north, following the qi of flourishing yin, so that which moistens and descends follows yin.
Fire lies in the south, following the qi of flourishing yang, so that which flames upward follows yang.
Wood in the east and Metal in the west are balanced between yin and yang: the soft can bend and straighten, the hard can be shaped and transformed.
Earth contains and nourishes the myriad things, serving as the master of the Five Phases.

Master Zhu said: Jing Fang deduced many principles from divination.
His theory states: The *Great Expansion* is fifty, but one is not used, for Heaven’s generative qi, intending to empty and then fill, employs forty-nine.
Ten days, twelve branches, and twenty-eight constellations together make fifty.
One is not used; here, only the phrase “generative qi” is taken as the explanation.
The one is Heaven’s generative qi.
In my humble opinion: Heaven’s number does not use five, for one emerges from five.
The number of the *Great Expansion* does not use one, for one is Heaven’s spirit.
When one enters the north, it transforms *Kun* into *Kan* and generates Water, its number one.
When one enters the south, it transforms *Qian* into *Li* and generates Fire, its number two.
When one enters the east, Heaven first joins Earth and generates Wood, forming *Zhen*, its number three.
When one enters the west, yin delights in yang and generates Metal, forming *Dui*, its number four.
In the end, one returns and is stored in five, becoming the root of the myriad transformations.
The one that is preserved and not used is the generative qi.
This is the beginning of the *Tai Chu* qi.

Fifty-five retains five as the root of the Five Phases.
The *Great Expansion* of fifty retains one as the root of the Supreme Ultimate.
From the Supreme Ultimate to the Five Phases, one divides into five, and five divides into ten.
The forty-nine are the detailed numbers of the Five Phases.
Fifty is five times ten.
Ten is two times five.
Two is one.
One is Water.
The beginning of the Five Phases, the emergence of generative qi.
Ten is Earth.
The end of the Five Phases, the return of generative qi.

Thus, the ten days, twelve branches, and twenty-eight constellations are dispersed in Heaven.
Three hundred sixty are the degrees, dispersed on Earth.
Ten thousand one thousand five hundred twenty are the full numbers of the myriad things.
The one that is not used retreats into secrecy.
Thus, when Wood flourishes, Water retreats; when Fire flourishes, Wood retreats; when Earth flourishes, Fire retreats; when Metal flourishes, Earth retreats; when Water flourishes, Metal retreats.
These fifty-five, by retreating five and not using them, eliminate the surplus of the *Great Expansion*.
Fifty, by retreating one and not using it, empties the root number of the *Great Expansion*.
Thus it is said: Restrain its fullness and emptiness. The ten myriad things originate from five, and five originates from one. Heaven and Earth’s fullness and emptiness ebb and flow with time.
Heaven transforms one into four, and the four have form, but one has no form.
This one in humans is the heart; in virtue, it is benevolence; in the *Yi*, it is *Qian*; in time, it is spring.
Nowhere does it not serve as Heaven’s generative qi—how could the forty-nine stalks rely solely on this for their spirit?
Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things all depend on this as the ground of their existence.
Thus it is said: The one that is not used is the ancestral root of all that is used.

chunks.original_text: 乾金，《易》卦金也。 兑金，五行金也。 巽木是卦中取象，震木是束方属木。 以土寄王四季，故止言四时。 唐孔氏谓：五行去土，亦日四象，谓金木水火。 土□震木离火兑金坎水，各主一时。 又巽同震木，乾同兑金，加以坤土，又日七八九六之谓。 在一一物为木火金水，在人为仁义礼智，在方为束西南北，在《易》为元亨利贞，在象为龙虎鹑龟，在月为弦望晦朔，在日为日一昼暮夜，在首为目耳鼻口，在身为骨肉血髓。 理也有此四段，气也有此四段。 事事物物，都相离不得。 春子丑寅为少阳，夏卯辰巳为太阳，秋午未申为少阴，冬酉戌亥为太阴。 邵伯温曰：水火土石，本体也，五行在其中矣。 金木水火土，致用也，五材出焉。 金出於石，木生於土。 有石后有金，有土后有木。 四象四体，先天也。 五行，后天也。 又曰：天下道理，只是一个生两个。 《易》说到八数住，《洪范》说到十数住。 卦八而数十，八是阴阳□数，十是五行数。 一阴一阳便是二。 以二乘二便是四，以四乘四便是八。 五行本是五，而有十者，一个包两个。 木包甲乙，火包丙丁，土包戊己，金包庚辛，水包壬癸。 又曰：甲乙是两个木，丙丁是两个火，戊己是两个土，金水亦然。 兼三才而两之，是阴阳五行之相克也，所以相成，而五常之德亦然。 莫大於仁，木德也。 仁或失於弱，故以义断之。 义，金德也。 义或失於刚，故以礼节之。 礼，火德也。 礼或失於拘，故以智通之。 智，水德也。 智或失於诈，故以信正之。 五常之德，乃五行相克之理。 老苏之说为然。 金克木，刚胜柔也。 水克火，柔胜刚也。 又曰：有互相发者。 王氏曰：水言润则火燥，土#5得木敷金敛可知。 火言炎则水洌土，蒸木温金清可知。 水言下火言上，则木左金右土中央可知。 木言曲直，则土园金方火锐水平可知。 金言从革，则木变土化水因火革可知。 土言稼穑，则井洫火爨木与金器械可知。 所谓木变者何？ 炳为火，斓为土。 土化者何？ 能燥能润，能敷能敛。 水因者何？ 因甘而甘，因苦而苦，因苍而苍，因白而白。 火革者何？ 革生为熟，革柔为刚，革刚为柔。 金亦能化，可园可平，可锐可曲直。 然非火革，则不能自化，故命之日从革。 又曰：得五行之秀者，为人只言五行，不言阴阳。 做这人，须是五行方做得成。 五行一阴阳也，舍五行别无讨阴阳处。 如甲木阳乙木阴之类。 朱子曰：数只是算气之节候，大率只是一个阴阳。 播而为五行，五行各有阴阳。 甲乙木，丙丁火，春木夏火，年月日时，无非五行之气。 甲乙丙丁，又属阴属阳，只是二五之气。 人生适逢其气，参差不齐，贵贱寿夭皆然。 圣贤在上，则其气中和。 不然，则气偏。 五行有得其气清者，聪明而无福禄； 有得其气浊者，有福禄而无智慧； 皆其气数使然。 尧舜禹汤文武周召得其正，孔孟齐鲁得其偏。 五代极乱，却生许多圣贤，如祖宗时。 如大睡一觉，醒时却有精神。 五行有理有气有数，其行於十干十二支之中。 可得而数，天一与地六合，生成水居北。 子数一，亥数六，壬为阳水一，癸为阴水六也。 地二与天七合，生成火而居南。 巳数二#6，午数七，丙为阳．火，七丁为阴火，二也。 天三地八生成木而居束。
