chunks.original_text: 卦气 卦气起於中孚。 京房传於焦赣，焦赣得之隐者。 言四正卦，分主四方，为方伯监司之官。 用坎离震兑者，是二至二分之日。 四时专主之气，春木夏火秋金冬水。 各卦主时，其占各以其日，观其善恶。 其余六十四卦爻，别主一日，几三百六十日。 余有五日四分日之一者，每日分为八十分。 分起於夜半，五日分为四百分。 四分日之一，又为二十分。 六十卦分之六七四十二卦，别各得七分。 剥卦阳气之尽，在九月末，十月当纯坤用事。 坤卦有六日七分，坤卦之尽，则复卦阳来，是从剥尽至阳气来复。 隔坤一卦，六日七分，举成数言，故日七日也。 愚谓以月卦言剥至复。 隔坤一卦，以侯卦言，每月各有五卦。 已上见《易纬图》#1。 京传以消息卦为君。 息卦日太阴，消卦日太阳，其余卦日少阴少阳。 西山蔡氏曰：康节亦用六日七分，扬子云放之以作《太玄》。 《太玄》去坎兑离震，《经世》去乾坤坎离。 皆去四正卦，用六十卦六日七分之说。 子夏曰：极六位而反於坤之复，其数七。 七爻在初，故称七日。 胡安定曰：几历六爻，一爻为一日，六十卦爻当三百六十日。 而两卦相去，皆以七日。 且卦有以爻为岁者，有以爻为月者，有以爻为日者。 复言七日，明卦气也。 以消息言，立冬十月节，至大雪十一月节。 坤至复卦，几历七日。 诸儒说皆源於子夏。 两汉诸儒，传经皆用六日七分之说。 至宋，王昭素、王沬、宋咸始着论驳之。 昭素曰：注疏并违夫子之义。 十月纯坤，犹有阳气在内。 故荠麦先生坤上六，犹有龙战。 若用六日七分为坤卦之尽，则十月节终，一阳便来据其节，去冬至尚十五日。 则知七日之义，难用《易》纬之数。 胡旦难之曰：西汉京房以卦气主事皆验，束汉郎颠六日七分之学，最为精妙。 夫六日七分，卦爻实数也。 岁之日，虚数也。 月不尽之日，铃加算以为闺焉。 昭素未明闰数之妙，故有去冬至十五日之疑也。 惜纬文丧失，京郎已亡。 朱子发曰：昭素知其大纲尔，岂知四正卦主四方六十卦。 主#2一期之日，节气皆统於四正，则余五日。 四分日之一，积而成闺。 每卦六日七分，气之进退，推荡而成。 如九月剥也，有艮既济噬大过，几五卦而后成坤。 十月卦也，又有未济骞颐孚，几五卦而后成复。 剥复相去三十日，复主冬至，冬至中气起於中孚，自中孚之后七日而复。 故曰：天行也。 历代先儒，惟玄得其旨。 故玄一，中二，羡三，从四，更五，眸六，廓七，喊八，沉九，成中象。 中孚冬至节，日起牛宿一度，斗建子。 律中黄锺，夏后之十一月也，其入牛宿五度为周。 周象七五一复，七日来复，是也。 自扬雄、马融、郑玄、宋、虞、陆、范并传此学，而昭素非之奈何。 王沬既驳孔颖达释王传之非矣，宋咸又贬京郎关朗辈假《易》以行壬遁卜祝阴阳衍数之学，圣人之旨无有焉。 何如以是卦直是月，以是爻直是日。 气何不起他卦，而独起中孚。 朱氏难之曰：颖达王传《易》纬消息之卦，不可非也。 六壬参时日，而得《易》之坎离。 遁甲分九官，而得《易》之《河图》。 皆得《易》之一端，而不能尽。 又谓：诸儒假壬遁言《易》，以笼天下，不知壬遁实出於《易》。 而言《易》者，亦何假夫壬遁哉！
chunks.translated_text:
The Hexagram-Qi System

The hexagram-qi system originates with *Zhong Fu* (Hexagram of Inner Truth). Jing Fang transmitted it from Jiao Gan, who received it from a recluse. It states that the four cardinal hexagrams govern the four directions, serving as regional overseers. The hexagrams *Kan* (Water), *Li* (Fire), *Zhen* (Thunder), and *Dui* (Lake) correspond to the solstices and equinoxes—days when the qi of the four seasons holds sway: wood in spring, fire in summer, metal in autumn, and water in winter. Each hexagram governs its season, and divination on its designated day reveals auspicious or inauspicious omens. The remaining sixty-four hexagrams and their lines each govern a single day, totaling three hundred and sixty days. The remaining five and a quarter days are divided into eighty parts per day, beginning at midnight, so that five days comprise four hundred parts, and the quarter-day is further divided into twenty parts. The sixty hexagrams are apportioned such that forty-two hexagrams each receive seven parts. The *Bo* hexagram (Stripping), where yang qi is exhausted, falls at the end of the ninth month, and the tenth month is governed solely by *Kun* (Earth). *Kun* spans six days and seven parts; when *Kun* is exhausted, the *Fu* hexagram (Return) brings the return of yang qi. From the exhaustion of *Bo* to the return of yang in *Fu*, *Kun* intervenes with six days and seven parts. Rounded to whole numbers, this is referred to as "seven days." In my humble opinion, when speaking of monthly hexagrams, *Bo* to *Fu* spans *Kun*; when speaking of seasonal hexagrams, each month contains five hexagrams. The above is recorded in the *Yi Wei Tu* (Diagrams of the *Weft* Texts of the *Book of Changes*).

Jing Fang’s transmission designates the waxing and waning hexagrams as rulers: waxing hexagrams are called *Tai Yin* (Great Yin), waning hexagrams *Tai Yang* (Great Yang), and the rest are termed *Shao Yin* (Lesser Yin) and *Shao Yang* (Lesser Yang). Cai Shi of Xishan remarked: Shao Yong also employed the six-day-seven-part system, and Yang Xiong adapted it to compose the *Tai Xuan* (Supreme Mystery). The *Tai Xuan* omits *Kan*, *Dui*, *Li*, and *Zhen*, while the *Jing Shi* (Sovereign Generations) omits *Qian*, *Kun*, *Kan*, and *Li*. Both exclude the four cardinal hexagrams, adhering to the sixty-hexagram, six-day-seven-part system. Zixia said: "When the six positions are exhausted, they revert to *Fu* within *Kun*; the number is seven." The seventh line begins at the first position, hence the term "seven days." Hu Anding stated: Traversing six lines, each line represents a day, so the sixty hexagrams and their lines correspond to three hundred and sixty days. The interval between any two hexagrams is seven days. Moreover, some hexagrams take a line as a year, others as a month, and others as a day. The phrase "seven days" clarifies the hexagram-qi system. In terms of waxing and waning, from the *Li Dong* (Beginning of Winter) solar term in the tenth month to the *Da Xue* (Great Snow) solar term in the eleventh month, *Kun* transitions to *Fu*, spanning nearly seven days. The explanations of all scholars trace back to Zixia. The Confucians of the two Han dynasties transmitted the Classics using the six-day-seven-part system. By the Song dynasty, Wang Zhaosu, Wang Kui, and Song Xian began to write treatises refuting it.

Zhaosu argued: The commentaries and sub-commentaries both contradict the Master’s meaning. Even in the tenth month, when *Kun* is pure, yang qi still resides within. Thus, the *Qimai* (Millet) Master’s *Kun* hexagram’s top line speaks of "dragons battling." If *Kun* were exhausted after six days and seven parts, then at the end of the tenth month, a single yang would immediately occupy its position, leaving fifteen days until the winter solstice. This demonstrates the difficulty of applying the seven-day principle to the numerical system of the *Yi Wei*. Hu Dan challenged this, saying: In the Western Han, Jing Fang’s hexagram-qi governance consistently proved accurate. In the Eastern Han, Lang Dian’s six-day-seven-part theory was the most refined. The six-day-seven-part system is the actual count of hexagrams and lines, while the days of the year are a nominal count. The remaining days of the month are calculated and added as intercalary days. Zhaosu failed to grasp the subtlety of intercalation, hence his doubt about the fifteen-day gap before the winter solstice. It is regrettable that the *Weft* texts have been lost, and Jing Fang and Lang Dian’s teachings have perished.

Zhu Zifa remarked: Zhaosu only understood the general outline. How could he comprehend that the four cardinal hexagrams govern the four directions, while the sixty hexagrams govern the days of a full year? The solar terms are all regulated by the four cardinal hexagrams, leaving five days and a quarter, which accumulate to form intercalary days. Each hexagram spans six days and seven parts, with the advance and retreat of qi propelling the cycle. For example, in the ninth month, *Bo* is followed by *Gen* (Mountain), *Ji Ji* (After Completion), *Shi He* (Biting Through), and *Da Guo* (Great Exceeding), totaling five hexagrams before *Kun* is complete. In the tenth month, *Wei Ji* (Before Completion), *Jian* (Obstruction), *Yi* (Nourishment), and *Zhong Fu* (Inner Truth) precede *Fu*, again five hexagrams. Thirty days separate *Bo* and *Fu*, with *Fu* governing the winter solstice. The mid-point qi of the winter solstice begins with *Zhong Fu*, and seven days after *Zhong Fu*, *Fu* arrives. Thus it is said: "This is the movement of Heaven." Among the scholars of past dynasties, only the *Xuan* (Mystery) grasped its essence. Hence: *Xuan* is one, *Zhong* (Center) is two, *Xian* (Surplus) is three, *Cong* (Compliance) is four, *Geng* (Renewal) is five, *Mou* (Gaze) is six, *Kuo* (Vastness) is seven, *Han* (Shout) is eight, *Chen* (Submersion) is nine, forming the central image.

*Zhong Fu* corresponds to the winter solstice solar term, when the sun rises at one degree of the *Niu* (Ox) constellation, and the Dipper points to *Zi* (North). The pitch-standard *Huang Zhong* (Yellow Bell) governs the eleventh month of the Xia calendar. The Zhou dynasty entered the *Niu* constellation at five degrees. The Zhou symbol *seven-five-one-return* (七五一复) signifies the seven-day return of yang qi. From Yang Xiong, Ma Rong, Zheng Xuan, Song, Yu, Lu, and Fan, all transmitted this learning, yet Zhaosu opposed it—what could be done? Wang Kui had already refuted Kong Yingda’s interpretation of Wang Bi’s commentary, and Song Xian further denounced Jing Fang, Lang Dian, and Guan Lang for appropriating the *Book of Changes* to practice *Ren Dun* (Six Ren), divination, incantations, and yin-yang numerology, which deviate from the Sage’s intent. Why not simply assign each hexagram to a month and each line to a day? Why does the qi not arise from other hexagrams but uniquely from *Zhong Fu*?

Zhu Shi countered: Kong Yingda and Wang Bi’s *Yi Wei* waxing-and-waning hexagrams cannot be dismissed. *Liu Ren* (Six Ren) divination aligns times and days with the *Kan* and *Li* hexagrams of the *Book of Changes*. *Dun Jia* (Hidden Jia) divides the nine palaces according to the *He Tu* (Yellow River Diagram), both capturing one aspect of the *Book of Changes* but not its entirety. He further argued: Scholars who invoke *Ren Dun* to explain the *Book of Changes* seek to encompass all under heaven, unaware that *Ren Dun* actually derives from the *Book of Changes*. Why, then, should those who expound the *Book of Changes* rely on *Ren Dun*?

chunks.original_text: ．圣人推阴阳消息之理，以明得失存亡之象。 咸信刚柔进退，而不信消息《易》纬之学，而谓卦气不起於中孚，是终日数十而不知二五也。 岂得为善观书乎。 元贞乙未冬至日，虚谷方先生以书抵予。 曰：朱子发冬至起牛宿一度，此古法也。 汉文帝三年甲子，冬至日在牛二十二度，至唐兴元元年甲子，冬至日在斗九度。 九百六十一年问，差十二度。 今元贞元年十一月初七，冬至日在箕八度，又退十二度。 冬至后五日，在斗三度。 如何尚执旧说，为冬至日入牛宿为周象复乎？ 愚曰：稽之往古，难玖尽同。 《历》谓：尧时冬至日在虚一度，何承天却云在女十度。 宋《元嘉历》冬至日在斗十七度，《月令要义》却云在斗十四度。 唐开元《大衍历》冬至日在斗十度，至宋《统元历》冬至日在斗二度。 至如古历分日起於子半，淳风却以子初为朔，遂差二刻，当时亦伏其精。 盖阴阳二气，参差不齐，推荡而成一岁。 其盈缩进退，自是如此，不过箕斗牛女之间而已。 《太玄》谓入牛宿象复者，亦本《太初》历法。 举当时已效者言之，约其大数以为之准尔。 末流虽异，其本则同，未敢轻訾也。 朱子曰：善为历者，要叉立虚宽之大数以包之，斯言是已。 若夫六日七分之说，诸儒辩之详矣，焉用赘。 革之《象》曰：泽中有火，革； 君子以治历明时。 朱氏子发曰：冬至日起牵牛一度，右行周十二次，尽斗二十六度，复还牵牛之一度，而历更矣。 牵牛火位，星纪水位，日月交会于此，泽中有火之象也。 此上元《太初》起历之元，在卦气为三月。 《太玄》准之，以更史氏日革。 居序卦之四十九，当太衍之数节。 居序卦之六十，当周天之度。 六十卦三百六十爻，一爻主一日。 上经乾起甲子，泰甲戌，噬甲申，至离三十卦一百八十日而三甲尽。 下经咸起甲午，损甲辰，震甲寅，至节癸亥而终，亦三十卦一百八十日而年一周。 所以京焦用以直日节，日天地节。 而四时成革，亦日天地革。 而四时成是，或一道节。 后继以中孚小过既未者，所以分坎离震兑四卦，应子午卯酉，为春夏秋冬。 四时两之，以为八节，是为分至启闭。 每爻直十五日，以应七十二侯。 先儒言卦起中孚，非也。 中孚起於甲子尔。 乾十一月起甲子，阳气至巳而终节。 十月卦而得癸亥，是阴生於午，至亥而终巳，结算一年了毕。 今又曰：中孚亦为十一月，卦起甲子，至未济而终者，盖以卦气皆自前月中气而起。 《太玄》以中准中孚配坎之初六，为十一月。 中气一场始生，以应上元。 《太初》十一月朔旦，冬至为起数之元，算历之首也。 中孚巽上兑下，小过震上艮下，并既未济坎离之体为六子。 少阳少阴，六子之气，分布四时，以成一年之候。 邵子曰：洛下闳改《颛历》为《太初历》，子云准《太初历》作《太玄》。 凡一隔五卦，气起於中心。 故首中卦参天两地，倚数非天地正数，拟天地正数而然也。 康节曰：《太玄》其知天地之心乎？ 心者，坤极生乾，始於冬至之时。 此律历之元也。 其钩深致远，与神契合有如此。 故其诗曰：若无杨子天人学，安有庄生内外篇。 一阳初动，万物未生，圣人以此见天地心。 卦起中孚，七日应焉。 以其中虚象心也，与汉《太初历》相应。
chunks.translated_text:
The sage deduced the principles of yin-yang waxing and waning to illuminate the images of gain and loss, survival and demise. Those who trust in the advance and retreat of hardness and softness yet reject the *Xiao Xi* (Waxing and Waning) learning of the *Yi Wei* (Apocrypha of the *Book of Changes*), claiming that hexagram qi does not arise from *Zhong Fu*, are like those who count all day yet know not of two and five—how can they be deemed skilled at reading books?

On the winter solstice of the *yimao* year in the *Yuanzhen* reign (1295), Master Fang of Xugu sent me a letter, stating: "Zhu Zifa posits that the winter solstice begins at the first degree of *Niu* (Ox) Mansion—this is an ancient method. In the third year of Emperor Wen of Han (177 BCE), the winter solstice fell on the twenty-second degree of *Niu*. By the first year of the *Xingyuan* reign of Tang (784 CE), it had shifted to the ninth degree of *Dou* (Dipper). Over 961 years, it regressed twelve degrees. Now, in the first year of *Yuanzhen* (1295), on the seventh day of the eleventh month, the winter solstice falls on the eighth degree of *Ji* (Winnowing Basket), having regressed another twelve degrees. Five days after the solstice, it lies at the third degree of *Dou*. How can one still cling to the old saying that the winter solstice enters *Niu* Mansion to symbolize the return of the Zhou?"

I replied: "Examining antiquity, it is difficult to find complete uniformity. The *Calendar* states that in the time of Yao, the winter solstice fell on the first degree of *Xu* (Emptiness), yet He Chengtian claimed it was on the tenth degree of *Nü* (Woman). The *Yuangai Calendar* of the Song placed the solstice at the seventeenth degree of *Dou*, while the *Monthly Ordinances Essential Meaning* placed it at the fourteenth degree. The *Dayan Calendar* of the Tang’s *Kaiyuan* era set it at the tenth degree of *Dou*, and by the Song’s *Tongyuan Calendar*, it had shifted to the second degree. Moreover, ancient calendars marked the start of the day at midnight, yet Cui Zhongrong took the beginning of *zi* (midnight) as the start of the month, resulting in a two-*ke* discrepancy—yet even then, his precision was acknowledged.

For yin and yang qi, uneven and irregular, surge and recede to form a year. Their expansion and contraction, advance and retreat, naturally follow this pattern, shifting only within the bounds of *Ji*, *Dou*, *Niu*, and *Nü*. The *Tai Xuan*’s claim that entering *Niu* Mansion symbolizes return derives from the *Tai Chu* calendar. It speaks of what was empirically validated at the time, approximating the general reckoning as a standard. Though later developments diverged, their foundation remains the same—I dare not dismiss them lightly."

Zhu Xi said: "A skilled calendar-maker must establish broad, flexible parameters to encompass all—this is indeed correct." As for the theory of "six days and seven fen," the various scholars have debated it thoroughly—what need is there to belabor it further?

The *Xiang* (Image) of *Ge* (Revolution) states: "Fire within the marsh—*Ge*. The noble person, in accordance with this, regulates the calendar and clarifies the seasons." Zhu Zifa said: "The winter solstice begins at the first degree of *Qianniu* (Ox Leader), proceeding rightward through the twelve stations, completing at the twenty-sixth degree of *Dou*, then returning to the first degree of *Qianniu*—thus the calendar is renewed. *Qianniu* is the fire position, *Xingji* (Star Marker) the water position; the sun and moon conjoin here, forming the image of fire within the marsh. This is the origin of the *Tai Chu* calendar’s epoch, corresponding in hexagram qi to the third month. The *Tai Xuan* aligns with this, renewing the historian’s daily reckoning. It occupies the forty-ninth position in the sequence of hexagrams, matching the nodal point of the *Tai Yan* (Great Expansion) number, and the sixtieth, aligning with the degrees of the celestial circuit.

The sixty hexagrams and 360 lines, each line governing a day. The upper canon begins with *Qian* at *jiazi*, *Tai* at *jiaxu*, *Shi* at *jiashen*, and concludes at *Li*, thirty hexagrams encompassing 180 days, exhausting the three *jia*. The lower canon begins with *Xian* at *jiawu*, *Sun* at *jiachen*, *Zhen* at *jiayin*, and ends at *Jie* at *guihai*, likewise thirty hexagrams spanning 180 days to complete a year. Thus, Jing and Jiao used them to determine daily nodes, calling them 'heaven-and-earth nodes.' The four seasons achieve revolution—this is also called 'heaven-and-earth revolution.' The four seasons are thus established, or unified in a single Dao of nodal division.

The subsequent hexagrams—*Zhong Fu*, *Xiao Guo*, and *Ji Ji*—serve to divide the *Kan*, *Li*, *Zhen*, and *Dui* hexagrams, corresponding to *zi*, *wu*, *mao*, and *you*, representing spring, summer, autumn, and winter. Doubling the four seasons yields the eight nodes, marking the solstices, equinoxes, and the beginnings and closings of the seasons. Each line governs fifteen days, aligning with the seventy-two seasonal markers.

Former scholars claimed that hexagrams begin with *Zhong Fu*—this is incorrect. *Zhong Fu* begins at *jiazi*. *Qian* in the eleventh month starts at *jiazi*, with yang qi culminating at *si* and ending its node. Ten hexagrams yield *guihai* in the tenth month—here, yin is born at *wu*, culminating at *hai* to conclude the reckoning of a year.

Now, it is also said that *Zhong Fu* corresponds to the eleventh month, beginning at *jiazi* and concluding at *Wei Ji*—this is because hexagram qi all arise from the mid-month qi of the preceding month. The *Tai Xuan* aligns *Zhong Fu* with the initial six of *Kan*, corresponding to the eleventh month. The mid-month qi begins to stir, resonating with the *Shang Yuan* (Upper Origin). The *Tai Chu* calendar takes the new moon and winter solstice of the eleventh month as the origin of reckoning, the head of calendar computation.

*Zhong Fu* (upper *Xun*, lower *Dui*), *Xiao Guo* (upper *Zhen*, lower *Gen*), and *Ji Ji* (embodying the forms of *Kan* and *Li*) constitute the six children. The qi of lesser yang and lesser yin, the six children, distribute across the four seasons to complete a year’s seasonal markers."

Shaozi said: "Luo Xiahong reformed the *Zhuan* calendar into the *Tai Chu* calendar, and Yang Xiong modeled the *Tai Xuan* upon the *Tai Chu* calendar. Every sixth hexagram, qi arises from the center. Thus, the first hexagram combines three celestial and two terrestrial numbers—though not the true celestial and terrestrial numbers, it approximates them.

Kangjie said: "Does the *Tai Xuan* not grasp the heart of heaven and earth? The heart is where *Kun*’s extremity generates *Qian*, beginning at the time of the winter solstice—this is the origin of pitch standards and calendars. Its profound and far-reaching insights harmonize with the divine to this extent." Thus, his poem reads: "Were it not for Yangzi’s learning of heaven and man, how could there be Zhuangzi’s inner and outer chapters?"

When the first yang stirs and the myriad things are yet unborn, the sage perceives the heart of heaven and earth in this. Hexagrams begin with *Zhong Fu*, responding in seven days. Its central emptiness images the heart, resonating with the Han *Tai Chu* calendar.

chunks.original_text: 《颛帝历》以十月为首，《连山》经以艮为首。 子云参之八十一首，每首九赞，通七百二十九赞。 赞，爻也。 两赞直一日，每赞直六时，一时得六策，一赞得三十六策，与六十卦气之爻合。 每卦六日七分，玄每首四日有半。 一首四日分则有余，两首九日分则平。 阴首以阴数为主，阳首以阳数为主。 以五居二四之中，五土也。 一二三四，生数居五之前，六七八九，成数居五之后。 朱子曰：《太玄》都是学焦延寿推卦气。 焦氏诸家说不同。 文王八卦，乾在西北，十二卦在束南； 坤在西南，十二卦在西北； 位置迥然不同。 《易》卦震束兑西离南坎北为一说，十二辟卦分属十二辰为一说。 及焦延寿为卦气直日之法，乃合二而一之。 既以八卦之坎离震兑，二十四爻直日时，又以十二辟直十二月。 且分为四十八卦，为公侯卿大夫，而六日七分之说生焉。 《太玄》放之卦气，以中孚为冬至之初，颐上九为大雪之末。 《太玄》亦以中为阳气开端，冬至初也。 养有崎赢二赞，大雪末也。 皆以《易》卦气为次序，而变其名称。 卦气以坎离震兑，主二十四气。 《玄》则自中将四而六之，以主二十四气。 其取数也，一本之《河图》。 一与六共宗，二与七共朋，三与八成友，四与九同道，五与十相守，盖合生成之数。 以睨．拟之，衣裳之示。 ，取诸三八；

The *Zhuan Emperor’s Calendar* takes the tenth month as its beginning, while the *Lianshan* Classic begins with *Gen*. Ziyun’s *Tai Xuan* comprises eighty-one chapters, each with nine eulogies, totaling seven hundred twenty-nine eulogies. These eulogies are the *yao*. Two eulogies correspond to one day, each eulogy governing six hours; one hour yields six *ce*, so one eulogy yields thirty-six *ce*, aligning with the *yao* of the sixty hexagrams’ qi. Each hexagram spans six and seven-sevenths days, while each *Tai Xuan* chapter spans four and a half days. One chapter of four and a half days leaves a remainder, but two chapters of nine days balance evenly. Yin chapters take yin numbers as their basis, while yang chapters take yang numbers. The number five resides between two and four—five is earth. One, two, three, and four, the generating numbers, precede five; six, seven, eight, and nine, the completing numbers, follow it.

Master Zhu said: "*Tai Xuan* entirely follows Jiao Yanshou’s method of deriving hexagram qi." The explanations of Jiao’s school differ. In King Wen’s eight trigrams, *Qian* lies in the northwest, with twelve hexagrams in the southeast; *Kun* lies in the southwest, with twelve hexagrams in the northwest—their positions are entirely distinct. The *Yi*’s trigrams—*Zhen* in the east, *Dui* in the west, *Li* in the south, and *Kan* in the north—form one system, while the twelve sovereign hexagrams assigned to the twelve earthly branches form another. When Jiao Yanshou devised his method of hexagram qi governing days, he merged the two into one. He not only used the eight trigrams’ *Kan*, *Li*, *Zhen*, and *Dui*—with their twenty-four *yao* governing days and hours—but also assigned the twelve sovereign hexagrams to the twelve months. Further dividing them into forty-eight hexagrams, corresponding to dukes, marquises, ministers, and grandees, the theory of "six days and seven parts" emerged. *Tai Xuan* models itself on hexagram qi, taking *Zhong Fu* as the beginning of the winter solstice and *Yi*’s top *yao* as the end of *Da Xue*. *Tai Xuan* also takes the center as the inception of yang qi, the start of the winter solstice. *Yang* contains the two eulogies *Qi* and *Ying*, marking the end of *Da Xue*. All follow the sequence of the *Yi*’s hexagram qi but alter their names. Hexagram qi employs *Kan*, *Li*, *Zhen*, and *Dui* to govern the twenty-four qi. *Tai Xuan*, however, begins with the center, multiplies by four and then six, to govern the twenty-four qi. In its selection of numbers, it fundamentally follows the *River Chart*: one and six share a lineage, two and seven form a fellowship, three and eight become companions, four and nine follow the same path, and five and ten guard one another—thus uniting the generating and completing numbers. To approximate this, the symbols of robes and garments are derived from three and eight...

When the first yang stirs and the myriad things are yet unborn, the sage perceives the heart of heaven and earth in this. Hexagrams begin with *Zhong Fu*, responding in seven days. Its central emptiness images the heart, resonating with the Han *Tai Chu* calendar.

chunks.original_text: 甲戟之威，取诸四九； 君臣之制，取诸二七； 鬼神之祀，取诸一六； 酒食之养，取诸五五； 其不言五者，以五五为十也。 又曰：扬雄《太玄》，全是模仿《易》。 他全用三数，《易》却用四数。 他本是模《易》，故就他模底句上看《易》也。 可略见得意思。 《太玄》准《易》者。 周准复，童准蒙，增准益，交准泰，颐准养。 皆就《易》卦上取名。 或一首准一卦，二首三首准一卦，所以明分秒之法也。 玄冲者，序卦也。 玄错者，杂卦也。 玄数者，说卦也。 玄文者，文言也。 系辞之於摊莹抗图，告也。 皆准《易》也。 《易》以一生二，二生四，四而八之，八八六十四而止。 《玄》以一生三，三生九，九而九之，九九八十一而止。 《易》有六爻，金木水火为一分，上为二。 六六相乘，六十四卦而三百八十四爻生。 《玄》有九赞，分金木水火之生。 成为八，并土之守一为九。 九九相乘，至於七百二十九赞而备。 《易》与《玄》皆同一五行也。 《易》以二乘四，四乘八，八乘六十四，六十四乘三百．八十四，盖本於《河图》之天三数而乘地四数也。 故以四为地体，而天以三数用之。 此伏羲所以重三爻而为六爻，以成一卦。 《玄》之数，起於黄锺之律。 九寸空围九分，三其一为三才，三其天三为九畴，三其地四为十二辟卦，三其天五为十五日之一气，三其地六而为十有八变而成卦。 黄锺起於子，天之一。 故参子之一，於丑为三。 参丑之三，於寅为九。 参寅之九，於卯为二十七。 参卯之二十七，於辰为八十一。 参辰之八十一，於巳为二百四十三。 参巳之二百四十三，於午而为七百二十九。 由午以及未申酉戌亥五辰，则得十七万七千一百四十七。 此乃京房六十律相生之数，而见於束西《律历志》之注云。 《玄》三百六十五日，每一日以八十一乘之，为二万九千五百六十五分。 又益以四分日之一二十分．少，合二万九千五百八十五分少。 每赞每气，算之皆合。 故曰：下饮上饮，出入九虚。 玄者，神之魁也。 又曰：子云为人思沉，会去思索。 如阴阳消长之妙，他直是去推求。 张平子谓其妙极道。 ．数使人论难阴阳之事，汉家得天下二百岁之书，与五经相拟。 如曰：天日错行，阴阳更迭#6死生相缪，万物乃缠。 此言明生魄死，魄死明生，死生相授，万物缠绵而成就也。 如曰：察龙虎之文，观乌龟之理。 立天经，日阴与阳。 立地纬，日纵与横。 立人行，日晦与明。 此言天为经，地为纬，南北为经，束西为纬。 晦明贤愚之分，在其中矣。 如日．．一昼一夜，然后作一日。 一阴一阳，然后生万物。 此言夏昼六十刻，冬夜六十刻。 夜长无过冬至，昼长无过夏至。 冬至之夜，不如夏至之昼，故昼数多。 又如曰：生阳莫如子，生阴莫如午。 西北则子美尽，束南则午美尽。 此言阳起子终午，阴起午终子。 西南尚有微阳，故至西北而美尽。 束北尚有微阴，故至束南而美极。 至於阳道常饶，阴道常乏，言阳全用，阴半用也。 南北定位，东西通气。 言子午定位者，阴阳之府。 束木旺#7则西金死，气应而相通也。 其论日月也，曰：日有南有北； 不南不北，则无冬夏。 月有往有来； 不往不来，则晦朔不成。 圣人察乎跳侧匿之变，而律乎日月雌雄之序。
chunks.translated_text:
The might of halberds and spears derives from four and nine; the system of ruler and minister, from two and seven; the sacrifices to spirits and gods, from one and six; the nourishment of wine and food, from five and five—yet five is unspoken, for five times five makes ten.

It is further said: Yang Xiong’s *Tai Xuan* is entirely modeled on the *Yi*. While the *Yi* employs the number four, he uses the number three throughout. Since he originally imitated the *Yi*, one may glimpse its meaning by examining the very phrases he imitates. Where the *Tai Xuan* aligns with the *Yi*: *Zhou* corresponds to *Fu*, *Tong* to *Meng*, *Zeng* to *Yi*, *Jiao* to *Tai*, and *Yi* to *Yang*. All these names are drawn from the *Yi*’s hexagrams. Sometimes one section matches one hexagram, or two or three sections match a single hexagram—thus clarifying the method of minute divisions.

*Xuan Chong* is the sequence of hexagrams; *Xuan Cuo*, the miscellaneous hexagrams; *Xuan Shu*, the commentary on the hexagrams; *Xuan Wen*, the *Wen Yan*. The *Xi Ci*’s exposition on the *Tui Ying Kang Tu* is its proclamation—all modeled on the *Yi*. The *Yi* begins with one generating two, two generating four, four expanding to eight, and eight times eight yielding sixty-four, where it halts. The *Tai Xuan* begins with one generating three, three generating nine, and nine times nine yielding eighty-one, where it halts. The *Yi* has six lines: metal, wood, water, and fire form one division, the upper line another. Six times six produces sixty-four hexagrams and three hundred eighty-four lines. The *Tai Xuan* has nine eulogies, dividing the generation of metal, wood, water, and fire. These become eight, and with earth’s guarding of one, form nine. Nine times nine extends to seven hundred twenty-nine eulogies, where it is complete. Both the *Yi* and the *Tai Xuan* share the same Five Phases.

The *Yi* multiplies two by four, four by eight, eight by sixty-four, and sixty-four by three hundred eighty-four—rooted in the *River Chart*’s celestial three multiplied by earth’s four. Thus, four is the body of earth, while heaven employs the number three. This is why Fuxi doubled three lines into six to form a hexagram. The numbers of the *Tai Xuan* arise from the pitch of *Huang Zhong*: a nine-inch hollow with a nine-fen circumference. Tripling one yields the Three Powers; tripling heaven’s three yields the Nine Categories; tripling earth’s four yields the twelve sovereign hexagrams; tripling heaven’s five yields the fifteen days of one qi; tripling earth’s six yields the eighteen changes that form a hexagram.

*Huang Zhong* begins at *zi*, heaven’s one. Tripling *zi*’s one yields three at *chou*; tripling *chou*’s three yields nine at *yin*; tripling *yin*’s nine yields twenty-seven at *mao*; tripling *mao*’s twenty-seven yields eighty-one at *chen*; tripling *chen*’s eighty-one yields two hundred forty-three at *si*; tripling *si*’s two hundred forty-three yields seven hundred twenty-nine at *wu*. From *wu* through *wei*, *shen*, *you*, *xu*, and *hai*—the five celestial stems—it reaches one hundred seventy-seven thousand one hundred forty-seven. This is the number of Jing Fang’s sixty pitch-standards, as recorded in the annotations of the *Treatise on Pitch Standards and Calendars* in the Eastern and Western *Han Histories*.

The *Tai Xuan*’s three hundred sixty-five days, each multiplied by eighty-one, yield twenty-nine thousand five hundred sixty-five parts. Adding one-fourth of a day—twenty parts and a fraction—makes twenty-nine thousand five hundred eighty-five parts and a fraction. Every eulogy and every qi aligns precisely in calculation. Thus it is said: "Below they drink, above they drink, issuing and entering the nine voids." The *Xuan* is the chief of spirits.

It is also said: Ziyun (Yang Xiong) was a man of deep thought, who would withdraw to ponder. Like the subtleties of yin and yang’s waxing and waning, he simply sought to deduce them. Zhang Heng praised its profound Dao. Its numbers enable one to debate matters of yin and yang—a book of the Han dynasty’s two hundred years, comparable to the Five Classics.

For example: "The sun’s path errs; yin and yang alternate in succession. Death and life intertwine; the ten thousand things are thus entangled." This speaks of the bright phase’s birth and the dim phase’s death, the dim phase’s death and the bright phase’s birth—death and life passing one to the other, the ten thousand things entwined and accomplished.

Or: "Examine the patterns of dragon and tiger; observe the principles of tortoise and bird. Establish heaven’s warp as yin and yang; establish earth’s weft as vertical and horizontal; establish human conduct as darkness and light." This means heaven is the warp, earth the weft; south and north are the warp, east and west the weft. The division between darkness and light, worthiness and foolishness, lies therein.

Or: "One day and one night make a full day; one yin and one yang generate the ten thousand things." This refers to summer’s sixty *ke* of daylight and winter’s sixty *ke* of night. No night is longer than the winter solstice, no day longer than the summer solstice. The winter solstice’s night does not surpass the summer solstice’s day, hence the day’s count is greater.

Or: "Nothing generates yang like *zi*; nothing generates yin like *wu*. In the northwest, *zi*’s beauty is exhausted; in the southeast, *wu*’s beauty is exhausted." This means yang begins at *zi* and ends at *wu*, yin begins at *wu* and ends at *zi*. The southwest still holds a trace of yang, hence in the northwest its beauty is exhausted. The northeast still holds a trace of yin, hence in the southeast its beauty reaches its peak.

As for the Way of yang being ever abundant and the Way of yin ever deficient, this means yang is fully employed while yin is half used. "South and north fix position; east and west circulate qi." That *zi* and *wu* fix position refers to the storehouses of yin and yang. When east’s wood flourishes, west’s metal dies—qi responds and communicates.

In its discussion of the sun and moon, it says: "The sun has south and north; without south and north, there would be no winter and summer. The moon has going and coming; without going and coming, there would be no new and full moons." The sage observes the changes of concealment and exposure, and regulates the sequence of the sun and moon’s male and female.
chunks.overlap_context: four qi. *Tai Xuan*, however, begins with the center, multiplies by four and then six, to govern the twenty-four qi. In its selection of numbers, it fundamentally follows the *River Chart*: one and six share a lineage, two and seven form a fellowship, three and eight become companions, four and nine follow the same path, and five and ten guard one another—thus uniting the generating and completing numbers. To approximate this, the symbols of robes and garments are derived from three and eight...

chunks.original_text: 盖日南至牵牛，北至束井。 南为太阳，北为太阴。 阳精至太阳为夏，阴精至太阴为冬。 晦而月见西日跳，朔而月见束日侧匿（余见太阳章）。 其论阴阳数也，曰：子午数九，丑未八，寅申七，卯酉六，辰戌五，巳亥四。 故律四十二吕三十六。 或还或否，几七十有八。 甲己数九，乙庚八，丙辛七，丁壬六，戊癸五。 声生於日，律生於辰。 声以情质，律以和声，声律协而八音生。 盖以黄锺起子，乾始初九，午为子官，故数俱九。 以子丑寅卯辰巳月，对午未申酉戌亥月。 分四五六七八九之数，甲与己合，随子称九。 乙庚随丑称八，丙辛随寅称七，六五之数亦如之。 阳律九，七五而倍之，故四十二。 阴吕八，六四而倍之，故三十六。 并之七十八。 八则丑未还，得吕而不得律。 五声生於十干。 甲乙角也，丙丁征也，庚辛商也，壬癸羽也。 十二律生於十二时，律所出也。 八音者，金石丝竹匏土革木也。 此声律之源，五行之数。 后世托是以谈康节之数者，岂知其实出於此。 玄旨 《太玄》数始於三。 太玄，即太极也。 以象君位。 三方，即天地人也。 以象三才，日天玄地玄人玄。 三方象三公，一#8方有三州凡九州象九卿。 一州有三部凡七十二部象大夫。 立天道日始中终，立地道日上中下，立人道日思祸福。 《易》占以变，《玄》占以通。 《玄》之首赞，皆本五行。 自中而周，以至於养。 中为一水，周为二火，瓒为三本，闲为四金，少为五土，戾又为六水（地六成水）。 上又为七火，干又为八木，妳又为九金。 数止於九。 自羡而起，又为一水。 此以后皆然。 每首九赞，九赞之中，初一亦属水，次二属火，次三属木，次四金，次五土，次六又属水，次十又属火，次八又属木，次九又属金。 诸首中，以五为君。 一首之主，亦如《易》卦，以五爻为主也。 《玄》中首一阳生，对应首一阴始。 八十一首，皆相对待。 奇首阳，偶首阴。 奇对奇，偶对偶，所主不同而相反。 《玄》序曰：巡乘六甲，与斗相逢。 此《玄》起历之大旨。 《玄》有锜满，犹斗有闰月也。 八十一首自中而起，每首必指月旦日入之度，而皆以斗为主。 盖时之易正而可见者，斗历之难明而易差者。 闺气侯与斗相迎，既无差武，则闰正而历正矣。 又曰：《太玄》昼测之日，夜测之斗。 而不及於月，谓其常满以御虚也。 玄昼日及斗所指者，以其常满常指故也。 月有盈虚大小，疾迟无常，故不书也。 图中二十八宿之度，非天盘二十八宿也，乃节侯所至。 每月旦日日入之度，与《月令．》日入之度，大略相似。 《玄》图曰：自子至辰，自辰至申，自申至子，冠之以甲。 而章会统元与月蚀俱没，《玄》之道也。 郁林吴绩释曰：太初上元正月甲子朔旦，冬至无余分。 后千五百三十九岁甲辰朔旦，冬至无余分。 又千五百三十九岁甲申朔旦，冬至无余分。 十九岁为一章，二十七章五百一十三岁。 一会者，日月交会一终也。 八十一章，千五百三十九岁为一统。 从子至辰，自辰至申，凡四千六百一十七岁为一元。 元有三统， 统有三会，会有二十七章。 九会二百四十三章，没终也。 置一元之数，以章会三统。 几九会统数，除之终尽焉。 一章闰分尽，一会月食尽，一统朔分尽，一元六甲尽，《玄》之道。
chunks.translated_text:
The sun reaches its southernmost point at *Niu* (Ox) and its northernmost at *Dongjing* (Eastern Well). The south is the Greater Yang; the north is the Greater Yin. When yang essence reaches the Greater Yang, it is summer; when yin essence reaches the Greater Yin, it is winter. At dusk, the moon appears in the west as *tiao* (exposure); at dawn, it appears in the east as *ce ni* (concealment)—the rest is seen in the *Greater Yang* chapter.

In its discussion of the numbers of yin and yang, it states: *Zi* and *wu* are nine; *chou* and *wei* are eight; *yin* and *shen* are seven; *mao* and *you* are six; *chen* and *xu* are five; *si* and *hai* are four. Thus, the forty-two *lü* and thirty-six *lü* (pitch standards) alternate or not, totaling seventy-eight. *Jia* and *ji* are nine; *yi* and *geng* are eight; *bing* and *xin* are seven; *ding* and *ren* are six; *wu* and *gui* are five. Sound arises from the sun; *lü* arises from the celestial stems. Sound is based on essence and substance; *lü* harmonizes with sound. When sound and *lü* align, the eight tones arise. The Yellow Bell begins at *zi*, as *Qian*’s first yang line starts with nine. *Wu* is the palace of *zi*, hence both are nine. The months from *zi* to *si* correspond to those from *wu* to *hai*. The numbers four, five, six, seven, eight, and nine are divided: *jia* and *ji* pair with *zi* as nine; *yi* and *geng* follow *chou* as eight; *bing* and *xin* follow *yin* as seven; the numbers six and five follow likewise. Yang *lü* are nine, seven, and five, doubled to make forty-two. Yin *lü* are eight, six, and four, doubled to make thirty-six. Combined, they total seventy-eight. At eight, *chou* and *wei* return, obtaining *lü* but not *lü* (pitch standards). The five tones arise from the ten celestial stems: *jia* and *yi* are *jiao* (角); *bing* and *ding* are *zhi* (徵); *geng* and *xin* are *shang* (商); *ren* and *gui* are *yu* (羽). The twelve *lü* arise from the twelve hours, from which they emerge. The eight tones are metal, stone, silk, bamboo, gourd, earth, leather, and wood. This is the source of sound and *lü*, the numbers of the Five Phases. Later generations who cite this to discuss Kangjie’s numbers—how could they know its true origin lies here?

The profound principle: The numbers of the *Tai Xuan* begin with three. *Tai Xuan* is the Supreme Ultimate. It symbolizes the ruler’s position. The three directions are heaven, earth, and humanity, representing the Three Powers. The *Xuan* of heaven, the *Xuan* of earth, and the *Xuan* of humanity. The three directions symbolize the Three Dukes; each direction has three provinces, totaling nine provinces symbolizing the Nine Ministers. Each province has three departments, totaling seventy-two departments symbolizing the grand masters. Heaven’s Way is established as beginning, middle, and end; earth’s Way as upper, middle, and lower; humanity’s Way as contemplating fortune and misfortune.

The *Yi* divines through change; the *Xuan* divines through penetration. The opening eulogies of the *Xuan* are all based on the Five Phases. From *zhong* (center) to *zhou* (cycle), reaching *yang* (nourishment): *zhong* is one, water; *zhou* is two, fire; *zan* is three, wood; *xian* is four, metal; *shao* is five, earth; *li* is six, water (earth’s six completes water). *Shang* is seven, fire; *gan* is eight, wood; *shi* is nine, metal. The numbers end at nine. From *xian* onward, it begins again as one, water. This pattern continues thereafter. Each of the nine eulogies in a section: the first is water, the second is fire, the third is wood, the fourth is metal, the fifth is earth, the sixth is water again, the seventh is fire, the eighth is wood, and the ninth is metal. In all sections, five is the ruler. The primary line of a section is like the fifth line in a *Yi* hexagram. In the *Xuan*, the first section begins with yang, corresponding to the first section of yin. The eighty-one sections all correspond to one another. Odd sections are yang; even sections are yin. Odd corresponds to odd; even to even. Their governing principles differ and oppose one another.

The *Xuan*’s sequence states: "Patrolling the six *jia*, it meets the Dipper." This is the great principle of the *Xuan*’s calendrical origins. The *Xuan* has *qi man* (excess), just as the Dipper has intercalary months. The eighty-one sections begin from the center, and each section must indicate the degree of the sun’s entry at the month’s first day, all governed by the Dipper. For time is easily corrected and visible, while the Dipper’s reckoning is obscure and prone to error. When seasonal qi and the Dipper align without discrepancy, intercalation is correct, and the calendar is accurate.

It also states: "The *Tai Xuan* measures the sun by day and the Dipper by night," omitting the moon, for it constantly waxes to govern the void. The *Xuan* measures the sun by day and the Dipper’s pointer because they are constant and unchanging. The moon waxes and wanes, its size and speed irregular, hence it is not recorded. The degrees of the twenty-eight lodges in the diagram are not the celestial twenty-eight lodges but the positions of seasonal nodes. The degrees of the sun’s entry at the month’s first day and the *Monthly Ordinances*’ solar entries are broadly similar.

The *Xuan*’s diagram states: "From *zi* to *chen*, from *chen* to *shen*, from *shen* to *zi*, crowned with *jia*." Chapters, sessions, unities, and elements vanish together with lunar eclipses—this is the *Xuan*’s Way. Wu Ji of Yulin annotates: In the first year of the *Taichu* epoch, the first month was *jiazi*, the new moon coincided with the winter solstice, with no remainder. After 1,539 years, the first month was *jiachen*, the new moon coincided with the winter solstice, with no remainder. After another 1,539 years, the first month was *jiashen*, the new moon coincided with the winter solstice, with no remainder. Nineteen years make one *zhang*; twenty-seven *zhang* make 513 years. One *hui* is the completion of the sun and moon’s conjunction. Eighty-one *zhang* make 1,539 years, one *tong*. From *zi* to *chen*, from *chen* to *shen*, totaling 4,617 years make one *yuan*. A *yuan* has three *tong*; a *tong* has three *hui*; a *hui* has twenty-seven *zhang*. Nine *hui* have 243 *zhang*, completing the cycle. Calculating a *yuan*’s numbers with *zhang*, *hui*, and *tong*: when the nine *hui*’s *tong* numbers are exhausted, the cycle ends. One *zhang* exhausts intercalary fractions; one *hui* exhausts lunar eclipses; one *tong* exhausts new moon fractions; one *yuan* exhausts the six *jia*—this is the *Xuan*’s Way.

chunks.original_text: 《玄》起於天元，甲子朔旦。 冬至始於牵牛之初，自咫（八寸）及步运行不息。 周乎三百六十五度四分度之一，三十日为月，十二月为岁。 加闰以定四时，成三百六十五日四分日之一不周。 《颛历》四分日之三不周，《太初历》日之半。 所以不周者，阳数盈，阴数虚。 故为锜赢二赞，以满玄数，以合天度。 犹岁有闰月，以合岁之日，而行律历也。 愚谓：康节《经世历》与此虽不同，亦触类而进，以造神妙尔。 邵子先天卦气。 乾坤坎离，分配四时，主二十四气。 坎尽子中交离，初爻冬至，上爻惊垫。 离尽卯中交乾，初爻春分，上爻芒种。 乾尽午中交坎，初爻夏至，上爻白露。 坎尽□酉中交坤，初爻秋分，上爻大雪。 春夏秋冬，各用六十四卦气，皆中起子午卯酉，为四中二至二分。 当之寅申巳亥，为四孟四立。 当之《经世历》，以冬至为天地之元，元之元也。 故去四正卦，而用三百六十。 《卦气图》以春分为人物之元，亦元之元也。 故用六十四卦，而四之为二百五十六位。 《卦气图》以冬至子中为世之元，春分卯中为元之元，夏至午中为会之元，秋分酉中为运之元。 各六十四卦，各以气运而更迭。 直事开物於寅中，而起於惊垫者，二月初气也。 闭物於戌中，而终於立春者，十月初气也。 何也？ 曰：寅中戌中，虽主月会而言其用，则实由乎节气。 地之生物，以气为机。 天之气先至，而后地之物应之。 气之来，常先半月。 气以舒而常盈，月以疾而常缩。 故关子明云：当期之数，过者谓之气盈，不及者谓之朔虚。 气朔有盈，虚之不齐。 积微之久，中气或有居於月晦者，铃闺以置之，乃复乎初。 《经世》本於先天，故中朔同起卦气。 因先天本数，取中气以主月。 元会运世皆从中起，所谓举正於中也。 《卦图》曰：大运法当依《经世》，数起於星甲辰子。 小运法当依《卦气图》，起於甲巳孟日。 天统乎体。 气之体，生於四中。 故大运甲子当冬至，而二十四气之首，皆得子午卯酉之四中也。 气之用行於四立，故小运甲寅当立春，而二十四气之首，皆得寅申巳亥而王乎四孟也。 朱#10子曰：《先天图》左方自震初为冬至，离兑中为春分，至乾之末而交夏至。 右方自巽初为夏至，坎艮中为秋分，至坤之末而交冬至。 图之逆顺左右行，先儒详矣。 乾一兑二离三震四，已生之卦，其序自南而北。 若卦气运行，则自北而南。 一场生於震始，故邵子以冬至子之半为复。 十一月中也，十二月丑初小寒，其卦为坎、屯。 益月半大寒，则震、噬嗑、随#11正月寅初立春，其卦为无妄、明夷。 月半雨水，则贵、既济、家人。 二月卯初惊垫，其卦为丰、离、革。 月半春分，则同人、临。 三月辰初清明，其卦为损、节、孚。 月半谷雨，则妹、睽、兑。 立夏巳初，其卦为履、泰。 月半小满，则大畜、需、小畜。 五月午初芒种，其卦为．壮、大有、央。 至乾之末，交夏至焉，即午之半也。 此三十二卦属阳，以当春夏。 巽五坎六艮七坤八，未生之卦也。 图自西而北，若卦气之行，则自一阴生於巽始，故夏至午之半为始。 五月中也，六月未初小暑，其□卦为大过、鼎、怛。 月半大暑，则巽井蛊。 七月申初立秋，其卦为升、讼。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Xuan* begins at the Celestial Origin, at the first dawn of *jiazi*, when the winter solstice commences at the start of *Qianniu*. From a span of eight *cun* to a single step, it moves ceaselessly. It revolves through 365¼ degrees, thirty days make a month, twelve months make a year. Intercalary months are added to fix the four seasons, completing 365¼ days—yet it does not fully circle. The *Zhuan* calendar falls short by ¾ of a day, while the *Tai Chu* calendar falls short by half a day. The reason it does not fully circle is that yang numbers overflow while yin numbers are deficient. Thus, two surplus measures are added to fulfill the *Xuan*’s numbers and align with celestial degrees—just as intercalary months are added to reconcile the year’s days, thereby enacting the pitch pipes and calendrical reckoning.

I deem that Shao Kangjie’s *Jingshi* calendar, though differing from this, proceeds by analogy to achieve divine subtlety. Master Shao’s *Xiantian* hexagram qi: *Qian* and *Kun*, *Kan* and *Li*, are apportioned to the four seasons, governing the twenty-four qi. When *Kan* completes its course at the *zi* midpoint, it exchanges with *Li*; its first line marks the winter solstice, its top line the *Jingzhe*. When *Li* completes its course at the *mao* midpoint, it exchanges with *Qian*; its first line marks the spring equinox, its top line the *Mangzhong*. When *Qian* completes its course at the *wu* midpoint, it exchanges with *Kan*; its first line marks the summer solstice, its top line the *Bailu*. When *Kan* completes its course at the *you* midpoint, it exchanges with *Kun*; its first line marks the autumn equinox, its top line the *Daxue*. Spring, summer, autumn, and winter each employ sixty-four hexagram qi, all arising from the *zi*, *wu*, *mao*, and *you* midpoints as the four cardinals—two solstices and two equinoxes. The *yin*, *shen*, *si*, and *hai* positions correspond to the four *Meng* and four *Li*. In the *Jingshi* calendar, the winter solstice is the origin of heaven and earth, the origin of origins. Thus, it omits the four cardinal hexagrams and employs three hundred sixty. The *Guqi Tu* takes the spring equinox as the origin of humanity, also the origin of origins. Thus, it employs sixty-four hexagrams, multiplied fourfold to make two hundred fifty-six positions. The *Guqi Tu* takes the *zi* midpoint of the winter solstice as the origin of the world, the *mao* midpoint of the spring equinox as the origin of origins, the *wu* midpoint of the summer solstice as the origin of conjunctions, and the *you* midpoint of the autumn equinox as the origin of revolutions. Each employs sixty-four hexagrams, alternating according to qi and revolution. The inception of affairs and the unfolding of things begin at the *yin* midpoint, commencing at the *Jingzhe*, the second month’s first qi. The closure of things occurs at the *xu* midpoint, concluding at the *Lichun*, the tenth month’s first qi. Why? The *yin* and *xu* midpoints govern monthly conjunctions in name, but in function, they truly depend on the nodal qi. The earth’s generation of things relies on qi as its mechanism. Heaven’s qi arrives first, and only then do earth’s things respond. The qi’s arrival always precedes by half a month. Qi, by its nature, is ever-expansive and thus constantly overflows, while the moon, by its swiftness, is ever-contracting and thus constantly deficient. Thus, Guan Ziming said: "In the reckoning of appointed times, that which exceeds is called *qi* surplus, while that which falls short is called new moon deficiency." The irregularities of *qi* surplus and new moon deficiency accumulate over time, so that the central qi may occasionally fall on the month’s last day. Intercalation is then applied to restore the original alignment.

The *Jingshi* is rooted in the *Xiantian*, thus its central conjunctions and new moons both arise from hexagram qi. Following the *Xiantian*’s fundamental numbers, it takes the central qi to govern the months. The origins of *yuan*, conjunctions, revolutions, and worlds all begin from the center—this is what is meant by "establishing the correct from the center." The *Guqi Tu* states: "The great revolution’s method should follow the *Jingshi*, its numbers beginning at *xing*, *jia*, *chen*, *zi*. The lesser revolution’s method should follow the *Guqi Tu*, beginning at *jia*, *si*, *Meng* days." Heaven unifies the forms. The form of qi arises from the four midpoints. Thus, the great revolution’s *jiazi* corresponds to the winter solstice, and the heads of the twenty-four qi all attain the four midpoints of *zi*, *wu*, *mao*, and *you*. The function of qi operates through the four *Li*, thus the lesser revolution’s *jiayin* corresponds to the *Lichun*, and the heads of the twenty-four qi all attain the *yin*, *shen*, *si*, and *hai* positions, reigning over the four *Meng*.

Master Zhu said: In the *Xiantian Tu*, the left side begins with the first line of *Zhen* as the winter solstice, the midpoints of *Li* and *Dui* as the spring equinox, and proceeds to the end of *Qian* to exchange with the summer solstice. The right side begins with the first line of *Xun* as the summer solstice, the midpoints of *Kan* and *Gen* as the autumn equinox, and proceeds to the end of *Kun* to exchange with the winter solstice. The diagram’s reversal and progression, left and right, have been detailed by earlier scholars. *Qian* as one, *Dui* as two, *Li* as three, *Zhen* as four—these are the generated hexagrams, their sequence proceeding from south to north. As for the circulation of hexagram qi, it proceeds from north to south. The first yang arises at the beginning of *Zhen*, thus Master Shao takes the *zi* midpoint of the winter solstice as *Fu*. The eleventh month’s midpoint is the *Xiaohan*, its hexagrams *Kan* and *Zhun*. The twelfth month’s *Chuji* is the *Dahan*, its hexagrams *Zhen*, *Shike*, and *Sui*. The first month’s *Yinchu* is the *Lichun*, its hexagrams *Wu Wang* and *Ming Yi*. The month’s midpoint is the *Yushui*, its hexagrams *Gui*, *Ji Ji*, and *Jia Ren*. The second month’s *Maochu* is the *Jingzhe*, its hexagrams *Feng*, *Li*, and *Ge*. The month’s midpoint is the spring equinox, its hexagrams *Tong Ren* and *Lin*. The third month’s *Chenchu* is the *Qingming*, its hexagrams *Sun*, *Jie*, and *Fu*. The month’s midpoint is the *Guyu*, its hexagrams *Mei*, *Kui*, and *Dui*. The *Sichu* of the fourth month is the *Lixia*, its hexagrams *Lü* and *Tai*. The month’s midpoint is the *Xiaoman*, its hexagrams *Da Xu*, *Xu*, and *Xiao Xu*. The *Wuchu* of the fifth month is the *Mangzhong*, its hexagrams *Da Zhuang*, *Da You*, and *Guai*. At the end of *Qian*, it exchanges with the summer solstice, which is the *wu* midpoint. These thirty-two hexagrams belong to yang and correspond to spring and summer.

The hexagrams *Xun* as five, *Kan* as six, *Gen* as seven, and *Kun* as eight are the ungenerated hexagrams. The diagram proceeds from west to north, but the circulation of hexagram qi begins with the first yin arising at the start of *Xun*, thus the *wu* midpoint of the summer solstice is the beginning. The fifth month’s midpoint is the *Xiazhi*, the sixth month’s *Weichu* is the *Xiaoshu*, its hexagrams *Da Guo*, *Ding*, and *Heng*. The month’s midpoint is the *Dashu*, its hexagrams *Xun*, *Jing*, and *Gu*. The *Shenchu* of the seventh month is the *Liqiu*, its hexagrams *Sheng* and *Song*.

Nine *hui* have 243 *zhang*, completing the cycle. Calculating a *yuan*’s numbers with *zhang*, *hui*, and *tong*: when the nine *hui*’s *tong* numbers are exhausted, the cycle ends. One *zhang* exhausts intercalary fractions; one *hui* exhausts lunar eclipses; one *tong* exhausts new moon fractions; one *yuan* exhausts the six *jia*—this is the *Xuan*’s Way.

chunks.original_text: 月半处暑，则困、未济、解。 八月酉初为白露，其卦为泱、坎、蒙。 月半秋分，则‘师遁。 九月戌初寒露，其卦为咸旅小过。 月半霜降，则渐、赛、艮。 十月亥初立冬，其卦为谦、天否。 月半小雪，则萃、晋、豫。 十一月子初大雪，其卦为观、比、剥。 至坤之末，交冬至焉，即子之半也。 此三．十二卦属阴，以当秋冬。 子至巳，乾兑离震。 六阳月，其节有四，冬至立春春分立夏也。 午至亥，巽坎艮坤。 六阴月，其节亦四，夏至立秋秋分立冬也。 一年八节。 二之计一十六卦，外有十六气。 三之而计，四十八卦，并之则六十四，以当一期之气候。 所以定时成岁，行鬼神成变化也。 今朱子以二至二分举其纲，愚因卦气以推其目。 天原发微卷之十一竟 #1《四库全书》本在此句末多『云』一字。 #2『主』，原作『王』，据《四库全书》本改。 #3『睨』，《四库全书》本作『议』。 #4『示』，《四库全书》本作『荣』。 #5原脱『三百』二字，据《四库全书》本补。 #6〔迭』，原作『巡』，据《四库全书》本改。 #7『旺』，原作『王』，据《四库全书》本改。 #8『一』，原作『二』，据《四库全书》本改。 #9『令』，原作『合』，据《四库全书》本改。 #10『朱』，原作『宋』，据《四库全书》本改。 #11原脱『嗑』字，据《四库全书》本补。 天原发微卷之十二 鲁斋鲍云龙景翔编着虚谷方回万里校正

The month’s midpoint is *Chushu*, its hexagrams *Kun*, *Weiji*, and *Xie*. The eighth month’s *You* beginning is *Bailu*, its hexagrams *Yang*, *Kan*, and *Meng*. The month’s midpoint is the autumn equinox, its hexagrams *Shi* and *Dun*. The ninth month’s *Xu* beginning is *Hanlu*, its hexagrams *Xian*, *Lü*, and *Xiaoguo*. The month’s midpoint is *Shuangjiang*, its hexagrams *Jian*, *Jian*, and *Gen*. The tenth month’s *Hai* beginning is *Lidong*, its hexagrams *Qian* and *Pi*. The month’s midpoint is *Xiaoxue*, its hexagrams *Cui*, *Jin*, and *Yu*. The eleventh month’s *Zi* beginning is *Daxue*, its hexagrams *Guan*, *Bi*, and *Bo*. At the end of *Kun*, it exchanges with the winter solstice, which is the *Zi* midpoint. These thirty-two hexagrams belong to yin and correspond to autumn and winter.

From *Zi* to *Si* are *Qian*, *Dui*, *Li*, and *Zhen*. The six yang months have four solar terms: the winter solstice, *Lichun*, the spring equinox, and *Lixia*. From *Wu* to *Hai* are *Xun*, *Kan*, *Gen*, and *Kun*. The six yin months also have four solar terms: the summer solstice, *Liqiu*, the autumn equinox, and *Lidong*. One year has eight solar terms. Doubling these yields sixteen hexagrams, with sixteen additional qi. Tripling these yields forty-eight hexagrams, and combining them makes sixty-four, corresponding to one cycle of seasonal qi. Thus time is fixed and the year completed, and the movements of ghosts and spirits bring about transformation.

Now Master Zhu* takes the two solstices and two equinoxes to grasp the essentials; I, in my foolishness, have inferred the details through hexagram qi.

*Tianyuan Fawei*, Scroll Eleven, concludes.

chunks.original_text: 盈缩 阳盈六日，又日气盈。 即余分五日四分日之一也。 阴缩六日，又曰朔虚。 即朔空之六，小月也。 一岁共余十二以为闰，先天尊阳也。 言日月五星，皆从天左旋。 后天任卫也。 言日月五星，皆违天右转。 天左旋，日月皆左旋。 日行不及天，月行不及日，数顺理亦顺。 儒者以此说为是，从先天也。 天左旋，日月皆违天右转。 日行迟，月行反速。 历家主此说，以为《易》算，从后天也。 儒者有所不取，姑两存之，以备参考。 《尧典》三百六旬有六日，以闰月定四时成岁。 《书传》日：今年冬至至来年冬至为一期。 一期中问，铃有三百六十六日或三百六十五日有奇。 天与日会於其上而成一岁，凡二十四气，两年相去皆然，虽遇闺月亦同。 日法以□九百四十分乘。 度其周天，度外余四分日之一者，盖以一日九百四十分。 分为四个，二百三十五分，此即一度。 四分中得其一分也。 朱#1子日：气言则三百六十日，朔言则三百五十四日，举气盈朔虚之中数而言，故日三百六十。 自余进退，不过六分。 《尧典》举成数言，故日三百六旬有六日。 胡氏伸日：岁以四时计者，各为日九十四其九十。 以六气计者，各为六十六其六十。 以五行计者，各为日七十二五其七十二。 皆得三百六十。 乾坤二策亦然，是为天数之正。 过此则盈，不及则缩。 盈则阳道常饶，故日行周天之度为一岁。 於三百六十日之外，而岁常余五日强。 缩则阴道常亏，故月行周天之度为一月，而常不足於三十日，此所以有小月而岁余五日强。 积而成岁，所谓十一日弱者是也。 积岁之所奇，三而一五而再十九年而七，天道大备矣。 日月不能无盈缩，作历者不能无差错，故置闺而时定岁成。 《皇极经世》亦以三百六十为率。 一元三百六十运，一．会三百六十世，一运三百六十年，一世三百六十月，一年三百六十日，一月三百六十辰。 阳得三百六十者，六也。 横渠张子日：日月皆是左旋。 其说日：天甚健，一日一夜，一周天三百六十五度四分度之一。 又过一度，日行速健次於天。 一日一夜，周三百六十五度四分度之一，正恰好彼天进一度，则日却成退喊一度。 二日天进二度，日亦退二度。 积至三百六十五日四分日之一，则天所进过之度，又恰周得本数。 而日退之度，亦却退尽本数，遂与天会成一年。 月行迟，一日一夜三百六十五度四分度之一，行不尽比之天，却退了十三度有奇。 朱子日：若以为天是一日一周天为不过，而日不及一度，则四时中星如何解不同。 若如此，则日日一般把甚么做时节定限。 继来灯去，将次午时打三更矣。 今取《月令》疏中两处，说得分明，其他历书都不如此。 今若把天裹说时，只行得三百六十五度四分度之一，若把天外来说，则是一日过了一度。 论日月则在天裹，若是去太虚空裹观，那天自是日日裒得不在旧时处。 又曰：日月皆从角起，日则一日一周，依旧到那角上，天则一周了。 又过角些子，日日累上去，到一年便与日会。 愚按：二先生之说如此，则知天行太过，月行不及，惟日行得其正。 故一年以三百六十日为率。 邵子曰：阳气於三百六十上盈。 一岁日与天会，多五日二百三十五分，为气盈。 一日气盈十三分七厘八丝三忽。
chunks.translated_text:
The Expansion and Contraction of Yang and Yin

Yang expands for six days, also called *qi* expansion. This accounts for the remainder of five and one-quarter days. Yin contracts for six days, also called new moon deficiency. This refers to the six days of lunar emptiness in a short month. Over one year, the total remainder of twelve days is allocated as intercalary months, honoring the supremacy of yang.

This describes the sun, moon, and five planets all revolving leftward with the heavens. The latter system follows the motions of the guards. It describes the sun, moon, and five planets all revolving rightward against the heavens. If the heavens revolve leftward, the sun and moon also revolve leftward. The sun’s motion falls short of the heavens, and the moon’s motion falls short of the sun’s—this sequence follows principle and is thus correct. Confucians regard this explanation as valid, adhering to the *prior heavens*.

If the heavens revolve leftward while the sun and moon revolve rightward against them, the sun moves slowly while the moon moves swiftly. Calendar scholars adopt this explanation for *Yi*-based calculations, adhering to the *posterior heavens*. Confucians do not accept this view but provisionally retain both for reference.

The *Canon of Yao* states: “Three hundred and sixty-six days, with intercalary months to fix the four seasons and complete the year.” The *Book of Documents* commentary says: “From this winter solstice to the next is one cycle. Within this cycle, there are either 366 days or slightly more than 365 days. The heavens and the sun converge above to form one year, comprising twenty-four qi. The interval between two years remains consistent, even when intercalary months occur.”

The *day divisor* is multiplied by 940 parts to measure the celestial circuit. The remainder beyond the full degrees is one-quarter of a day, for a day is divided into 940 parts. Dividing these into four yields 235 parts, which constitutes one degree. Thus, one-quarter of these parts is obtained.

Master Zhu said: “In terms of *qi*, there are 360 days; in terms of lunar phases, there are 354 days. Taking the median of *qi* expansion and lunar deficiency, we speak of 360 days. The remaining variations do not exceed six parts.” The *Canon of Yao* uses round numbers, hence “three hundred and sixty-six days.”

Hu Shenzhen said: “When reckoning the year by the four seasons, each season has ninety-four days and ninety parts. When reckoning by the six *qi*, each has sixty-six days and sixty parts. When reckoning by the five phases, each has seventy-two days and seventy-two parts. All yield 360 days. The two trigrams *Qian* and *Kun* follow the same principle—this is the norm of celestial numbers. Exceeding this is expansion; falling short is contraction.

When expanded, the yang path is ever-abundant, so the sun’s circuit of the celestial degrees constitutes one year. Beyond the 360 days, the year consistently has a remainder of slightly more than five days. When contracted, the yin path is ever-deficient, so the moon’s circuit of the celestial degrees constitutes one month, consistently falling short of thirty days. This is why there are short months and why the year has a remainder of slightly more than five days. Accumulated over the years, this yields the so-called eleven-day deficit. The surplus of accumulated years—once every three years, twice every five, and seven times every nineteen years—completes the great pattern of the heavens.

The sun and moon cannot be without expansion and contraction, and calendar makers cannot avoid discrepancies. Thus, intercalary months are established to stabilize the seasons and complete the year.” The *Supreme Principles Governing the World* also takes 360 as the standard: one *yuan* comprises 360 *yun*, one *hui* comprises 360 *shi*, one *yun* comprises 360 years, one *shi* comprises 360 months, one year comprises 360 days, and one month comprises 360 *chen*. Yang attains 360 through the number six.

Master Zhang of Hengqu said: “The sun and moon both revolve leftward.” His explanation: “The heavens are exceedingly vigorous, completing one circuit of 365¼ degrees in one day and night. They then exceed this by one degree. The sun’s motion, though swift, is secondary to the heavens. In one day and night, it completes 365¼ degrees, precisely matching the heavens’ advance of one degree, which causes the sun to appear to retreat by one degree. Over two days, the heavens advance two degrees, and the sun retreats two degrees. Accumulating over 365¼ days, the heavens’ excess degrees complete a full cycle, and the sun’s retreating degrees also exhaust their original count, reuniting with the heavens to form one year.

The moon moves slowly, completing 365¼ degrees in one day and night but falling short of the heavens by slightly more than thirteen degrees.” Master Zhu said: “If one assumes the heavens complete one circuit daily without excess while the sun falls short by one degree, how can the mid-star positions of the four seasons differ? If this were so, what would define the boundaries of the seasons? As days pass like lamps relayed in succession, noon would soon strike the third watch.”

Here, I cite two passages from the *Monthly Ordinances* commentary that clarify the matter; other calendrical works do not explain it thus. If we consider the heavens’ motion internally, they complete only 365¼ degrees. If we consider them externally, they exceed one degree per day. The sun and moon are discussed within the heavens; if observed from the great void, the heavens themselves are not fixed in their former positions.

He further said: “The sun and moon both begin at *Jiao*. The sun completes one circuit daily, returning to *Jiao*, while the heavens complete one circuit and slightly surpass *Jiao*. This accumulates daily, and after one year, they reunite with the sun.”

In my humble opinion, the explanations of these two masters reveal that the heavens’ motion exceeds, the moon’s falls short, and only the sun’s motion is correct. Thus, one year is reckoned at 360 days. Master Shao said: “Yang *qi* expands upon 360. In one year, the sun’s reunion with the heavens exceeds five days and 235 parts, constituting *qi* expansion. Each day’s *qi* expansion is 13 parts, 7 *li*, 8 *si*, and 3 *hu*.”

chunks.original_text: 两立春相去中间，共四千九百三十五分，合盈五日二百三十五分。 以成数言，天多六日。 日行不及天之数。 朱子曰：天体至圆，周围三百六十五度四分度之一。 绕地左旋，常一日一周而过一度。 日丽天而少迟，故一日亦绕地一周。 而在天为不及一度，积三百六十五日九百四十分日之二百三十五而与天会，是一岁日行之数也。 按：孔氏疏云：天是太虚，本无形体，但指诸星运转，以为天尔。 天包地外，如卵之最黄。 诸星之转，从束而西，铃三百六十五日四分日之一，星复旧处。 星既左转，日则右行，亦三百六十五日四分日之一，至旧星之处。 星即二十八宿，分布四方，是为天体。 每宿计十三度四百二分，总四七之数为三百六十五度四分度之一。 在天为度，在年为日，俱有此数。 但其气数有过与不及，所以有盈亏也。 张诸前说备矣。 愚谓：若使天行无过度与日一般，月行无不及之度，亦与日一般。 日日都到角上，年年都有三百六十日无零数。 既无寒暑不齐，又无日月大小与旱乾水溢。 假使天公装个硬本与人，便不成造化模样矣，岂鬼神福善祸淫之机哉。 又曰：阴气於三百六十上缩。 一月朔虚四百四十一分。 自子至丑，月共五千二百九十二分。 合虚五日五百九十二分，举成数言六日也。 乃月行不及日之数。 朱子曰：月丽天而尤迟一日，常不及天十三度十九分度之七。 积二十九日九百四十分日之四百九十九而与日会。 十二会得全日三百四十八余分之积五千九百八十八。 如日法九百四十而得六，不尽三百四十八，通计得三百五十四日九百四十分。 日之三百四十八，是一岁月行之数也。 愚按：十九分度之七者，以九百四十分分为十九分。 每分计四十九分四厘#2一毫五忽七丝六秒#3比月行一日，不及天与日常度之余分也。 如是，则月行一日，不及日十二度三百四十六分上。 每月积至二十九日四百九十九分上，其不及日者，三百六十五度二百三十五分。 则日所进过之度，恰周得本数。 而月所不及之度，亦退尽本数。 恰恰与日会而成一月，合十二个二十九日。 计全日三百四十八，十二个四百九十九分，积五千九百八十八。 以日法九百四十分除之，得六日零三百四也。 盖阳□ 全阴半，阳常盈，阴常缩，日行常过月，月行常不及日也。 一岁闰以气盈朔虚，总为十日令八百二十七分，举成数为十二日。 以起闰，三岁□ 一闰，积三个十日令八百二十七分，计三十二日令六百一分，成数为三十六日也。 五岁再闰，积五个十日令八百二十七分，计五十四日二百七十五分。 成数为六十日也。 大抵三十二日一闺，虽不尽同，亦不相远。 故圣人作历，归余以裨月行不及日，日行不及天之数。 三者参会而为一，以至二十九年气朔分齐天时，既无毫发之差，而人事亦应时而举矣。 或问天历曰：月之大小，便是一本历书，只要人推算尔。 如初二生明，前月爻是大。 或初三生明，前月叉是小。 如玄乌二月叉来，八月又去。 物亦是如此。 前辈有云… 日月会於晦朔之问。 初一晚最好看，起日才西坠微茫之，月亦随．以坠。 至初二，便相隔微阔。 初三，生明以后，相去渐远。 直至十五日，＂月对望，则是日行速进而远至半天。

Between two *lichun* solar terms, there are in total 4,935 parts, which together constitute the excess of five days and 235 parts. Speaking in whole numbers, the heavens exceed by six days. This is the measure by which the sun’s motion falls short of the heavens.

Master Zhu said: “The celestial body is perfectly round, with a circumference of 365¼ degrees. Revolving leftward around the earth, it completes one full circuit each day while surpassing one degree. The sun, attached to the heavens yet slightly slower, also completes one circuit around the earth daily, but in relation to the heavens, it falls short by one degree. Over 365 days and 940/940 of a day—specifically 235 parts—it reunites with the heavens. This is the measure of the sun’s annual motion.”

According to Kong’s commentary: “The heavens are the great void, inherently formless; we merely designate the revolving stars as ‘heaven.’ The heavens envelop the earth like the white surrounds the yolk. The stars revolve from east to west, completing one cycle in 365¼ days before returning to their original positions. While the stars turn leftward, the sun moves rightward, also taking 365¼ days to return to its original stellar position. These stars are the twenty-eight lunar lodges, distributed across the four directions, forming the celestial body. Each lodge spans 13 degrees and 402 parts, totaling 365¼ degrees. Whether measured in celestial degrees or annual days, the count remains the same. Yet due to the excess or deficiency of *qi*, there arises the waxing and waning of time.” The preceding explanations have thoroughly addressed this.

In my humble opinion: If the heavens’ motion were without excess, matching the sun’s, and the moon’s motion without deficiency, also matching the sun’s—if every day they all returned to *Jiao* and every year consisted of exactly 360 days without remainder—then there would be no irregularity in cold and heat, no variation in the size of days and months, no droughts or floods. Were the heavens to impose such rigid uniformity upon humanity, the workings of creation would lose their pattern. How then could the mechanisms of spirits reward virtue and punish vice operate?

He further said: “Yin *qi* contracts upon 360. Each month’s new moon lacks 441 parts. From *zi* to *chou*, the moon totals 5,292 parts. Together with the deficiency of five days and 592 parts—rounded to six days—this constitutes the measure by which the moon’s motion falls short of the sun’s.”

Master Zhu said: “The moon, attached to the heavens, is even slower. Each day, it falls short of the heavens by 13 degrees and 7/19 of a degree. Over 29 days and 499/940 of a day, it reunites with the sun. Twelve such conjunctions yield 348 full days, with an accumulated remainder of 5,988 parts. Divided by the day divisor of 940, this gives six days and a remainder of 348, totaling 354 days and 348/940 of a day. This is the measure of the moon’s annual motion.”

In my humble analysis: The “7/19 of a degree” means dividing 940 parts into nineteen portions, each portion being 49 parts, 4 *li*, 2 *hao*, 1 *hu*, 5 *si*, 7 *miao*, and 6 *shao*—the daily shortfall by which the moon lags behind the heavens and the sun’s regular motion. Thus, each day, the moon falls short of the sun by 12 degrees and 346 parts. Over 29 days and 499 parts, its accumulated shortfall reaches 365 degrees and 235 parts—the very degrees by which the sun advances. At this point, the sun’s excess precisely completes its full cycle, while the moon’s deficiency is entirely exhausted. They reunite to form one month. Twelve such periods of 29 days yield 348 full days, and twelve accumulations of 499 parts total 5,988. Divided by the day divisor of 940, this results in six days and a remainder of 348.

For yang is whole while yin is half; yang is ever in excess, yin ever in contraction. The sun’s motion constantly surpasses the moon’s, while the moon’s motion constantly falls short of the sun’s. In one year, intercalary days arise from the *qi* excess and new moon deficiency, totaling 10 days and 827 parts—rounded to twelve days. These are used to establish intercalary months. Every three years, one intercalary month is added, accumulating three sets of 10 days and 827 parts—32 days and 601 parts, or thirty-six days in whole numbers. After five years, a second intercalary month is added, accumulating five sets of 10 days and 827 parts—54 days and 275 parts, or sixty days in whole numbers. Generally, an intercalary month occurs every thirty-two days, though not precisely uniform, the variation is not great. Thus, the sages devised the calendar, redistributing the remainders to compensate for the moon’s shortfall relative to the sun and the sun’s shortfall relative to the heavens. By harmonizing these three cycles into one, over twenty-nine years, the *qi*, new moons, and divisions align perfectly with the celestial timing, leaving no discrepancy even as fine as a hair’s breadth. Human affairs, too, proceed in accord with the seasons.

Someone asked about the celestial calendar: “The varying lengths of months are already set in the almanac; one need only calculate them. For instance, if the crescent appears on the second day, the preceding month was long; if on the third, it was short. As the dark bird arrives in the second month and departs in the eighth, so too do things follow this pattern.” An elder once said: “The sun and moon meet between the last and first days of the lunar month. On the first evening, the sight is most splendid: as the sun sets, a faint glow lingers, and the moon follows in its descent. By the second day, they are slightly farther apart. After the third day, as the crescent waxes, the distance gradually increases. By the fifteenth day, when the moon is full and opposite the sun, the sun’s swift motion has carried it halfway across the sky.”

chunks.original_text: 月行不及日，而退亦逮半□ 天矣。 自十六至月晦，日行全远尽一天，月行全不及亦尽一天。 则日进尽本数，月退尽本数，而又复相会。 邵子曰：一岁之闰，六阴六阳。 三年三十六日，故三年一闰。 五年六十日，故五岁再闰。 十九年二百二十八日。 故七闺无余分，历法十九年为一章。 七闰得二百二十八者，闺法所起也。 置闰之法，起於日月之行不齐。 日一日行天一度，月一日行天十三度十九分度之七。 其十三度为一年十二周天之数，余七分则为闰。 故闺法以七与十九相取，以十二乘七得八十四七年之月数以十二乘十九得二百二十八十九年之月数，故年中取月，日中取时。 则又以八十四为七分，以二百二十八为十九分，今自一时积之一日余七分。 以一月三＋日之数乘之，计二百一十分。 十二月则二千五百二十分，每十九分为一时。 年得一百三十二时十一日，余十二不尽。 若以十九年之数乘之，得四万七千八百八十分。 如法除析，每年得一十一日余十二分#4。 尽十九年共得二百九日余二百二十八分，则一日十二时之分数，通为二百十日，故十九年七闰无余分。 今欲求年，年置七分，满十九分而为闺，则知当闰之年。 复以十二月数乘一年之数，年得八十四分，满二百二十八为闰，则知置闺之月。 欲求日，日置闰七分，满十九而得闪一时，则知闰朔之日。 复以十二时之数乘一日之数，得八十四分，满二百二十八分，而得闺一时，则知合朔之时。 七与十九相取者，闰法之粗。 八十四与二百二十八而取者，闰法之密。 闰本奇数．’积於．七满於十九，故七与十九，自相乘除，皆得一百三十三。 月与时法既衍十二以乘，当衍十二以除，故得二百二十八。 其一月之分，一章之日，皆二百一十。 所以《系辞》言归奇於初以象闰。 而先天日数用一百三十三，星数用一百五也。 闰本天之奇数，而以月求之。 故知阳以阴为节，而阴阳相为体用也。 二百二十八而十之，又偶之，则四千五百六十万。 《四分历》一元之数也。 又曰：日以迟为进，月以疾为退。 日月一会，加半日臧半日，是以为闰余。 日一大运而进六日，月一大运而退六日，是以为闰差。 天左旋，日月右转其度数说见前。 月一月一周天，皆为徒行。 其及日者，在最后之一日半，而常在日之后。 故日迟而反为进，月疾而反为退也。 日月三十日一会，实二十九日半。 盖月本二十九日半，日本得三十日半，而皆以为三十日故也。 故一会而日加半日，月喊半日。 加半日者，日一岁本多於月六日，而又加六日。 喊半日者，月一岁本亏於月六日，今又喊六日，以所加喊积之是为闰余也。 日月一大运，进退十二日。 得三年一闺，五年再闰，是为闺差。 八年三闺，十年四闺，十三年五闰，十六年六闰，十九年七闰。 自此推之，往来不穷谓之通。 子云有言：岁宁恙而年病。 岁宁者，数足年安。 岁恙者，年病而闺以偿之也。 朱子曰：闰以中气为定。 中气只在本月，若灯得中气在月尽后，月便当置闰也。 斗指所建为中气，日月所在，斗指两辰之间日月会处。 若无中气，则置为闰。 斗柄左移，日月右转，辰与建常相合也。 周天分界，过宫分秒。 王氏炎曰：以周天度数，分配十二官。

The moon’s motion falls short of the sun’s, yet its retreat also covers half the heavens. From the sixteenth day to the month’s end, the sun’s course fully spans one celestial revolution, while the moon’s shortfall likewise completes one revolution. Thus, the sun advances through its full measure, the moon retreats through its full measure, and they meet again.

Master Shao said: “A year’s intercalation consists of six yin and six yang phases. Three years yield thirty-six days, hence one intercalary month every three years. Five years yield sixty days, hence two intercalary months every five years. Nineteen years yield two hundred twenty-eight days. Thus, seven intercalary months leave no remainder, and the calendar takes nineteen years as one *zhang*. That seven intercalary months yield two hundred twenty-eight days is the origin of the intercalation method.

The method of placing intercalary months arises from the irregular motions of the sun and moon. The sun travels one degree of the heavens per day, while the moon travels thirteen degrees and seven nineteenths of a degree per day. The thirteen degrees account for twelve revolutions of the heavens in one year, while the remaining seven nineteenths form the intercalary fraction. Thus, the intercalation method takes seven and nineteen as its basis: multiplying seven by twelve yields eighty-four, the number of months in seven years; multiplying nineteen by twelve yields two hundred twenty-eight, the number of months in nineteen years. Hence, within a year, one takes months; within a day, one takes hours. Then, taking eighty-four as seven parts and two hundred twenty-eight as nineteen parts, beginning from one hour and accumulating to one day yields a remainder of seven parts. Multiplying this by the thirty days in a month yields two hundred ten parts. Twelve months yield two thousand five hundred twenty parts, with every nineteen parts constituting one hour. A year thus contains one hundred thirty-two hours and eleven days, with a remainder of twelve parts. Multiplying this by the nineteen-year cycle yields forty-seven thousand eight hundred eighty parts. Dividing according to the method, each year yields eleven days and a remainder of twelve parts. Over nineteen years, this totals two hundred nine days and a remainder of two hundred twenty-eight parts, which, when converted into the divisions of a day’s twelve hours, equals two hundred ten days. Thus, nineteen years with seven intercalary months leave no remainder.

To determine the year, set seven parts per year, and when nineteen parts are reached, an intercalary month is added—thus knowing the year to intercalate. Multiplying the twelve months by the number of years yields eighty-four parts per year; when two hundred twenty-eight parts are reached, an intercalary month is added—thus knowing the month to intercalate. To determine the day, set seven intercalary parts per day, and when nineteen parts are reached, one hour of intercalation is gained—thus knowing the day of the intercalary new moon. Multiplying the twelve hours by the number of days yields eighty-four parts; when two hundred twenty-eight parts are reached, one hour of intercalation is gained—thus knowing the time of conjunction.

The mutual reckoning of seven and nineteen is the rough method of intercalation; the mutual reckoning of eighty-four and two hundred twenty-eight is the precise method. Intercalation originates from odd numbers, accumulating to seven and reaching completion at nineteen. Thus, seven and nineteen, when multiplied or divided by each other, both yield one hundred thirty-three. Since the methods for months and hours are derived by multiplying by twelve, they must also be divided by twelve, yielding two hundred twenty-eight. The parts of one month and the days of one *zhang* are both two hundred ten. Hence, the *Xici* speaks of “returning the odd to the beginning to symbolize intercalation,” while the *Xiantian* uses one hundred thirty-three for the number of days and one hundred five for the number of stars.

Intercalation is fundamentally the odd number of heaven, yet it is sought through the moon. Thus, one knows that yang takes yin as its measure, and yin and yang mutually constitute substance and function. Multiplying two hundred twenty-eight by ten and then doubling it yields forty-five million six hundred thousand—the number of one *yuan* in the *Sifen* calendar.

It is also said: the sun advances by slowing, the moon retreats by hastening. When the sun and moon meet, half a day is added and half a day is subtracted, forming the intercalary remainder. The sun advances six days in one great revolution, the moon retreats six days in one great revolution—this is the intercalary difference. The heavens rotate leftward, while the sun and moon revolve rightward; their degrees have been explained earlier. The moon completes one revolution of the heavens each month, yet this is merely its apparent motion. Its actual conjunction with the sun occurs in the final day and a half, always trailing behind the sun. Thus, the sun, though slow, is deemed to advance, while the moon, though swift, is deemed to retreat.

The sun and moon meet every thirty days, though in reality it is twenty-nine and a half days. For the moon’s true period is twenty-nine and a half days, while the sun’s is thirty and a half days, yet both are reckoned as thirty days. Thus, at each conjunction, the sun gains half a day, and the moon loses half a day. The gain of half a day arises because the sun’s yearly course exceeds the moon’s by six days, and an additional six days are added. The loss of half a day arises because the moon’s yearly course falls short of the sun’s by six days, and an additional six days are subtracted. The accumulation of these gains and losses forms the intercalary remainder.

In one great revolution, the sun and moon advance and retreat by twelve days, yielding one intercalary month every three years and two intercalary months every five years—this is the intercalary difference. Three intercalary months in eight years, four in ten years, five in thirteen years, six in sixteen years, and seven in nineteen years. Extending this reckoning endlessly is called *tong*.

Master Zi said: “The year is at peace, yet the *nian* is afflicted.” The year is at peace when its reckoning is complete; the *nian* is afflicted when its reckoning is deficient, and intercalation compensates for it.

Master Zhu said: “Intercalation is determined by the central qi. The central qi belongs to its own month; if it falls after the month’s end, that month is to be intercalated.” The Dipper’s pointer indicates the central qi; the positions of the sun and moon, where the Dipper’s pointer lies between two celestial markers, is the place of their conjunction. If there is no central qi, the month is intercalated. As the Dipper’s handle shifts leftward and the sun and moon revolve rightward, the celestial markers and the established months remain in constant alignment.

The heavens are divided by boundaries, passing through the degrees and minutes of the palaces. Master Wang Yan said: “Using the degrees of the celestial revolution, one allocates them among the twelve palaces.”
