The initial line is the qi of earth, the root of life. In the *Precelestial Chart*, the thirty-two yang and thirty-two yin lines that remain unchanged are the initial lines left unused. The top line is the spirit of heaven, the origin of nature. Thus, the eight pure hexagrams evolve through five generations to become the "wandering soul" of heaven, and the top line of the *Yijing* does not move.

Master Shao said: The *Yijing* possesses variable numbers, and hexagrams possess variable images. Heaven’s number contains three; doubling three makes six, and tripling three makes nine. Nine times nine is eighty-one, the extreme of yang numbers. At its extreme, yang transforms into yin. Earth’s two doubled makes four, and four times four is sixty-four, the extreme of yin numbers. At its extreme, yin transforms into yang.

There are hexagram transformations: one change yields three—*Qian* transforms into *Zhen*, *Kan*, and *Gen*; *Kun* transforms into *Xun*, *Li*, and *Dui*. One change yields eight—*Qian* shifts from *Gou* to *Tai*, and *Kun* shifts from *Bo* to *Pi*. Among the hexagrams of the three outer sons and three outer daughters, one shares the same variable hexagrams, as observed through the casting of yarrow stalks. Obtaining the two elders’ nine-six changes results in *Qian* and *Kun*. Obtaining the two youths’ seven-eight unchanged lines results in *Zhen*, *Kan*, *Gen*, *Xun*, *Li*, and *Dui*.

There are line transformations: for example, *Kun* changes one line to become *Fu*, and when all six lines change, it becomes *Qian*. Another method involves the mutual ascent of one yang line as a transformation, yielding *Fu*, *Shi*, *Jian*, *Yu*, *Bi*, and *Bo*. There are also transformations of two yang lines, comprising fifteen hexagrams, all derived from *Lin*. Transformations of three yang lines comprise ten hexagrams, all derived from *Tai*.

*Qian* changes one line to become *Gou*, and when all six lines change, it becomes *Kun*. Another method involves the mutual transformation of one yin line, generating *Gou*, *Fu*, *Lü*, *Xiaoxu*, and *Dayou*. There are also transformations of two yin lines, comprising fifteen hexagrams, all derived from *Dun*. Transformations of three yin lines comprise ten hexagrams, all derived from *Pi*. These describe transformations of lines and hexagrams.

The eight trigrams’ transformations, eight times eight, culminate in sixty-four. The sixty-four hexagrams’ transformations, sixty-four times sixty-four, culminate in four thousand ninety-six hexagrams. By extrapolating hexagram lines, these are twelve-line hexagrams. Extending to twenty-four lines yields seventeen million seven hundred seventy-seven thousand two hundred sixteen hexagrams.

Furthermore, in the *Precelestial Chart*, one change yields two hexagrams, two changes yield four, three changes yield eight, four changes yield sixteen, five changes yield thirty-two, and six changes complete the sixty-four hexagrams. The square and circular *Precelestial Charts* correspond precisely. Thus, Master Shao states below: "Changes within correspond to responses without; changes without correspond to responses within. Changes below correspond to responses above; changes above correspond to responses below."

*Xun*, *Li*, and *Dui* with twenty-eight yang lines correspond to *Kan*, *Gen*, and *Zhen*’s twenty-eight yin lines. *Kan*, *Gen*, and *Zhen*’s twenty yang lines correspond to *Xun*, *Li*, and *Dui*’s twenty yin lines. *Qian*, *Dui*, *Xun*, and *Kan* occupy the upper position, while *Li*, *Zhen*, *Gen*, and *Kun* occupy the lower. *Qian*, *Dui*, *Li*, and *Zhen* are internal, while *Xun*, *Kan*, *Gen*, and *Kun* are external. As yang wanes and yin waxes, each hexagram mirrors the other, and there is no change without correspondence.

Change follows heaven. Heaven moves leftward, and the sun shifts one degree; the response follows the sun’s daily rightward movement, with heaven responding one degree. All correspond left and right. The sun’s path is marked by stars—*Qian* and *Li*; the moon meets the celestial stems—*Dui* and *Zhen*; fire arises from earth—*Kun* and *Kan*; fire lies hidden in stone—*Gen* and *Xun*. All correspond above and below.

Flying creatures perch on trees—*Li* and *Gen*; walking creatures rely on grass—*Zhen* and *Kun*; heart and lungs connect—*Qian* and *Xun*; liver and gallbladder adjoin—*Dui* and *Kan*. All correspond internally and externally. Thus, in the *Yijing*’s six lines, the first and fourth correspond, the second and fifth correspond, and the third and sixth correspond, always in opposition.

Heaven and earth envelop each other; the female and male summon one another. Heaven is yang, earth is yin; heaven’s pitch corresponds to earth’s tone. Heaven’s voice initiates, and earth responds. *Qian*, *Dui*, *Li*, and *Zhen* reside in the northwest, initiating earth’s sixteen hexagrams—five, six, seven, eight—in the southeast. They further intersect with the sixteen hexagrams of the southwest—*Pi*, *Dun*, *Song*, and *Shi*—constituting the transformations of heat and cold, day and night, the natures and forms of walking, flying, and plant life. The sixteen hexagrams of movement combine to form two hundred fifty-six hexagrams, their positions aligning with thirty-four changes. All successes and failures, virtues and flaws of animals arise from this.

Earth’s tone harmonizes with heaven. *Kun*, *Gen*, *Kan*, and *Xun* reside in the southeast, harmonizing with heaven’s sixteen hexagrams—one, two, three, four—in the northwest. They further intersect with the sixteen hexagrams of the northeast—*Tai*, *Lin*, *Yi*, *Fu*—constituting the transformations of rain, wind, dew, and thunder, the natures and forms of walking, flying, and plant life. The sixteen hexagrams of vegetation combine to form two hundred fifty-six hexagrams, their positions aligning with thirty-one changes. All flourishing and withering, blossoming and fruiting of plants arise from this.

The hexagrams of the southwest, observed from left to right, pertain to animals. Animals’ lives reside in the head, attached to heaven, with yang arising below. Among the thirty-two hexagrams below, all lines face upward—life resides above. Thus, humans’ heads are above, while birds and beasts are born horizontally. The hexagrams of the northeast, observed from top to bottom, pertain to plants. Plants’ lives reside in the roots, attached to earth, with yin arising above. Among the thirty-two hexagrams above, all lines face downward—life resides below. Thus, humans’ kidneys are below, while grasses and trees grow inverted.

Then, pairing them with the hexagrams of sound: the voices of the sun, moon, and stars belong to heaven’s one hundred twelve hexagrams. The tones of water, fire, earth, and stone belong to earth’s one hundred fifty-two hexagrams.

It is also said: Heaven and earth undergo sixteen changes, totaling six hundred seventy-two divisions of waxing and waning. Heaven’s eight leftward changes, from *Zi* to *Si*, constitute daytime, with three hundred thirty-six as the number of growth.
chunks.overlap_context: the middle lines is because heaven and earth do not generate beings at dawn and dusk but do at midday, and earth’s north and south do not generate beings but do at midday. If *Li* were not preserved, the four yang lines would have no way to receive *Kun*’s yin. If *Kan* were not preserved, the four yin lines would have no way to accept *Qian*’s yang. Thus each excludes four to establish form. Excluding four means they are constantly preserved yet unused, while two hundred fifty-six are employed.

chunks.original_text: 地右八变，自午至亥为夜，三百三十六．为数之消。 共二八一十六变，天统乎体，八变而终于十六。 以乾为主，自央而行，两卦当一变，同人当八变，娠当十六变。 天地各分A 变，各得数三百三十六者，五十六卦之爻数也。 八八六十四卦，除去乾坤坎离大小过中乎颐二十四爻。 二十四而十二，即阳之数赢六日。 右六阴月一百八十日卦，去坤坎大小过二十四爻。 爻二十四而十二，即阴之数缩六日也。 共去二十四，所以有三百三十六，合为六百七十二分消长也。 又为七六五四之变。 八卦生数，乾一兑二离三震四巽五坎六艮七坤八。 蔡氏曰：阳之生阴，二而六之为十二。 阴之生阳，三而十之为三十。 是乾始一而兑为十二，离则十二而三十为三百六十，震则十二而为四千三百二十。 自巽而坤，皆奇偶之生数，厘之於二十四卦，以所生之数而相乘，知其总数也。 兑之震，则为十五万五千五百二十之数。 愚尝砍之矣。 阳一为奇，阴二为偶。 是以一元之数起於乾，为起数之端，犹一岁包年月日时而为之也。 乾之后有兑。 兑为月，其数二。 衍之为十二，一岁有十二月也。 兑之后有离。 离为日，其数三。 衍之为三百六十，一岁有三百六十日也。 离之后有震。 震为时，其数四。 衍之为四千三百二十，一岁有四千三百二十时也。 此一二三四，为天地生物之始数，阳之所以先一阴也。 震四之后，继以巽五。 阴元之气，莫先於此。 是为巽元之年数，衍之为十二万九千六百，为起数之端。 坎六继之，是为巽元之月数。 衍之为一百五十五万五千二百月。 艮七又继之，是为巽元之日数，衍之为四千六百六十五万六千日。 若夫巽之时数，则居之坤八焉。 又衍之而得五万五千九百八十七万二千时。 此五六七八，又天地成物之终数，阴之所以承乎阳也。 由是重而衍之，以至於八，则乾之世数四千三百二十，衍之为五万五千九百八十七万二千。 兑之世数五万一千八百四十，衍之为六十七万一千八百四十六万四千。 循序而推，皆可栗见。 大抵乾兑离震之数，包巽坎艮坤在其中。 自子至巳上六辰皆属乾，谓之先天。 自午至亥下六辰皆属坤，谓之后天。 后天皆效先天而为之也。 故曰：成象之谓乾，效法之谓坤，可举隅而知之也。 十二与三十互用。 岁月十二，即岁之一而十二之。 岁日三百六十，即十二而三十之。 岁时四千三百二十，即三百六十而十二之。 世岁三#34 十，即岁之一而三十之。 世月三百六十，即世数而三十#35之。 世日万八百，即世日而三十之。 世时十二万九千六百，即世日#36而十二之。 十二辰十二次，其数即三四二六。 两其十二，而三八四六。 阴数二衍为十二，十二支十二时十二月十二世十二卦。 坤有十二画，人有十二物，所以地数起于十二。 十二辰者，辰数月数也。 自子至巳为阳，自午至亥为阴。 二六也，以生成而分。 自子至戌为阳，自丑至亥为阴，亦二六也。 以奇偶分二六，十二阴阳各半，析一为二，分其十二也。 四三十二者，四时各三析二为四，又分其二六也。 二十四者，气数十二月也。 八节者，一节而三气。 四时者，一时而六气者。 先天一官八卦之爻，各止四十八者，分四方立体应乎四行也。

Earth’s eight rightward changes, from *Wu* to *Hai*, constitute night, with three hundred thirty-six as the number of waning. Together, the two eights make sixteen changes. Heaven governs the body, its eight changes culminating in sixteen. With *Qian* as the master, proceeding from *Yang* onward, two hexagrams correspond to one change, *Tongren* to eight changes, and *Shen* to sixteen changes.

Heaven and earth each divide into eight changes, each yielding the number three hundred thirty-six—the total line count of fifty-six hexagrams. Of the sixty-four hexagrams, excluding *Qian*, *Kun*, *Kan*, *Li*, *Daguo*, *Xiaoguo*, *Zhongfu*, and *Yi*, twenty-four lines remain. Dividing twenty-four by two yields twelve, which is the surplus of six days in the yang count. For the six yin months, totaling one hundred eighty days, excluding the twenty-four lines of *Kun*, *Kan*, *Daguo*, and *Xiaoguo*, twenty-four lines remain. Dividing twenty-four by two yields twelve, which is the deficit of six days in the yin count. Together, the twenty-four lines excluded account for the three hundred thirty-six, combining into six hundred seventy-two divisions of waxing and waning. This also corresponds to the changes of seven, six, five, and four.

The generative numbers of the eight trigrams: *Qian* as one, *Dui* as two, *Li* as three, *Zhen* as four, *Xun* as five, *Kan* as six, *Gen* as seven, *Kun* as eight.

Master Cai states: Yang generates yin, two multiplied by six becomes twelve. Yin generates yang, three multiplied by ten becomes thirty. Thus, *Qian* begins with one, and *Dui* becomes twelve; *Li* becomes twelve and thirty, totaling three hundred sixty; *Zhen* becomes twelve and four thousand three hundred twenty. From *Xun* to *Kun*, all are the generative numbers of odd and even. Applying these to the twenty-four hexagrams and multiplying their generative numbers reveals the total sum. From *Dui* to *Zhen*, the number reaches one hundred fifty-five thousand five hundred twenty. I have calculated this before.

Yang, as one, is odd; yin, as two, is even. Thus, the number of one *yuan* begins with *Qian*, the origin of all counts, just as one year encompasses years, months, days, and hours. After *Qian* comes *Dui*. *Dui* represents the moon, its number two. Expanded, it becomes twelve—one year has twelve months. After *Dui* comes *Li*. *Li* represents the sun, its number three. Expanded, it becomes three hundred sixty—one year has three hundred sixty days. After *Li* comes *Zhen*. *Zhen* represents the hours, its number four. Expanded, it becomes four thousand three hundred twenty—one year has four thousand three hundred twenty hours. These one, two, three, and four are the primordial numbers of heaven and earth’s creation, where yang precedes yin by one.

After *Zhen* four comes *Xun* five. Nothing precedes this as the primordial qi of yin. This is the year count of *Xun Yuan*, expanded to one hundred twenty-nine thousand six hundred, the origin of all counts. *Kan* six follows, representing the month count of *Xun Yuan*, expanded to one million five hundred fifty-five thousand two hundred months. *Gen* seven follows, representing the day count of *Xun Yuan*, expanded to forty-six million six hundred fifty-six thousand days. As for the hour count of *Xun*, it resides in *Kun* eight, further expanded to fifty-five million nine hundred eighty-seven thousand two hundred hours. These five, six, seven, and eight are the concluding numbers of heaven and earth’s completion, where yin follows yang.

Thus, layering and expanding these to eight: *Qian*’s world count is four thousand three hundred twenty, expanded to fifty-five million nine hundred eighty-seven thousand two hundred. *Dui*’s world count is fifty-one thousand eight hundred forty, expanded to six hundred seventy-one million eight hundred forty-six thousand four hundred. Proceeding in order, all can be clearly discerned. Generally, the numbers of *Qian*, *Dui*, *Li*, and *Zhen* encompass those of *Xun*, *Kan*, *Gen*, and *Kun*. From *Zi* to *Si*, the six upper branches belong to *Qian*, called *xiantian* (Prior Heaven). From *Wu* to *Hai*, the six lower branches belong to *Kun*, called *houtian* (Posterior Heaven). Posterior Heaven emulates Prior Heaven. Thus it is said: "Forming the image is called *Qian*; emulating the model is called *Kun*." One may infer the rest from this.

Twelve and thirty are used interchangeably. The twelve months of a year arise from one year multiplied by twelve. The three hundred sixty days of a year arise from twelve multiplied by thirty. The four thousand three hundred twenty hours of a year arise from three hundred sixty multiplied by twelve. The thirty *shi* of a world arise from one *shi* multiplied by thirty. The three hundred sixty months of a world arise from the world count multiplied by thirty. The ten thousand eighty days of a world arise from the world’s days multiplied by thirty. The one hundred twenty-nine thousand six hundred hours of a world arise from the world’s days multiplied by twelve.

The twelve branches and twelve stations correspond to the numbers three, four, two, and six. Doubling twelve yields three, eight, four, and six. The yin number two expands to twelve: twelve branches, twelve hours, twelve months, twelve worlds, twelve hexagrams. *Kun* has twelve lines; humans have twelve components—thus earth’s numbers begin with twelve. The twelve branches are the branch numbers and month numbers. From *Zi* to *Si* is yang; from *Wu* to *Hai* is yin—this is two sixes, divided by generation and completion. From *Zi* to *Xu* is yang; from *Chou* to *Hai* is yin—this is also two sixes, divided by odd and even. Twelve yin and yang each form half, splitting one into two and dividing the twelve. Four threes and two sixes: the four seasons each split into three, further dividing the two sixes. Twenty-four corresponds to the twelve qi of the months. Eight nodes: one node has three qi. Four seasons: one season has six qi.

The lines of the eight trigrams in Prior Heaven’s one palace each total forty-eight, divided among the four directions to correspond to the four phases.

chunks.original_text: 中虚十二为土，以应四方。 在甲子则存十二，在着则卦一，在坤则余十二阳，在乾则余十二阴。 四十八者，十二也。 去十二而用三十六为老阳。 自寅至戌，三用而一不用二十四者，去四六而用四六为老阴。 自卯至申去六用六各半也。 二十八者，去四五用四七。 三十二者，去四四用四八。 或自寅中至戌中，或当自卯至酉用者，常多於不用为乾坤进退之间。 此十二数，日分昼夜，月分跳纳。 进十二日则阳赢，退十二日则阴缩。 赢则气之余分六为百二十，缩则气之虚分六亦百二十。 进退六日，进退六十日，亦偶之而二十四，故用二百四十二、二百五十二、二百六十四。 一年六十甲子，小则六时，大则六日。 又大用六十年，皆十二也。 故曰：六甲而天道穷，月三十日用中也。 中问半日，为日月之合。 除闺亦合一官之数，只是无人曾说来。 乾用九，坤用六。 乾坤进退於七八九六之中。 体四用六，乾坤包乎体用。 故三十六以四变则四九，以六变则六六。 二十四以四变则四六，以六变则六四。 若二十八与三十二，以四变而已，不能以六变也。 自用言之，四六二十四，极阴也。 进六为三十而阳中，又进六为三十六而阳极。 六六三十六，极阳也。 退六为三十而阴中，又退六为二十四而阴极。 自体言之，六四二十四，极阴也。 进四为二十八，又进四为三十二，又进四为三十六而阳老。 九四三十六，极阳也。 退四三十二，又退四二十八，又退四二十四而阴老矣。 惟乾坤进退，独能会于七八九六之中。 为阴阳二老而加用也。 六子不能以六变，故不言用。 阳生阴中，自六进至九，而老阴生阳中。 自九退至六，而老二老之变，皆不离乎四象。 故以四而加於九八七六之上，得其体数之四矣。 又於体中而推其用焉，则日三十六也，三十二也，二十八也，二十四也。 《易》有六十四卦，六十以应六甲，四卦以应四时。 二老二少，虽各有攸司，然阴终不可以先乎阳。 乾本六阳数，又能兼坤半以为九。 三三而九，九九八十一。 此老阳之数，所以始於三而极於九。 而老阴二少之数，皆其中之节目云尔。 故曰：以一气之体统言，则谓之乾而无不包者此也。 大《易》两其十八以分经，共成三十六。 文王序之，孔子翼之，示人至矣。 自汉以来，未有能言之者。 经世两其二六以分运，共成三百六十数。 大小二运，六进六退，年月日#37时上见之。 张观物曰：数法十有二，本於阴阳气数而分。 三百八十四，体数也。 三百六十，用数也。 十用七，十二用八，交数也。 阳嬴六，阴缩六，余数也。 一三五七九，二四六八十，奇偶之数也。 长数者，长小为大，复至乾也。 分数者，分大为小，娠至坤也。 又分乾一爻，降为六卦。 大有小畜履同人#38娠者，乾之象也。 因数者，二因十二而常终于二，三因三进于三十而常终于六。 #39析数者，析一而二，二而四，四四而十六也。 除数者，消数也。 乘数者，长数也。 如以阴乘阳，阳乘阴，三百六十乘三百六十，得一十一万九千六百为一元之类是也。 又曰：卦有由用之体，即体之用。 由用之体者，由一阴一阳为二阴二阳，二阴二阳为四阴四阳。 四而八，合之则十二阴十二阳。 《先天图》外八卦由八而下，八阳间八阴，八而十六。

The central void of twelve corresponds to earth, aligning with the four directions. In *Jiazi*, it holds twelve; in *Zhouyi*, one hexagram; in *Kun*, twelve yang remain; in *Qian*, twelve yin remain. Forty-eight is twelve. Subtract twelve and use thirty-six as old yang. From *Yin* to *Xu*, three are used and one unused—twenty-four: remove four sixes and use four sixes as old yin. From *Mao* to *Shen*, remove six and use six, each half. Twenty-eight: remove four fives and use four sevens. Thirty-two: remove four fours and use four eights. Whether from the middle of *Yin* to the middle of *Xu*, or from *Mao* to *You*, the used always exceeds the unused, marking the advance and retreat of *Qian* and *Kun*. These twelve numbers divide day and night, and the moon’s waxing and waning. Advancing twelve days, yang gains; retreating twelve days, yin contracts. When yang gains, the surplus of qi divides six into one hundred twenty; when yin contracts, the deficiency of qi also divides six into one hundred twenty. Six days advance, sixty days advance—paired, they make twenty-four—hence the use of two hundred forty-two, two hundred fifty-two, and two hundred sixty-four. One year has sixty *Jiazi*; small, it is six hours; large, six days. Even larger, sixty years—all twelve. Thus it is said: "Six *Jia* exhaust the heavenly Dao," and the moon uses thirty days as its mean. The midpoint of half a day is the conjunction of sun and moon. Excluding intercalary months also aligns with the numbers of one palace—though none have spoken of this before. *Qian* uses nine, *Kun* uses six. *Qian* and *Kun* advance and retreat within seven, eight, nine, and six. The body is four, the function six; *Qian* and *Kun* encompass both body and function. Thus thirty-six, transformed by four, becomes four nines; transformed by six, six sixes. Twenty-four, transformed by four, becomes four sixes; transformed by six, six fours. As for twenty-eight and thirty-two, they transform only by four and cannot transform by six.

From the perspective of function: four sixes make twenty-four, the extreme of yin. Advancing six makes thirty, the middle of yang; advancing another six makes thirty-six, the extreme of yang. Six sixes make thirty-six, the extreme of yang. Retreating six makes thirty, the middle of yin; retreating another six makes twenty-four, the extreme of yin. From the perspective of body: six fours make twenty-four, the extreme of yin. Advancing four makes twenty-eight, then another four makes thirty-two, then another four makes thirty-six, old yang. Nine fours make thirty-six, the extreme of yang. Retreating four makes thirty-two, then another four twenty-eight, then another four twenty-four, old yin. Only *Qian* and *Kun* can advance and retreat, uniquely converging within seven, eight, nine, and six—used as the two elders of yin and yang. The six children cannot transform by six, so their use is not discussed.

Yang arises within yin, advancing from six to nine; old yin arises within yang. Retreating from nine to six, the changes of the two elders never depart from the four images. Thus, adding four to nine, eight, seven, and six yields the body’s numbers of four. Further deducing function from within the body, we have thirty-six, thirty-two, twenty-eight, and twenty-four. The *Yi* has sixty-four hexagrams: sixty correspond to the six *Jia*, and four to the four seasons. The two elders and two youths each have their offices, yet yin can never precede yang. *Qian* is originally the number of six yangs, yet it can also incorporate half of *Kun* to become nine. Three threes make nine; nine nines, eighty-one. This is the number of old yang, beginning at three and culminating at nine. The numbers of old yin and the two youths are but nodes within it. Thus it is said: speaking of the body of one qi, it is called *Qian*, encompassing all.

The great *Yi* doubles its eighteen to divide the classic, totaling thirty-six. King Wen ordered it, Confucius aided it—revealing the utmost to humanity. Since the Han, none have been able to expound it. The *Jingshi* text doubles its two sixes to divide the epochs, totaling three hundred sixty. The great and small epochs, six advances and six retreats, manifest in years, months, days, and hours.

Zhang Guanwu said: The numerical method of twelve originates from the qi numbers of yin and yang, then divides. Three hundred eighty-four is the number of the body; three hundred sixty, the number of function. Ten uses seven, twelve uses eight—these are intersecting numbers. Yang gains six, yin contracts six—these are surplus numbers. One, three, five, seven, nine; two, four, six, eight, ten—these are the numbers of odd and even. Long numbers extend the small to the great, returning to *Qian*. Fractional numbers divide the great into the small, gestating into *Kun*. Further dividing one line of *Qian* descends into six hexagrams: *Dayou*, *Xiaoxu*, *Lü*, *Tongren*, and *Dun*—these are the images of *Qian*.

Multiplying numbers: two multiplied by twelve always ends at two; three multiplied by three advances to thirty, always ending at six. Dividing numbers: divide one into two, two into four, four into sixteen. Subtracting numbers are diminishing numbers. Multiplying numbers are extending numbers. For example, yin multiplying yang, yang multiplying yin—three hundred sixty multiplied by three hundred sixty—yields one hundred nineteen thousand six hundred, as in one *yuan*.

It is also said: Hexagrams have a body derived from function, and function derived from body. The body derived from function begins with one yin and one yang, becoming two yins and two yangs, then four yins and four yangs. Four becomes eight, combining into twelve yins and twelve yangs. In the *Prior Heaven Diagram*, the outer eight hexagrams descend from eight: eight yangs interspersed with eight yins, eight becoming sixteen.

chunks.original_text: 十六阴问十六阳，十六而三十二。 三十二阴间三十二阳，三十二而六十四。 一百九十二阳八十阴，一百九十二阴八十阳。 合而论之，则内官之左六十四阳三十二阴，右亦六十四阴三十二阳。 上官左右，则各有四十八阳四十八阴也。 即体而之用，由六十四而三十二，三十二而十六，十六而八，八而四，四而二，二而一。 一者，太极也。 太极、两仪、四象、八卦之分也。 邵子曰：天地之体数四，用者三，不用者一。 又曰：天四变含地四变。 天地各有四卦，八者四而已。 天圆以用为主，体则统乎地。 地方以体为主，用则从乎天。 天裁四为三，以三为用。 地析一为四，以四为体。 自寅至戌，三用一不用者，老阳四九也。 自卯至申，半用半不用者，老阴四六也。 四四一十六位，形有四方，气有四时，天有四象。 变为寒暑昼夜，含地四象，化为雨风露雷，天足以包地也。 天重三则六，六从一起。 并本则七，去本则六。 故阳常存一以主进，进之为三十六。 地二．用十二，十二从四起。 并本则十六，去本则十二。 故阴#40常晦一以主退，退#41十二月消十二日也。 是故天之大极#42从地而右转，地之元气从天而左行。 又曰：三即三十，一一即二六。 举一岁阴阳之气数言之也。 一岁四时，一时三月，一月三旬。 从天用干，则五日一候，三五一十五日为一气。 从地用支，则六日一分，三四一十二时为一日。 大则一年，统三百六十日，自三十日而分。 小则一月，．统三百六十时，自三十分而积。 日一变三十，一会三十运，一世三十年。 三十个十二时为一月，十二个三十日为一岁，三十个十二月为一世，十二个三十岁为一运，三十个十二世为一会，十二个三十运为一元。 又曰：天六变生三百六十，此运行之数也。 一变生六，再变生十二，三变而十八，四变而二十四，五变而三#43 十，六变而三十六。 於是进而为三百六十。 天运行之数，以一为本。 以一用六，无藉乎地。 一变六十，六变三百六十，此以天地而言也。 五生六者，一月五卦，一卦六爻。 以五乘六，五六□ 三十#44 也。 除四正卦外，一年卦有六十，六六三百六十爻。 一年周六十甲子，亦六六三百六十日也。 一变生六，去一则五，五以一为本。 二变生十二，去二则十，十以二为本。 以至三变四变五变六变，皆去其三四五六，以存其本，而得十五#45二十、二十五、三十之数也。 故曰：五六生三#46 十。 三十卦，当天之六变，而得一百八十。 《 先天图》 左右皆然，各有五变，而生三十二阳三十二阴。 五六递交，奇偶相配，此五六所以为天地之中数。 四时运行，无往而不与之合。 以十二支数卦，以六日一变。 以十干数候，以五日一变。 六十变而三百六十生焉。 以三百六十乘三百六十，得一元十二万九千六百之数。 又曰：地四变而生三十六，生物之数也。 四生十二，十二生二十，二十生二十八，二十八生三十六，於是进而为二百五十六。 地生物之数，以四为本，以二用十。 二析一为四，析四为十六，析十六为六十四，析六十四为二百五十六，此地之四变也。 十六者，地之四。 一变为四者，地之一。 四生八者，一四生二四，并之则为三四一十二。

Sixteen yins interspersed with sixteen yangs, sixteen becoming thirty-two. Thirty-two yins interspersed with thirty-two yangs, thirty-two becoming sixty-four. One hundred ninety-two yangs with eighty yins, one hundred ninety-two yins with eighty yangs. Taken together, the left side of the inner palace has sixty-four yangs and thirty-two yins, while the right side likewise has sixty-four yins and thirty-two yangs. In the upper palace, left and right each have forty-eight yangs and forty-eight yins. From body to function: from sixty-four to thirty-two, thirty-two to sixteen, sixteen to eight, eight to four, four to two, two to one. The One is the Supreme Polarity. This is the division of the Supreme Polarity, the Two Modes, the Four Images, and the Eight Trigrams.

Master Shao said: The body of Heaven and Earth has the number four, its function is three, and what is not used is one. He also said: Heaven’s four transformations contain Earth’s four transformations. Heaven and Earth each have four trigrams; the eight are merely four. Heaven is round and takes function as its master, while its body is subsumed under Earth. Earth is square and takes body as its master, while its function follows Heaven. Heaven pares four down to three, taking three as its function. Earth splits one into four, taking four as its body. From *yin* to *xu*, three are used and one is not—this is the old yang of four nines. From *mao* to *shen*, half are used and half are not—this is the old yin of four sixes. Four times four makes sixteen positions. Forms have the four directions, *qi* has the four seasons, and Heaven has the Four Images. Their transformations become cold and heat, day and night; containing Earth’s Four Images, they transform into rain, wind, dew, and thunder. Heaven is sufficient to envelop Earth. Heaven’s three doubled makes six, and six arises from one. Including the root makes seven; excluding the root makes six. Thus yang always preserves one to govern advance, advancing to thirty-six. Earth’s two uses twelve, and twelve arises from four. Including the root makes sixteen; excluding the root makes twelve. Thus yin always obscures one to govern retreat, retreating twelve months to diminish twelve days.

Therefore, the great ultimate of Heaven turns rightward from Earth, while the primordial *qi* of Earth moves leftward from Heaven. It is also said: Three is thirty, and one-one is two sixes. This speaks of the numerical reckoning of yin and yang *qi* in one year. One year has four seasons, one season has three months, and one month has three decades. Following Heaven’s function with the heavenly stems: five days make one *hou*, and three *hou* (fifteen days) make one *qi*. Following Earth’s function with the earthly branches: six days make one *fen*, and three *fen* (twelve hours) make one day. In the large, one year encompasses three hundred sixty days, divided from thirty days. In the small, one month encompasses three hundred sixty hours, accumulated from thirty *fen*. One day transforms into thirty, one *hui* has thirty *yun*, and one *shi* has thirty years. Thirty twelve-hour periods make one month, twelve thirty-day periods make one year, thirty twelve-month periods make one *shi*, twelve thirty-year periods make one *yun*, thirty twelve-*shi* periods make one *hui*, and twelve thirty-*yun* periods make one *yuan*.

It is also said: Heaven’s six transformations generate three hundred sixty—this is the number of its movement. One transformation generates six, two transformations generate twelve, three transformations generate eighteen, four transformations generate twenty-four, five transformations generate thirty, and six transformations generate thirty-six. Thereupon, advancing to three hundred sixty. The number of Heaven’s movement takes one as its root. Using one with six requires no reliance on Earth. One transformation is sixty, and six transformations are three hundred sixty—this is spoken in terms of Heaven and Earth. Five generates six: one month has five trigrams, and one trigram has six lines. Five multiplied by six—five sixes—makes thirty. Excluding the four cardinal trigrams, one year has sixty trigrams, and six sixes make three hundred sixty lines. One year completes sixty *jiazi* cycles, also six sixes making three hundred sixty days. One transformation generates six; subtract one to make five, and five takes one as its root. Two transformations generate twelve; subtract two to make ten, and ten takes two as its root. Extending to three, four, five, and six transformations, always subtract their three, four, five, or six to preserve the root, yielding the numbers fifteen, twenty, twenty-five, and thirty. Thus it is said: Five sixes generate thirty. Thirty trigrams correspond to Heaven’s six transformations, yielding one hundred eighty. In the *Prior Heaven Diagram*, left and right are alike, each having five transformations generating thirty-two yangs and thirty-two yins. Five and six alternate, odd and even pair, and thus five and six are the central numbers of Heaven and Earth. The movement of the four seasons goes nowhere without harmonizing with them.

Counting trigrams with the twelve branches, one transformation occurs every six days. Counting *hou* with the ten stems, one transformation occurs every five days. Sixty transformations generate three hundred sixty. Three hundred sixty multiplied by three hundred sixty yields the number of one *yuan*: one hundred twenty-nine thousand six hundred.

It is also said: Earth’s four transformations generate thirty-six—this is the number of generating things. Four generates twelve, twelve generates twenty, twenty generates twenty-eight, twenty-eight generates thirty-six, and thereupon advancing to two hundred fifty-six. The number of Earth’s generation takes four as its root and uses two with ten. Two splits one into four, splits four into sixteen, splits sixteen into sixty-four, and splits sixty-four into two hundred fifty-six—these are Earth’s four transformations. Sixteen is Earth’s four. One transformation into four is Earth’s one. Four generates eight: one four generates two fours, and combining them makes three fours—twelve.

chunks.original_text: 八生十二者，二四生三四，并之则为五四二十。 十二生十六者，三四生四四，并之则为四七二十八。 十六生二十者，四四生五四，并之则为四九三十六。 地用四变而极于九，所以生物。 六六而数之，天所以运行。 四九而数之，地所以生物。 一期自草木萌动，至于地始冻而物不生，二百五十六日而已。 卦体八八，卦用六六。 爻体三百八十四，爻用二百一十六。 卦用三十六，爻用二百一十六，合之即用数之用二百五十二也。 爻，天也。 六为天之用。 卦，地也。 八为地之体，所以用乎地上，皆一阳之气，阳包乎阴也。 天有六气，三阳三阴。 一气而六旬，三十六者旬数也。 六子皆三十六，一年三百六十日。 六阳为十二，六变为三十六阳。 六阴为十二，六变为三十六阴。 四九三十六。 四九者，九之体。 六六者，六之用。 阳六又兼阴六之半，是以为九。 坤用四六，两其十二。 乾用四九，三其十二。 是以兼阴六之半。 故曰：体有八而用有六，卦有八而爻用六。 阳三十六，三之为一百八。 阴三十六，三之为一百八。 三阳三阴，各半也。 三六一十八，即一百八也。 两其十八，即二百一十六。 乾四九，坤四六，乾克其余分，故坤退一六以奉乾。 乾得七六，坤得三六。 而已用卦之策，乾尽包之，阴已无有。 是以三阳三阴，分乾之二百一十六。 一日十二时，一年十二月。 自寅至午一百八，自午至戌#47一百八。 阳中三阴，阴中三阳，皆为昼为开物之时。 其余百四十四，虽属之坤，寅之末一十八，戌之初一十八，共三十六分，犹为阳之余分所克。 为春夏秋生物之时，以助乾之施化。 三用而一不用也。 故曰：阳以阴为基。 《易》之生数，一十二万九千六百。 总于四千三百二十世，此消长之大数。 衍三十年之辰数，即其数也。 以时之阴阳，进退消长。 积为一年推之，岁三百六十日，得四千三百二十辰，以三十乘之尔。 甲子甲午为一世，首数有十，生成各半。 元会运世年，天之生数五。 日月时分秒，地之成数五。 故经世之数止於年大，而小之数极于秒。 以一元推之，秒则一月，分则一年，辰则一世，日则一运，月则一会，元则一年。 乾官一位八卦，自元至辰，宗于天之一元。 天地大数也。 外七位每位八卦，亦自元至辰，各有其元者。 人物小数也。 天之八数，同起甲子。 造化初也。 经世甲子，指一元之年数尔。 日甲月子，星甲辰子。 从之者，月为会，星为运，辰为世。 是月与星辰，皆得一十二万九千六百之数。 得泰之五，亿数则尽。 乾一位八卦之数，又变三十，得兑位履卦百七十七。 亿则一辰三十分之数也。 每月日时阴阳，皆有消长。 一日成二日，一时成二时。 以分藏秒，以秒藏时，时藏月，月藏日，日藏年。 愈细愈大，愈大愈细，鬼神不能窥矣。 分秒之数何如？ 一时三十分，计三百六十秒，卦当大有。 一日十二时三百六十分，计四千三百二十秒，卦大壮。 一月三百六十时一万八百分，计十二万九千#48六百秒，卦小畜。 一年四千三百二十时十二万九千六百分，计一百五十五万五千二百秒，需卦。 一世三十年一十二万九千六百时三百八十八万八千分，计四千六百六十五万六千秒，大畜卦。 一运十二世一百五十五万五千二百时四千六百六十五万六千分，五亿五千九百八十七万二千秒，泰卦。

chunks.original_text: 一会三十运四千六百六十五万六千时十三亿九千九百六十八万分，计一百六十七亿九千九百十六万秒，履卦。 一元十二会五亿五千九百八十七万二千时一百六十七亿九千九百一十六万分，计二千一十五亿五千三百九十二万秒，兑卦。 十二万九千六百为元，一元之年，一会之月，一运之日，一世之辰，皆有一十二万九千六百之数。 六十甲子，周流先天方圆二图之内。 圆图为天，去四正卦二十四爻，当三百六十日，行乎十干十二支。 十干以应天之十日，十二支以应地之十二月十二时。 所谓五日一候，十日一甲，十五日一气，三十日一月。 甲戊以阳变，己癸以阴变，五以变也。 午亥以阴变，子巳以阳变，六以变也。 一年甲子十之六，一月三甲而六其五，一年三十六甲而三百六十运，周以天之五而生七十二也。 一月两子兼半而五其六，一年三其十子而亦三百六十运，周以地之六而亦成七十二也。 图之左，一十五子。 一子两变，共三十变一三六一百八十。 右亦然，亦三百六十也。 三十分为时，三百六十为时之秒，四千三百为日之积。 又以月为年，两日半三十时为一月。 时之三十分，一分为一日，每分十二秒，一秒为一时。 缩年为月，缩月为日，缩日为时。 十二万九千六百年，亦自一时之分秒而积之尔。 微而分之，至百六十七亿九千六百一十六秒而止。 细之又细，所以能研物理而穷事情。 高入苍天，低入黄泉，大含#49元气，细入无伦。 子云亦尝推见此矣。 今以圆图转之，以见皇帝王伯之铺舒，古往今来之治乱，四时万化之运行，日月星辰之流转。 乾坤主之，所以明天之数也。 方圆为地，四以为体。 四四以数，至四九而转十六事以明，至二百五十六位而分。 天声倡於上而六律呜，地音和於下而六吕应，走飞草木皆应其数。 坎离主之运，四阴四阳以生物於地也。 先天之学，图由中起。 大关造化，皆自然之妙也。 宜邵子玩心神明，而终日不离乎此。 程子曰：《易》逆数也。 要测知未萌事若已往，何用筹筹。 然数者，理也。 理有必然，如五世三世。 希不失之类，数莫逃乎理也。 秦汉以来，舍理言数，入於谶纬久矣。 到康节说数方及理，参天地之运。 颓乎其顺，浩然其归。 如曰：画前元有子后无移。 数如此，理亦如此。 愚谓：穷理尽性以至於命。 理为主，数亦在其中。 夫子虽不言命，而日河不出《图》吾已矣。 夫数不明，则理亦晦。 故邵子曰：学不际天人，不足谓之学。 君子当造其极可也。 愚谓：天下之数出於理，违理则入于衍。 朱子曰：康节之学，虽作用不同，而其实则伏羲所画之卦也。 吕国史中日，．体天地之撰者，至於《易》而止。 天奇地偶之画，阳九阴六之数，四千九十六卦之变，万有一千五百二十策，有加乎此哉。 故其日月星辰水火土石，尽天地之体用。 以寒暑昼夜雨风露雷，尽天地之变化。 以性情形体走飞草木，尽万物之感应。 以元会运世岁月日辰，尽天地之终始。 以皇帝王伯《易》、《诗》、《书》、《春秋》，尽圣贤之事业。 秦汉以来，一人而已。 数学枢要。 天一地二。 天奇一一，地偶二二。 天无十，地无一。 一三五三天#50故乾用九。 二四两地，坤用六。 一者，天圆之体。

A *hui* comprises thirty *yun*, totaling 46,656,000 *shi* and 1,399,680,000 *fen*, which amounts to 16,799,160,000 *miao*, corresponding to the *Lǚ* hexagram. A *yuan* comprises twelve *hui*, totaling 559,872,000 *shi* and 16,799,160,000 *fen*, which amounts to 201,553,920,000 *miao*, corresponding to the *Duì* hexagram. The number 129,600 constitutes a *yuan*: the years of a *yuan*, the months of a *hui*, the days of a *yun*, and the *chen* of a *shi* all share this number of 129,600.

The sixty *jiazi* cycle circulates within the Prior Heaven’s square and circular diagrams. The circular diagram represents Heaven; removing the four cardinal hexagrams and their twenty-four lines corresponds to 360 days, moving through the ten Celestial Stems and twelve Earthly Branches. The ten Stems correspond to Heaven’s ten days, while the twelve Branches correspond to Earth’s twelve months and twelve *shi*. Thus, five days make a *hou*, ten days make a *jia*, fifteen days make a *qi*, and thirty days make a month. *Jia* and *wu* transform through yang, *ji* and *gui* through yin—five transformations. *Wu* and *hai* transform through yin, *zi* and *si* through yang—six transformations. In a year, the *jiazi* cycle completes six-tenths; in a month, three *jia* cycles with five-sixths of another; in a year, thirty-six *jia* cycles yielding 360 movements, revolving through Heaven’s five to generate seventy-two. In a month, two *zi* with half of another, five-sixths of six; in a year, three sets of ten *zi*, also totaling 360 movements, revolving through Earth’s six to likewise complete seventy-two. On the left of the diagram, fifteen *zi*. Each *zi* undergoes two transformations, totaling thirty transformations—1, 3, 6, 180. The right is the same, also totaling 360. Thirty *fen* make a *shi*; 360 make the *miao* of a *shi*; 4,300 accumulate into a day. Again, taking months as years, two and a half days and thirty *shi* make a month. The thirty *fen* of a *shi*—each *fen* as a day, every *fen* with twelve *miao*, each *miao* as a *shi*. Condensing years into months, months into days, days into *shi*. Even 129,600 years are but the accumulation of the *fen* and *miao* of a single *shi*. Divided minutely, it extends to 16,799,616,000 *miao* and no further. Refined ever further, it enables the investigation of principles and the exhaustion of affairs. Ascending into the azure heavens, descending into the yellow springs, broadly containing primordial *qi*, minutely entering the boundless.

Master Yang Xiong once deduced this. Now, rotating the circular diagram reveals the expansion and contraction of emperors, kings, and hegemons; the order and chaos of past and present; the movements of the four seasons and myriad transformations; the revolutions of the sun, moon, and stars. *Qian* and *Kun* govern it, thereby illuminating Heaven’s numbers.

The square diagram represents Earth, structured by four. Counting by fours, reaching four nines, it turns to sixteen matters for clarification, extending to 256 positions for differentiation. Heaven’s voice initiates above as the six *lü* resonate; Earth’s tone responds below as the six *lü* answer. Creatures that run, fly, and plants all correspond to these numbers. *Kan* and *Li* govern its movements, with four yin and four yang generating beings on Earth.

The Prior Heaven’s study begins from the center of the diagram. The great pivot of creation is all the marvel of spontaneity. Master Shao should have contemplated this with profound insight, never departing from it even for a day. Master Cheng said: *"The Book of Changes* reckons in reverse. To foresee the unmanifest as if it were past, what need is there for divination?" Yet numbers are principle. Principle has its inevitabilities, such as the three or five generations. Rarely does it err—numbers cannot escape principle. Since the Qin and Han dynasties, abandoning principle to speak of numbers has long led to apocrypha. Only Master Kangjie spoke of numbers to reach principle, aligning with the movements of Heaven and Earth. Effortlessly compliant, vast in its return. As he said: "Before the diagram, there was *zi*; after *wu*, there is no change." If numbers are thus, principle is also thus. I say: exhaust principle, fulfill nature, to reach destiny. Principle is primary, yet numbers are within it. Though the Master did not speak of destiny, he said, "If the River does not yield the Diagram, I am done." If numbers are unclear, principle is also obscured. Thus, Master Shao said: "Learning that does not connect Heaven and humanity cannot be called learning." The noble person should attain its utmost.

I say: the numbers of the world arise from principle; violating principle leads to mere calculation. Master Zhu said: "Though Master Kangjie’s methods differ, in essence, they are the hexagrams drawn by Fuxi." The *Records of the Historian* state: "Those who embody the compositions of Heaven and Earth reach their culmination in *The Book of Changes*." The odd lines of Heaven and even lines of Earth, the yang nine and yin six, the 4,096 hexagrams’ changes, the 11,520 counting rods—what more can be added? Thus, the sun, moon, stars, water, fire, earth, and stone exhaust the substance and function of Heaven and Earth. Cold and heat, day and night, rain, wind, dew, and thunder exhaust the transformations of Heaven and Earth. Nature, emotions, forms, bodies, creatures that run, fly, and plants exhaust the responses of the myriad things. The *yuan*, *hui*, *yun*, *shi*, years, months, days, and *chen* exhaust the beginning and end of Heaven and Earth. Emperors, kings, hegemons, *The Book of Changes*, *The Book of Songs*, *The Book of Documents*, and *The Spring and Autumn Annals* exhaust the achievements of sages and worthies. Since the Qin and Han dynasties, there has been only one such master. The essentials of numerical study:

Heaven as one, Earth as two.
Heaven’s odd: one-one; Earth’s even: two-two.
Heaven has no ten; Earth has no one.
One, three, five—three heavens, thus *Qian* uses nine.
Two, four—two earths, thus *Kun* uses six.
One is the body of Heaven’s roundness.

chunks.original_text: 四者，地方之体。 天圆径一围三，积之而八，应八方四维。 地方起四积十二，每一用三。 故四方分十二次，四时分十二月。 天一而二，阴阳并行。 地二而四，阴阳分两。 天圆起一而积八，地方起四而积十二。 圆数奇，故天数一而用六。 方数偶，故地数二而用十二。 天变方为圆，常存其一。 地分二为四，常执其方。 阳主进，故天并一而为七。 阴主退，故地去四而为十二。 圆者起一积六，方者分一为四。 圆者裁方以为用，故一变四。 四去一则三，三变九，九去三则六。 用数成於三而极於六。 方者展圆以为体，一变三并四，四变十二并十六。 体数成於四极于十六。 天主用，故藏一於四十九之中。 五十着中藏一者，数中本有。 地主体，故显四於六十之外。 六十卦外去四者，数内本无。 日一变三十，月一变十二。 日一年盈六日，月一年缩六日。 日一年三百六十六日，月一年三百五十四日。 天起於一，地成於四。 乾一画包坤二画为三，乾三#51画包坤六画为九。 乾一爻三十六阳，坤一爻二十四阴，共六十。 乾一爻，六六三十六，六进一为七，六爻得二百五十二。 坤一爻，四六二十四，四退为三，得三六一#52百八。 坤於乾，百中取三，三百六十中取一百八。 地之用在天，故藏一於始。 天之体在地，故隐四於终。 主天一而言，阳进阴退。 主地二而言，阴阳互为进退。 天三地四，天一三五为九，五四为九。 地一二三为六，二四为六。 天之用，用三百六十。 地之体，具三百八十四。 天圆以用为主，体则托乎地。 地方以体为主，用则从乎天。 天三三为九，地三二为六。 天重三则六，地重四则八。 天生数一二三四，地成数六七八九。 天六六三十六，地四六二十四。 天分其三，故日有三十，进为三百六十日。 地起於二，故月有十二，分为二十四气。 天用数三而极于六，地体数四而极于十六。 天三地两，天七地三。 天有三辰，地有四行。 先天四维，震艮兑巽。 后天四维，乾坤艮巽。 天三地两，天地本用之数。 三而两，两而三，乾坤通用之数。 北极出地上三十六度，余则皆潜。 南极入地下三十六度，余则皆见。 卦用六爻者，三百八十四爻。 周四位者，二百五十六。 二男以二十八阳生乾父之三十六阳，三女以二十八阴生坤母之三十六阴。 坤母以十二阳生三男各二十阳，乾父以十二阴生三女各二十阴。 坤中藏十二阳，至乾成三十六阳。 乾中藏十二阴，至坤成三十六阴。 乾三百六十三，分用二为开物数。 坤四六二十四，去一存三为闭物数。 天铃有地三而两，地铃有天两而三。 乾包坤偶为三，坤分阳数为六。 乾主十六卦为奇，坤二十四卦为偶。 阴二而缺，阳全则三。 乾中藏三十六阳，坤中藏三十六阴。 乾三十六阳主进，进之为三百六十。 坤十二阴主消，一年十二月消十二日。 阳得三用进，六六三十六，三百六十卦分入体变，八八六十四，四千九百二十卦。 三十六为天之用卦，六十四应地之体。 《先天图》左为天，三百三十六分长。 震离兑乾为长，巽坎艮坤为消。 图右为地，三百三十二分消。 巽艮坎坤为长，震离兑乾为消。 天多於地，圣人扶阳为奇数，故天三地两。 地多於天，太极肇判为初数，故阳一阴二，天五地六，天五地十，天六地四，天四地六。

Four is the body of Earth’s squareness.
Heaven’s roundness has a diameter of one and a circumference of three, accumulating to eight, corresponding to the eight directions and four corners.
Earth’s squareness arises from four and accumulates to twelve, each one employing three.
Thus, the four directions divide into twelve stations, and the four seasons divide into twelve months.
Heaven is one and becomes two, with yin and yang proceeding together.
Earth is two and becomes four, with yin and yang splitting into pairs.
Heaven’s roundness begins with one and accumulates to eight; Earth’s squareness begins with four and accumulates to twelve.
The number of the round is odd, so Heaven’s number is one and employs six.
The number of the square is even, so Earth’s number is two and employs twelve.
Heaven transforms the square into the round, ever preserving its oneness.
Earth divides two into four, ever holding to its squareness.
Yang governs advance, so Heaven combines one to make seven.
Yin governs retreat, so Earth removes four to make twelve.
The round begins with one and accumulates to six; the square divides one into four.
The round trims the square for its use, so one transforms into four.
Four minus one leaves three; three transforms into nine; nine minus three leaves six.
The operational number is completed in three and reaches its limit at six.
The square expands the round for its body: one transforms into three and combines with four; four transforms into twelve and combines with sixteen.
The structural number is completed in four and reaches its limit at sixteen.
Heaven governs use, so it conceals one within forty-nine.
That fifty displays the center yet conceals one means the number inherently contains it.
Earth governs structure, so it reveals four beyond sixty.
That sixty hexagrams exclude four externally means the number inherently lacks it.
The sun transforms once every thirty days; the moon transforms once every twelve.
In one year, the sun gains six days; in one year, the moon loses six days.
One solar year has three hundred sixty-six days; one lunar year has three hundred fifty-four days.
Heaven arises from one; Earth is completed in four.
*Qian*’s one line envelops *Kun*’s two lines to make three; *Qian*’s three lines envelop *Kun*’s six lines to make nine.
*Qian*’s one line contains thirty-six yang; *Kun*’s one line contains twenty-four yin, totaling sixty.
*Qian*’s one line: six sixes make thirty-six; six advances by one to seven, so six lines yield two hundred fifty-two.
*Kun*’s one line: four sixes make twenty-four; four retreats to three, yielding three sixes one hundred eight.
Of *Kun* relative to *Qian*, one hundred takes three, so three hundred sixty takes one hundred eight.
Earth’s use lies in Heaven, so it conceals one at the beginning.

Six is Heaven’s operational number. Twelve is Earth’s operational number. Heaven’s transformations proceed through six qi in six changes. Earth’s transformations proceed through four bodies in four divisions. Heaven’s number is twenty-five, combined as fifty, corresponding to the tallying numbers. Earth’s number is thirty, combined as sixty, corresponding to the hexagram numbers. Heaven’s six operational numbers belong to yang; Earth’s eight structural numbers belong to yin.

Heaven’s six changes yield six times six, thirty-six periods. Earth’s four changes yield four times four, sixteen positions. Heaven’s number six, each line thirty-six: halved, three times six makes eighteen changes. Five times six makes thirty days; six times six makes three hundred sixty. Earth’s number two, each line twenty-four: halved, two times six makes four times forty-eight lines; six times seventy-two seasonal markers; sixty times six likewise yields three hundred sixty.

Heaven stores its operations in six; Earth manifests its power in eight. Heaven has six changes, with three yielding six. From six to thirty-six, these are Heaven’s six changes. Earth has four directions, with two yielding four. From four to two hundred fifty-six, these are Earth’s six changes. Heaven encompasses Earth, thus employing six changes: one change sixty, six changes three hundred sixty. Earth does not encompass Heaven, thus employing four changes: one change four, two changes sixteen, three changes sixty-four, four changes two hundred fifty-six.

Six as the operational number belongs to yang; eight as the structural number belongs to yin. Six times six constitutes the operational use of the thirty-six hexagrams. Eight times eight constitutes the structural body of the sixty-four hexagrams. Earth follows Heaven in employing five; Heaven follows Earth in employing six.

*Qian* and *Dui* correspond to spring, with fifty-six yang and forty yin. *Kan* and *Gen* correspond to autumn, thus the inverse. *Qian* and *Xun* correspond to summer, with sixty-four yang and thirty-two yin. *Kun* and *Gen* correspond to winter, thus the inverse. *Zhen*, *Kan*, and *Gen* hold six yang and twelve yin; *Xun*, *Li*, and *Dui* hold six yin and twelve yang.

*Qian* governs surplus, completing a year’s three hundred sixty days. *Kun* governs deficiency, contracting by six days to remain whole. Heaven’s number twenty-five, combined as fifty, advances to one hundred. Earth’s number thirty, combined as sixty, advances to one hundred twenty.

*Qian* totals two hundred fifty-two, the operational number of the thirty-six hexagrams. *Kun* totals one hundred eight, the intersecting number of the twenty-four hexagrams. From the fifty tallying numbers, remove one, dispersing it into forty-nine for use. Within use lies structure: beyond the sixty hexagrams, four remain—four as the body of the sixty hexagrams. Within structure lies use: Heaven seven, Earth eight. Heaven employs seven; Earth’s body is eight.

Hexagrams with six times six belong to use, attributed to yang lines, transforming into eight. Eight belongs to structure, attributed to yin hexagrams, opening things through *Qian*’s operation. In the eighth month, things close through *Kun*’s operation, dividing into three parts.

Heaven nine, Earth ten. Heaven’s five and four make nine; three times three makes nine; nine times nine makes eighty-one; four times nine makes thirty-six. From *zi* to *si*, six to nine. From *wu* to *hai*, nine to six.

*Qian*’s number is nine, yet Heaven employs six—nine grows from six. *Kun*’s number is six, yet Earth’s body is four—six arises from four. *Qian* employs nine: three times eight makes nine, yielding two hundred sixteen. Two times eight makes nine, likewise yielding *Kun*’s one hundred forty-four. *Kun* employs six: two times twelve makes six, yielding one hundred forty-four. Three times twelve makes six, likewise yielding *Qian*’s two hundred sixteen.

Heaven culminates in nine, Earth exhausts in ten. Ninety marks the beginning and end of Heaven and Earth. The numbers of the eight trigrams total thirty-six. One and eight, two and seven, three and six, four and five—all intersecting numbers are nine. To speak of ten is merely nine’s counterpart. Yang culminates in nine; yin ends in ten.

Heaven’s ten arises from one becoming two, two and five making ten. Earth’s ten arises from two becoming four, two and eight making ten. Fifty takes one as its root, forty-nine as its use. Sixty-four takes four as its root, sixty as its use.

Here concludes the sixteenth scroll of *Heaven’s Original Unfolding of Subtleties*.

The numbers of Heaven and Earth unite to form one thousand two hundred. The numbers of the Three Powers combine to make one hundred eighty. The numbers of the Four Seasons total seventy-two. chunks.original_text: 鬼神 《易》者天地鬼神之奥也。 始言幽明死生一句，趋一句说入鬼神上去。 仲尼赞《易》以后，自颜曾思轲以下，至于周程张朱数君子而已降。 是则聘竺二家，离了天地造化，又别作一样看。 释以鬼怖人，令人皈向则不堕轮回。 老以传诱人，令人修炼则可长生。 又降而世俗焉，则土木为像而庙之，巫现啸呼而祝之。 曰：如是而已，孰能探造化迹哉，吁可慨也，已上。 蔡谢氏曰：鬼神是天地间妙用，须是将来做题目，入思议始得。 《易□大传》曰：仰以观於天文，俯以察於地理，是故知幽明之故。 原始反终，故知死生之说。 精气为物，游魂为变，是故知鬼神之情状。 以者用《易》中阴阳之理而观察之也。 天文属阳故明，地理属阴故幽。 日月星辰明矣，亭毒寥邈又有幽焉。 下入黄泉幽矣，发育呈露又有明焉。 原始而来属阳，故曰生。 反终而归属阴，故曰死。 人生队百岁为准，存养得定，则虽老而阳亦壮。 反之！ 则虽壮年亦衰。 故阳为主，则阳去消阴，生意充满，屈者伸，桔者荣，光风齐月，融溢充匝#1，并可以见神之情状。 阴为主，则阴来消阳，生意挚缩，伸者屈，荣者枯，如缺月妻风，阳气消尽则死矣，又可以见鬼之情状。 天地问，阳只管生，若无阴以死之，则有生无死，造化亦几乎息矣。 故推幽明，可以知死生。 推死生，可以知鬼神。 一气万形，一息古今。 通昼夜之道，而知天地造化，源源於是。 非太极之英气，有以为之欤。 呜呼！ 微哉。

The Spirits and Gods

The *Book of Changes* (*Yijing*) reveals the mysteries of Heaven, Earth, spirits, and gods. It begins with the phrase on the obscure and the manifest, life and death, then proceeds to discuss spirits and gods. After Confucius’ commentary on the *Changes*, from Yan [Hui], Zeng [zi], Zisi, and Mencius down to the several masters of the Zhou [Dunyi], Cheng [brothers], Zhang [Zai], and Zhu [Xi], the teachings diverged. The two traditions of Śākya and Laozi departed from the creative transformations of Heaven and Earth, presenting an entirely different view. Buddhism uses the fear of spirits to guide people, urging them to take refuge so as not to fall into the cycle of rebirth. Daoism employs transmission to entice people, promising that through cultivation one may attain longevity. Descending further into世俗俗 practices, people carve statues from wood and earth to enshrine them, or invoke spirits through the shamanic cries of mediums. Is this all there is? Who can truly fathom the traces of the creative transformations? Alas, how lamentable!

Master Cai Xie said: Spirits and gods are the wondrous workings within Heaven and Earth. One must take them as a subject for contemplation and enter into reflection to grasp them. The *Great Commentary* of the *Book of Changes* states: "Looking up, one observes the patterns of Heaven; looking down, one examines the principles of Earth. Thus one knows the causes of the obscure and the manifest. Tracing things to their origins and returning to their ends, one knows the explanations of life and death. Essence and qi become things; wandering souls undergo transformation. Thus one knows the conditions and forms of spirits and gods." This is to apply the principles of yin and yang from the *Changes* to observation.

The patterns of Heaven pertain to yang and thus are manifest; the principles of Earth pertain to yin and thus are obscure. The sun, moon, and stars are manifest, yet in the vast and distant reaches, there is also obscurity. Descending into the Yellow Springs, all is obscure, yet in the sprouting and flourishing of life, there is also manifestation. Coming forth from the origin pertains to yang, hence it is called life. Returning to the end pertains to yin, hence it is called death. Human life is measured by a span of a hundred years. If one preserves and nurtures properly, even in old age, the yang may remain robust. If not—even in one’s prime, one may decline. Thus, when yang is dominant, yang recedes and yin diminishes; the vitality of life overflows, the bent straightens, the withered flourishes, and in the radiance of wind and moon, all is harmonious and abundant—here one may perceive the conditions of the spirit. When yin is dominant, yin advances and yang recedes; the vitality of life contracts, the straight bends, the flourishing withers, and like a waning moon or a chilling wind, when the yang qi is exhausted, death ensues—here one may perceive the conditions of the ghost.

Between Heaven and Earth, yang is solely concerned with generation. If there were no yin to bring about death, there would be life without end, and the creative transformations would nearly cease. Therefore, by examining the obscure and the manifest, one may know life and death. By examining life and death, one may know spirits and gods. One qi assumes myriad forms; one breath spans past and present. Comprehending the Dao of day and night, one may understand the creative transformations of Heaven and Earth, whose inexhaustible source lies herein. Is this not the vital qi of the Great Ultimate? Alas! How subtle it is!

chunks.original_text: 或问：《易》言天地日月四时，而终之以鬼神者，指二气之屈伸而言也。 周子言天地人，而终之以死生者，指在人一气之聚散而言也。 然则天地不可以死生言乎。 曰：天地其形也，死生其气也。 人受天地之气以生。 阳魂属天，阴魄属地。 死则魂气归于天，体魄降于地，依旧还大原里去#2。 故举人之死生，可以包天地之昼夜。 而日月晦明，四时变化，鬼神屈伸，皆在其中矣。 孰得以窥其际。 程子曰：《易》说鬼神，便是造化。 以春而原之，其必有冬。 以冬为终，而反之其必有春。 死生者，其与是类也。 知生之道，即知死之道。 知事人之道，即知事神之道。 死生人鬼，一而二，二而一也。 朱子曰：鬼神自是难理会底。 且就紧处做工夫，人生有多少道理。 自禀五常之性以来，所以父子有亲，君臣有义。 须一一理会生底道理，则死底道理皆可知。 如事君事亲，事其所当。 事尽诚敬之道，即移此心以事鬼神，则祭如在。 祭神如神在，须是得这道理无欠缺。 到得那死时，乃是生理已尽，亦安於死而无愧。 故张子曰：存吾顺事，设吾宁也。 儒者以理为不生不灭，释氏以神识为不生不灭。 圣人不说死已，更说甚事。 圣人只说既生之后，未死之前，须与他精细理会教是。 六经载圣贤行事备矣，於死生之际无述焉，益以为常事也。 《记》与《鲁论》独载曾子寝疾时事为详，不过教学者以保身谨理而已。 岂效浮屠不察於理，而以坐亡立脱为奇哉。 胡明仲曰：人生物也，佛不言生而言死。 人事可见也，佛不言显而言幽。 横渠形溃反原，以为人得此气而生。 死则复归大原去。 益人死则气散了。 那大原裹气，又别抽出来生人。 又曰：天地是体，鬼神是用。 天地是举其全体而言，鬼神是举其中运动变化通上下而言。 如雨风露雷草木，皆是以类而推。 春夏是神，秋冬是鬼。 昼是神，夜是鬼。 午前是神，午后是鬼。 息是神，消是鬼。 生是神，死是鬼。 鼻息呼是神，吸是鬼。 语是神，默是鬼。 伸是神，屈是鬼。 气方来是神，反是鬼。 日是神，月是鬼。 初三后是神，十六后是鬼。 天造是神，地化是鬼。 草木方发生是神，凋落是鬼。 人少壮是神，衰老是鬼。 风雷鼓舞是神，收敛是鬼。 风雨雷电初发时是神，风休雨过雷住电息是鬼。 张子曰：太虚不能无气，气不能不聚而为万物，万物不能不散为太虚。 循是出入，皆不得已而然也。 气之为物，散入无形，适得吾体。 聚而有象，不失吾常。 聚亦吾体，散亦吾体。 知死生之不亡者！ 可与言性矣。 朱子曰：性者，理而已矣，不可以聚散言。 其聚而生，散而死者，气而已矣。 所谓精神魂魄，有知有觉者，皆气之所为也。 故聚则有，散则无。 若理则初不为聚散而无有也。 但有是理，则有是气。 苟气聚乎此，则理亦命乎此矣，不得以冰呕比也。 鬼神便是精神魂魄，气也，非性也。 故祭祀之礼，以类而感，以类而应。 若性则又岂有类之可言。 然气之已散者，既散而无有矣。 其根於理而日生者则固，浩然而无穷。 故圣人之祭祀也，设主立尸媾萧灌魁。 或求之阴，或求之阳。 无所不用，其极而止，日庶或享之而已。 其至诚恻怛精微恍惚之意，益有所不容言者，非可以世俗麓浅知见执一而求也。
chunks.translated_text:
Someone asked: *"The* Book of Changes *speaks of Heaven and Earth, sun and moon, and the four seasons, yet concludes with ghosts and spirits—this refers to the contraction and expansion of the two qi. Master Zhou speaks of Heaven, Earth, and humanity, yet concludes with life and death—this refers to the gathering and dispersal of the single qi within humans. But can Heaven and Earth not be spoken of in terms of life and death?"*

I reply: *"Heaven and Earth are their forms; life and death are their qi. Humans receive the qi of Heaven and Earth to live. The yang soul belongs to Heaven; the yin corporeal soul belongs to Earth. In death, the soul’s qi returns to Heaven, while the body and corporeal soul descend to Earth, reverting to the Great Origin as before. Thus, by examining human life and death, one may encompass the day and night of Heaven and Earth. Within this are the waxing and waning of the sun and moon, the transformations of the four seasons, the contraction and expansion of ghosts and spirits—who can fathom their bounds?"*

Master Cheng said: *"The* Book of Changes *speaks of ghosts and spirits as the workings of creation. Tracing spring to its origin, winter must follow; taking winter as the end, spring must return. Life and death are of the same kind. To know the Way of life is to know the Way of death; to know the Way of serving humans is to know the Way of serving spirits. Life and death, humans and ghosts—one yet two, two yet one."*

Master Zhu said: *"Ghosts and spirits are inherently difficult to comprehend. One should focus on the essentials: how much principle governs human life! From the moment we receive the nature of the Five Constants, there are the bonds of father and child, the righteousness of ruler and minister. Each of these principles of life must be understood, and then the principles of death will also be known. In serving one’s ruler or parents, one fulfills what is proper. Having exhausted the Way of sincerity and reverence, one may then turn this mind to serving ghosts and spirits—thus, in sacrifice, the departed are present; in worship, the spirits are present. This requires grasping the principle without deficiency. At the time of death, when the principle of life is exhausted, one rests in death without regret."*

Thus, Master Zhang said: *"Preserve what is right in life; in death, find peace."*

The Confucians hold that principle is neither born nor destroyed, while the Buddhists claim that consciousness is neither born nor destroyed. The sages do not speak of what comes after death—what more need be said? They only teach that between birth and death, one must attend to life with utmost care. The Six Classics record the deeds of the sages and worthies in full, yet say nothing of the threshold of life and death, for they regard it as an ordinary matter. Only the *Records* and the *Analects of Lu* provide detailed accounts of Master Zeng’s final illness, merely to instruct scholars in preserving the body and upholding principle. How could they emulate the Buddhists, who, ignorant of principle, regard sitting death or standing transcendence as marvels?

Hu Mingshong said: *"Humans are creatures of life, yet the Buddha speaks only of death. Human affairs are visible, yet the Buddha speaks only of the hidden. Master Hengqu’s view that ‘when form dissolves, it returns to the Origin’ means that humans receive this qi to live, and in death, return to the Great Origin. Thus, when a person dies, their qi disperses. The qi within the Great Origin then emerges anew to give life to others."*

He also said: *"Heaven and Earth are the substance; ghosts and spirits are their function. Heaven and Earth are spoken of in their entirety, while ghosts and spirits refer to their dynamic transformations, permeating above and below. Rain, wind, dew, thunder, and plants—all are understood by analogy. Spring and summer are spirit; autumn and winter are ghost. Day is spirit; night is ghost. Before noon is spirit; after noon is ghost. Inhalation is spirit; exhalation is ghost. Life is spirit; death is ghost. Speaking is spirit; silence is ghost. Extension is spirit; contraction is ghost. Qi coming forth is spirit; its return is ghost. The sun is spirit; the moon is ghost. After the third day is spirit; after the sixteenth day is ghost. Heaven’s creation is spirit; Earth’s transformation is ghost. Plants sprouting is spirit; withering is ghost. Human youth and vigor are spirit; decline and old age are ghost. Wind and thunder stirring are spirit; their gathering is ghost. The onset of wind, rain, thunder, and lightning is spirit; their cessation is ghost."*

Master Zhang said: *"The Great Void cannot be without qi. Qi cannot but gather to form the myriad things, nor can the myriad things but disperse back into the Great Void. This cycle of exit and entry is inevitable. As qi, when dispersed, enters the formless, it perfectly attains our body; when gathered, it takes shape without losing its constancy. Gathered, it is our body; dispersed, it is still our body. Knowing that life and death do not perish—one may then speak of nature!"*

Master Zhu said: *"Nature is simply principle and cannot be spoken of in terms of gathering and dispersal. What gathers to give life and disperses in death is merely qi. The so-called spirit, soul, consciousness, and awareness are all the workings of qi. Thus, when gathered, they exist; when dispersed, they vanish. But principle is never absent due to gathering or dispersal. Where there is principle, there is qi. If qi gathers here, principle also resides here—it cannot be compared to ice and foam. Ghosts and spirits are the spirit, soul, consciousness, and corporeal soul—qi, not nature. Thus, the rites of sacrifice operate through resonance by kind. If nature were involved, how could there be such resonance? Yet the qi that has already dispersed is gone without a trace. That which is rooted in principle and daily renewed remains vast and inexhaustible. Therefore, the sages’ sacrifices—setting up ancestral tablets, employing impersonators, offering mugwort and millet, libations and purifications—whether seeking in the yin or the yang, spare no effort, stopping only at the utmost. They say, ‘Perhaps they will partake.’ The profound sincerity, compassion, subtlety, and elusive intent therein defy expression—such things cannot be sought with the shallow knowledge and rigid views of the common world."*

chunks.original_text: 岂日一受其成形，则此性遂为吾有。 虽死犹不灭，截然自为一物，藏乎寂然。 一体之中，以俟夫人祭祝之，求而时出以飨之耶。 又如此说，则其界限之广狭，安顿之处所，铃有可言者。 自开辟以来，积至于今，其重并积迭，计已无地之可容矣。 是又安有此理邪。 且乾坤造化，如大洪炉。 人物生生，无少休息。 是乃所谓实然之理，不忧其断灭也。 今乃斗一片大虚寂目之，而反认人物已死之知觉，谓之实然之理，岂不误哉。 又圣贤所谓归全安死者，亦曰无失其所。 受於天之理，则可以无愧而死矣。 非以为实有一物可奉，持而归之，然后吾之不断不灭者，得以宴然安处乎寂寞之中也。 夭寿不贰，修身以俟之，是乃无所为而然者。 与异端为生死事大，无常迅速，然后学者，正不可同日而语矣。 程子曰：鬼神只是一个造化。 天尊地卑！ 乾坤定矣。 鼓之以雷霆，润之以风雨是也。 此说明有礼乐，幽有鬼神。 朱子谓此对幽明而言也。 若谓幽有鬼神，而明无鬼神，便是错认题目，不知鬼神之为何物，而溺於轮回因果之说也。 岂知礼乐中有鬼神，鬼神中有礼乐。 二者一尔，第不可不分界限而辨别尔。 天地定位辨於履，礼也。 然二气交感，其中未尝无乐。 风雷鼓舞，乐也。 然风休雨止，雷垫霆息，各有序焉，其中未尝无礼。 礼撙节人情，气之屈也。 以和为贵，屈者又伸。 乐动荡人情，气之神也。 而合止有节，伸者又屈，幽明交通，屈伸相禅，无往而不与鬼神通。 彼释氏则死杀看了，谓明则为人，幽则为鬼。 岂知君子之所以谨独者，屋漏暗室，洋洋如在。 礼以束其筋体，乐以养其性情。 礼乐之在吾身，即鬼神之临乎其上。 《易》注云：精气谓七八，言木火之神，生物东南。 游魂谓九六，言金水之神！ 终物西北。 老阴老阳，屈者为鬼。 少阴少阳，伸者为神。 东南为明，西北为幽。 非止谓天地黑暗中有鬼神，而明无之也。 后世礼坏乐废，人心浮伪。 失其序而不和，所以交於鬼神者，非其道也。 不渎则馅，安有感格之理。 张子曰：鬼神二气之良能也。 朱子曰：伊川说鬼神造化之逵固好，但只浑沦在这裹，不如横渠说得分明，便见有个阴阳屈伸往来在。 愚按：阴阳二字，未可言鬼神。 阴之灵日鬼，阳之灵日神。 良能便是其灵处，所以能屈伸变化也。 又举张子物之初生，气日至而滋息。 物生既盈，气日反而游散。 至之谓神，以其申也。 反之谓鬼，以其归也。 又谓：人之初生，天地之气只管增添，在身上渐长渐大。 至极盛了，又渐衰耗以至于散。 然皆自然而然，非有使之然，故日良能。 邵子曰：阴者阳之影，鬼者人之影，月者日之影，情者性之影。 阳也，人也，日也，性也，皆阴鬼月情之主。 所主既定，影自从之。 子月一阳生，应得五月一阴生。 自子至巳六阳全，自午至亥亦六阴全。 天上一阳应地下一阴，水中一物应岸上一物，物物皆然。 但阳常为主，而阴常为影，如牝牡然。 一日有十二时，一年便有十二月。 日初则月生明，望则光满，上下二弦生魄，至晦皆然。 可以见鬼神之情状。 性中有个仁义礼智之理，外面便影得个恻隐羞恶辞逊是非之情。 出来一个形，便有一个影。 人之魂为神，便影得个鬼之魄在其中。
chunks.translated_text:
How can it be said that upon receiving one’s formed body, this nature thereby becomes one’s own possession, enduring even after death without annihilation, standing alone as a distinct entity hidden in stillness, awaiting the sacrifices and prayers of others to be summoned forth and partake of offerings? If this were so, then the boundaries of its scope and the place of its abode would indeed be definable. Yet from the beginning of creation until now, the accumulated dead would have piled up without end, leaving no space to contain them. How could such a principle exist?

Moreover, the creative transformations of Heaven and Earth resemble a great furnace. The ceaseless generation of beings knows no rest—this is the true principle of reality, unconcerned with annihilation. Now to fix one’s gaze upon a vast, empty stillness and instead regard the consciousness of the deceased as the true principle of reality—is this not a grave error?

What the sages and worthies mean by "returning to wholeness" and "resting in death" is simply that one has not lost one’s proper place. Having received the principle from Heaven, one may die without shame. It is not that there exists some tangible entity to be preserved and returned, thereby ensuring that one’s indestructible and imperishable self may repose in tranquil solitude. Whether one dies young or lives long, one remains unwavering, cultivating the self and awaiting one’s end—this is a state of being without contrivance. It cannot be equated with the heterodox view that makes much of life and death, warning of impermanence’s swift approach, and thus misleads scholars.

Master Cheng said: "Ghosts and spirits are but the workings of creation. Heaven is honored, Earth is lowly—thus the positions of Qian and Kun are established. They are stirred by thunder and nourished by wind and rain." This explains that in the manifest there are rites and music, and in the hidden there are ghosts and spirits. Master Zhu said this refers to the contrast between the hidden and the manifest. To claim that the hidden contains ghosts and spirits while the manifest does not is to misconstrue the subject, failing to understand what ghosts and spirits truly are and becoming mired in doctrines of rebirth and karma.

How could one not see that within rites and music there are ghosts and spirits, and within ghosts and spirits there are rites and music? The two are one and the same; one must only distinguish their boundaries and differentiate them. Heaven and Earth take their positions, distinguished by the act of treading—this is ritual. Yet within the interaction of the two qi, there is never an absence of music. The stirring of wind and thunder is music. Yet when the wind subsides and the rain ceases, when thunder stills and lightning fades, each follows its proper order—within this, there is never an absence of ritual.

Ritual restrains human emotions, for qi contracts. Harmony is prized, and what contracts will again expand. Music stirs human emotions, for qi is spirit-like. Yet its movements and rests are measured, and what expands will again contract. The hidden and the manifest communicate; contraction and expansion alternate, and there is nowhere they do not commune with ghosts and spirits.

The Buddhists, however, regard death and killing as settled matters, claiming that the manifest becomes human and the hidden becomes ghost. How could they know that the noble person’s vigilance in solitude makes even the hidden corners of a room feel as though the divine is present? Ritual binds the sinews and body, while music nurtures the nature and emotions. The rites and music within oneself are the very presence of ghosts and spirits above.

The *Commentary on the Book of Changes* states: "The essence of qi refers to the seventh and eighth hexagrams, speaking of the spirits of wood and fire that generate beings in the southeast. The wandering soul refers to the ninth and sixth hexagrams, speaking of the spirits of metal and water that end beings in the northwest." The old yin and old yang, when contracted, become ghosts. The young yin and young yang, when expanded, become spirits. The southeast is the manifest; the northwest is the hidden. This does not mean that ghosts and spirits exist only in the darkness of Heaven and Earth while the manifest is devoid of them.

In later ages, rites decayed and music was abandoned; human hearts became frivolous and deceitful. Having lost their order and harmony, their communion with ghosts and spirits no longer followed the proper way. If one does not revere them, they become distant—how could there be any principle of resonance and response?

Master Zhang said: "Ghosts and spirits are the innate capacities of the two qi." Master Zhu said: "Master Cheng’s explanation of ghosts and spirits as the pathways of creation is fine, but it remains too vague. Master Zhang’s account is clearer, revealing the presence of yin and yang, contraction and expansion, and their ceaseless alternation."

In my humble opinion, the terms "yin" and "yang" alone cannot fully express ghosts and spirits. The numinous aspect of yin is called ghost; the numinous aspect of yang is called spirit. Their innate capacity is precisely their numinosity, enabling them to contract, expand, and transform.

Master Zhang further said: "At the beginning of a thing’s life, qi arrives daily and flourishes. Once the thing reaches full growth, qi daily returns and disperses. The arrival is called spirit, for it expands. The return is called ghost, for it withdraws." He also said: "At the beginning of a person’s life, the qi of Heaven and Earth continually accumulates, gradually growing and expanding within the body. Upon reaching its peak, it gradually declines and dissipates. Yet all this occurs naturally, not by any external agency—hence it is called innate capacity."

Master Shao said: "Yin is the shadow of yang; ghosts are the shadow of humans; the moon is the shadow of the sun; emotions are the shadow of nature. Yang, humans, the sun, and nature are all the masters of yin, ghosts, the moon, and emotions. Once the master is established, the shadow naturally follows. At the winter solstice, the first yang is born, corresponding to the birth of the first yin at the summer solstice. From the winter solstice to the sixth month, the six yangs are complete; from the summer solstice to the twelfth month, the six yins are complete. One yang in the heavens corresponds to one yin on earth; one thing in the water corresponds to one thing on the shore—this is true of all things. Yet yang is always the master, and yin is always the shadow, like the male and female. A day has twelve hours, and a year has twelve months. At dawn, the moon begins to brighten; at the full moon, its light is complete. At the first and last quarters, it begins to wane, and by the end of the month, it is dark. From this, one may perceive the conditions of ghosts and spirits.

Within nature lies the principle of benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom, and externally, it casts the shadow of compassion, shame, deference, and a sense of right and wrong. Every form that emerges casts a shadow. The human soul becomes spirit, and within it, the shadow of the spirit becomes the ghost’s corporeal soul."

They say, ‘Perhaps they will partake.’ The profound sincerity, compassion, subtlety, and elusive intent therein defy expression—such things cannot be sought with the shallow knowledge and rigid views of the common world."*

chunks.original_text: 日至晦则月不光，人至老则神劳啧。 又曰：思虑未启，鬼神未知。 不由乎我，更由乎谁？ 人之为道，当至於鬼神不能窥处。 善恶形于言发于行，人始得知之。 但萌诸心发乎虑，鬼神已得而知之矣。 《中庸》曰：君子戒谨乎其所不睹，恐惧乎其所不闻。 此固君子谨独之学，上不愧于屋漏也。 然谓之思虑未启，即喜怒哀乐未发之时，鬼神不得以窥其际矣。 故曰：不由乎我，更由乎谁？ 益幽暗之中，细微之事进，虽未形而几则已动。 虽己所独知，人所不知，而鬼神已知之矣。 是以君子慎独，不待着于言行。 常若鬼神之临乎其上，不敢有一毫之妄念，动于中也。 昔人弹琴，见螳螂捕蝉，而闻者以为有杀声。 杀在心，而人闻其琴已知之，况於鬼神乎。 君子於此，惟敬以直内而已。 听於无声，视於无形，益不待征於色，发於声，而后始用其力也。 邵又曰：人心之神，即天地之神。 人之自欺其心，即所欺天也。 可不戒哉。 天地虚明，不用耳目，而无不见闻也。 又曰：气形盛则魂魄盛，气形衰则魂魄亦从而衰。 魂随气而变，魄随形而上。 故形存则魄存，形化则魄散。 耳目口鼻心脾胆肾之气全，谓之人。 心之灵日神，胆之灵曰魄，脾之灵日魂，肾之灵日精。 心之灵发乎目曰视，肾之精发乎耳曰聪，脾之魂发乎鼻日嗅，胆之魄发乎口曰言。 八者备，然后谓之人。 此说人形体内#3，研磨其魂魄以知。 人之一身，具天地鬼神之理之灵而不自反。 终日驰逐於外，至於皓首没世，而不自觉，亦可悲也。 夫金木者，生成之始终，在人则精神魂魄。 精为形而阴魄附，气为魂而阳神依。 四者都相离不得，所以魂魄随气形而盛衰也。 形变则阳魂离去，魄化则阴形朽腐。 所以先王以灰灭为极刑，而於人之死也，则卜宅兆哄安厝之。 肾北方，天一水，故以藏精。 精始化为魄，魄乃精之所自出，是精气之佐使而并其出入。 水能生木，木为之子，故胆中藏魄。 心南方，太虚火用晓藏神。 生阳日魂，魂乃神之所自出，是为神气之辅弼，而随其出入。 火能生土，土为之子，故脾中藏魂。 人之一身，精神其主，而魂魄其使也。 精盛则魄盛。 惟至诚则能生精，至精则能生神。 诚也者，皆天一所生而无伪也。 人能主於一，而不散其精，则至诚如神。 心能御气，不能主一。 而散其精，则心为形役。 岂徒没世而无闻哉，其违禽兽不远矣。 人之生也，精神魂魄。 性之用也，血气水谷。 形之用也，惟内外交相，养则精神强而魂魄盛。 性者受之於天，铃有藏焉。 心者神所藏，肾者精所藏，脾者魂所藏，胆者魄所藏。 统其藏者，心也。 故能发见於声臭言视之间，而不违其则者，所以灵也。 形者资於地，必有府焉。 肺为传气之府，肝为传血之府，胃为化水谷之府，又为之胖肠斗流其查滓浊秽。 故曰：天地之性人为贵，岂若异端者之言魂魄哉。 昔有学神仙者，与予言曰：只就龙虎鹑龟上做起。 又曰：只就心肾上。 又曰：只就五藏中五行上探来，终不肯泄其旨归。 后得其要诀，下手处亦甚易。 易但要精一工夫尔，今但知而不为也。 昔朱子与蔡西山研穷一世，深晓之矣。 尝日！ 道家爱径人，铅汞玄牝，互换其名，使人不测。 其实，则精气二者而已。 《楚词》屈子载荧魄之说。
chunks.translated_text:
When the sun reaches its darkest point, the moon loses its light; when a person grows old, the spirit becomes weary and restless.

It is also said: Before thoughts and considerations arise, ghosts and spirits do not yet know them. If not by me, then by whom? The practice of the Dao should reach a point where even ghosts and spirits cannot perceive it. Good and evil take form in speech and manifest in action, at which point others begin to know them. Yet as soon as they sprout in the heart and emerge in thought, ghosts and spirits already know them. *The Doctrine of the Mean* states: "The noble person is cautious and reverent in what is unseen, fearful in what is unheard." This is indeed the noble person’s discipline of vigilance in solitude, ensuring no shame even in the hidden corners of the house. Yet when it speaks of thoughts not yet arisen, it refers to the time before joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure are expressed—ghosts and spirits cannot glimpse that boundary. Thus it is said: If not by me, then by whom?

In the depths of obscurity and the subtlest of matters, though not yet manifest, the incipient movement has already stirred. Though known only to oneself and unseen by others, ghosts and spirits already know it. Therefore, the noble person is vigilant in solitude, not waiting for words or deeds to take shape. Ever mindful of ghosts and spirits hovering above, they dare not harbor even the slightest reckless thought within. Once, a man played the zither and saw a mantis hunting a cicada; those who heard it perceived a killing intent in the music. The killing intent was in the heart, yet others heard it in the zither—how much more so for ghosts and spirits? In this, the noble person cultivates only reverence to keep the inner self upright. They listen to the soundless, see the formless, and thus do not wait for signs in countenance or utterance before exerting effort.

Shao [Yong] also said: The spirit of the human heart is the spirit of Heaven and Earth. To deceive one’s own heart is to deceive Heaven itself. How can one not be vigilant? Heaven and Earth are empty and luminous, needing neither ears nor eyes to see and hear all.

It is further said: When qi and form flourish, the hun and po flourish; when qi and form decline, the hun and po also decline. The hun transforms with qi, while the po ascends with form. Thus, as long as form exists, the po remains; when form dissolves, the po scatters. When the qi of the ears, eyes, mouth, nose, heart, spleen, gallbladder, and kidneys is whole, it is called a person. The numinous spirit of the heart is called *shen*; the numinous spirit of the gallbladder is called *po*; the numinous spirit of the spleen is called *hun*; the numinous essence of the kidneys is called *jing*. The spirit of the heart manifests in the eyes as sight; the essence of the kidneys manifests in the ears as hearing; the hun of the spleen manifests in the nose as smell; the po of the gallbladder manifests in the mouth as speech. Only when these eight are complete is one called a person. This explains the inner workings of the human form, refining the hun and po to gain understanding.

The human body possesses the numinous principle of Heaven, Earth, ghosts, and spirits, yet fails to reflect inwardly. Instead, it spends its days chasing externals, reaching white-haired old age and death without self-awareness—how lamentable! Metal and wood mark the beginning and end of generation; in humans, they correspond to spirit, essence, hun, and po. Essence forms the body, and the yin po clings to it; qi forms the hun, and the yang shen depends on it. These four cannot be separated, which is why the hun and po wax and wane with qi and form. When form changes, the yang hun departs; when the po dissolves, the yin form decays. Thus, the ancient kings regarded dismemberment and incineration as the ultimate punishment, and for the dead, they divined burial sites to ensure peaceful rest.

The kidneys belong to the north, where Heaven’s One Water resides, hence they store essence. Essence first transforms into po, and the po is the source of essence—it is the servant of essence and qi, accompanying their ingress and egress. Water generates wood, and wood is its child, so the gallbladder stores po. The heart belongs to the south, where the Great Void’s fire governs clarity, storing shen. The yang hun is born of shen, and the hun is the attendant of shen and qi, following their ingress and egress. Fire generates earth, and earth is its child, so the spleen stores hun.

In the human body, spirit and essence are the masters, while hun and po are their agents. When essence flourishes, the po flourishes. Only utmost sincerity can generate essence, and utmost essence can generate spirit. Sincerity is what Heaven’s One produces without falsity. If one can focus on the One and not dissipate their essence, they attain sincerity like a spirit. The heart can govern qi but cannot master the One. If it dissipates essence, the heart becomes enslaved by form. How then is one different from beasts, not merely dying without a name?

Human life arises from spirit, essence, hun, and po—the functions of nature—and from blood, qi, water, and grain—the functions of form. Only through mutual nourishment of inner and outer can spirit and essence grow strong, and hun and po flourish. Nature is received from Heaven and must have a repository. The heart stores shen, the kidneys store essence, the spleen stores hun, and the gallbladder stores po. The heart governs these repositories. Thus, when it manifests in voice, scent, speech, and sight without violating principle, it is called numinous. Form is endowed by Earth and must have a storehouse. The lungs are the storehouse for transmitting qi; the liver is the storehouse for transmitting blood; the stomach is the storehouse for transforming water and grain, while the intestines and bladder separate the clear and turbid. Thus it is said: "Of the natures endowed by Heaven and Earth, humans are the most noble"—how could it be like the heterodox teachings on hun and po?

Once, a student of immortality told me: "Begin with the dragon, tiger, quail, and tortoise." He also said: "Begin with the heart and kidneys." And again: "Seek within the Five Agents of the Five Viscera," yet he never revealed the ultimate secret. Later, I obtained the essential method, and the starting point was quite simple. It is simply a matter of focused effort—yet today, people know but do not practice.

Master Zhu [Xi] and Cai Xishan explored this their whole lives and deeply understood it. They once said: Daoists favor shortcuts, using terms like lead, mercury, and the Mysterious Female, exchanging names to confound people. In truth, it is merely essence and qi. Qu Yuan’s *Chu Ci* contains the theory of "illuminating the po."

chunks.original_text: 以精神言也，荧，营也，阴灵之聚而有光景者。 魄不受魂，则魂不载魄，而人死矣。 益魂动魄静，魂火二而魄水一。 载营魄者，以魂加魄，以动守静，以火迫水，以二守一。 如人登车而载於其上，则魂安静而魄精明。 火不燥而水不溢，固长生久视之要诀也。 然亦未言其所以也。 朱子有诗曰：盗启玄#4命秘，窃当生死关。 又曰：但恐逆天道，偷生诅能安。 则亦知之而不为尔。 朱子曰：精气就物而言，魂魄就人而言。 鬼神离乎人而言。 生则谓之精 气，死则谓之魂魄，物则谓#5之鬼神。 气是实底，魂魄是半虚半实底，鬼神是虚数多实数少。 又曰：精气两个合，则魂魄聚而为人。 游魂一个离去，则阳己散，阴无所归，故为变。 子产谓：人生始化日魄，既生魄阳曰魂。 唐孔氏曰：人之生也，始变化为形。 形之灵日魄。 魄内自有阳气。 气之神日灵，魂魄神灵之名。 初生时，耳目心识手足运动，此魄之灵也。 及其精神，性识渐有知觉，此则气之神也。 益魂阳属火，魄阴属水。 天一生水，阴阳始交。 魄既生暖者为魂，先有魄而后有魂。 魂常为主为干《淮南子》曰：天气为魂阳神也，地气为魄阴神也。 乐祁曰：心之精爽是谓魂魄。 魄属形体，魂属精神。 精又是魄，魄是精之神。 神又是魂，魂是气之神。 朱子谓：魂神而魄灵，魂阳而魄阴，魂动而魄静。 生则魂载於魄，而魄检其魂。 死则魂进散，而归于天，魄沦坠而归于地。 运用动作底是魂，不运用动作底是魄。 魄盛则耳目聪明能记忆。 老人目昏耳赎记事不得者，魄衰也。 魂热而魄玲，能以魂守魄，则魂有所守，而亦静魄以魂，而亦有生意。 魂热生凉，魄玲生暖，惟二者不相离。 故阳不燥，阴不滞，而得其和矣。 不然魂愈动，魄愈静。 魂愈热，魄愈玲。 二者不得其和而死矣。 又曰：人生时，魂魄相交，死则各相离去#6。 魄有个形像在裹面，如水晶相祖，所以发出来为耳目#7之精明。 月黑晕是魄，其光是魂。 如香烧出汁子来是魄，那成烟后香底是魂。 魂是魄之光焰，魄是魂之根柢。 火是魂，镜是魄。 灯有光焰，物来便烧。 镜虽照见，却在裹面。 火日外景，金水内景。 火日是魂，金水是魄。 人之眼光是魄，耳亦体尔。 何以为魄，曰能听者便是魄。 鼻知臭，舌知味#8皆是。 但不可以知字为魄，知便属心。 若甘#9若咸酸，要从舌上过。 阴主藏受，故魄能记忆。 在内阳主运用，故魂能发用出来。 二物本不相离。 精聚则魄聚，气聚则魂聚。 是为人物之体，至於精竭魄降，则气散魂游而无所知矣。 就人身而言，气虽属阳，然体魄已属阴，生之中已带个死底道理。 变虽属阳，然魂气上游，体魄下降，亦自具阴阳也。 只今生人，便自一半是神一半是鬼。 未死前神为主，已死后鬼为主。 祭义宰我曰：吾闻鬼神之名，不知所谓。 子曰：气也者，神之盛也。 魄也者，鬼之盛也。 么口鬼与神，教之至也。 郊特牲曰：魂气归于天者，以魂本附气，人死则气必浮。 又曰：体魄降于地者，以魄本归形，人死则形归于土。 圣人绿生事死，制其祭祀。 存亡既异，别为作名。 改生之神曰魂#10，改生之鬼曰魄#11。 合魂与魄，命其名曰鬼神以尊事。 故日二．明命鬼神，以为黔首。
